posts.title: Domo Chronicles: Project Yuki pt. 2
posts.markdown:
well, since the first article I wrote did so well I decided to do another one. lol hmm… well let see… I guess I’ll just continue where I left off then.^_^

After crashing the clean red car, I was suuper bummed and had possibly one of the worst months in my life. Which was just full of bad-luck streaks. I had just changed the oil, and did a tune up with new spark plugs and wires before crashing the car. I also had to drive to the biggest nissan meet f the year in my rental car(2009 Chevy mailbu). Then, I nearly lost my debit card just before the event. lol and to top if all off it was a week until my birthday when I had crashed it last march. So…yeah…that month wasn’t very kind to me. lol

Initially I couldn’t decide what car I wanted next, so I just started looking around at all kinds of cars. From rx-7’s to corolla’s. While, I always wanted a corolla, I wasn’t ready for the work that it takes to put in those cars just yet. I still felt like a 240 was the way to go. Then one day my buddy Jamie said that his brother reggie had his 240 just chillin at there house and that they were thinking of selling it. After going down to check it out, I had thought it was okay, but it needed some work.

The day I showed up to buy the car, it was running but just barely. the thing was like driving a smoke show, and for some reason ran suuuper rich. I totally smoke screened out the freeway, while driving up to the ferry in bremerton,wa. I used roughly 1/2 a tank driving only 20-40 miles. lol

Now, here’s the icing on the cake. After waiting in line for the ferry, It was time to start boarding. So, I go to start the car….and…..nothing. the thing would not start. I ended having to get pushed by essentially what was a forklift with a huge tire on the front, into an open parkinglot to fix the issue. After talking to my buddy ricky, he told me to pop the injectors out, and let the car idle till it runs out of gas. that thing probably ran for a good 2 minutes straight with NO injectors plugged in. So, deciding this motor had something up with it, we decided to put Anna under the knife, and stick my motor from the red car in it.

poor thing………

*side note: when we had the red car towed up to my buddy’s shop after I crashed it, we decided to have some fun with it. lol

HELLA FLUSH!

we needed something to prop up the backend of this white S13 shell. then we realized, let’s put it ontop of my car! haha sadly, this is how it lived out the rest of it’s days before being towed off to the big racetrack in the sky

Anyways, back on topic! So, we pulled the POS single cam motor that was in the grey car a.k.a Anna to replace it with my dual cam from the red car!

Here’s the motor that just doesn’t like black people apparently. I later sold this to my other friend tim, who has had zero problems with it what so ever… lol

doing some cleaning on the engine bay and prepping to stick the motor in.

Once we got the motor in, I as a lot happier. Since the single cam motors are pretty gutless compared to the dual-cam ones. Shortly thereafter I got my bucket seat  and some other parts transferred over. It was then that I realized I needed a new steering wheel to fit in my bucket sit. lol

The car had also came with some tein coils, and I gotta say. For a while I was pretty happy just driving another 240 again. But because I was so spoiled with a really clean car, I felt like this one would never be able to live up to the potential like my previous car. I was thinking about fixing all the body damage on the car, but I later found out the whole core support would have to be replaced.

I was just curious one day, and started looking at some 240’s again. I then came across this really clean cherry red one. Once I saw the phone number of who was selling it I immediately realized who it was. Just so happens to be it was the same old guy, that I bought my previous red car from. I still to this day don’t know why I just didn’t get a car from him in the first place. but so far I’m happy with how things have turned out. This is how the car was the first day I brang it home.

the car was a perfect starter for me. the body was straight for the most part, the interior was clean, and the motor ran fine. I realized that the wheels were horrible though ,so I later changed them out.

So far I’ve been lucky and all of the cars I’ve owned have had really clean interiors.

just like the old red car I bought, the old guy gave me a factory brochure for this one as well.

managed to change out the horrible,horrible wheels that it came with.lol

I then started moving stuff over from the grey car, over to this one

my bucket seat, wheel, and a few other knick knacks like squash air freshner, and jdm option sticky pad for the dash that made the interior look pretty nice. lol

I also forgot to mention. I’ve always had a domo on my car. even in the previous maroon and grey cars. So, now I’m kinda superstitious about not having one. haha^_^ I decided to go buy a new one for this car. lol

Since I had two cars, it gave me a chance to just daily drive the grey one, and start building up the red car. Since it was a really good base to start with, I figured I’d start coming up with some ideas on what to do. My friend ricky ended up giving me a few great ideas, and things just started going from there. But, you won’t get to see what that is quite yet. You’ll have to stick around for the next part of this to see what I have in store for the red car.

Sorry for makin you guys read a novel again…like I said… it’s kind of a loong story. haha lemme know what you all think. Also if you have any questions feel free to post them up in the comments! thanks!^_^

posts.title: Domo Chronicles: Project Yuki pt. 3
posts.markdown: yooo, what’s up everybody. I’ve got some freetime here at work so I figured I’d update the cliffhanger post from last week. lol ikuze!! The C’s garage 180sx with the type-x kit and in midnight purple pictured above is one of my inspirations for building this new car. I had never really payed much attention to the type-x stuff before. However, once I saw it in midnight purple I was drooling for days. lol Just to put it out there, I’m not necessarily trying to copy this car with my build, but  It was my plan to use certain things that I really liked from it, and then add my own style to things. Now,usually I don’t name my cars, but since this car is special I figured I could make an exception. lol I’ve decided to call this one Yuki(雪). Now initially you’re probably thinking “why are you calling this car yuki when it’s not even related to anything like snow or even white.” Well, theres some background story to that one. In the anime Haruhi Suzumiya my favorite character happens to be Nagato Yuki. Much like myself she tinkers with computers throughout the show. mostly because she’s an alient though, but you’ll have to actually watch the show to understand that one. Anyways, another reason for me naming this car yuki is because when I imagine her, I think the color purple(probably because of her hair). So.. yeah.. Another one of my goals for this car was to do things right, clean, and not flashy. For example this car has the dmax hood carbon and grenador side mirrors, and the flash red bride bucket seat. Mine will have none of that. But I did decide to go with the nice clean fitting OEM Type-X aero instead of the version select replica stuff. Because, frankly I would rather spend more money on parts that are durable and fit better. Also, I won’t be doing any crazy motorswaps or anything. Since this is my Daily Driver and will be seeing track time only a few times a month I’m stickin to the ol’ faithful KA since it’s a really reliable motor if you treat it well. plus I’m poor Anyways, enough of my babbling. I’ll get to the parts updates now. lol also, note we did all the bodywork by hand with a sanding block. Since, with a DA you have issues getting everything totally flat and smooth. It’s much more do-able with a block by hand. It just takes a lot longer and it’s a Pain.>_< But, I think in the end I’ll be happy I went this route. we first noticed it looks like a small kid had jumped up and down on the roof, so we got everything all smoothed and evened out there. finally I hit it with some primer and got everything all nice a smooth^_^ goin to town with the first pass of filling all the little door dings with body filler, and getting everything smooth Got some PBM subframe risers to correct for subframe squatting, a full set of front and rear pillowball arms powder coated in metallic midnight purple by Yamato Garage(they look blue I this pic), and finally I sprayed the subframe,rear knuckles and LCA’s in silver. Some Energy suspension steering rack bushings,megan racing tie rods and tie rod ends, new tie rod bushings, and Bride racing gloves! My 97’ Q45 rotors for the front, S14 non-abs rotors for the rear. Both are 5lug, and slotted . Also I have Porterfield Q45 pads for the front, and Hawk HPS for the rear. shiny new 5-lug hubs! Slightly used Kaaz 2-way I picked up for an absolute steal! Here’s a sample shot with all the rear end stuff bolted on. I have Megan Racing coils I will eventually put on, but for painting purposes I’m leaving the stock stuff on for now. picked up an awesome 6.5” peaker adapter and JCV speakers! yaay now I can actually hear things up front. instead of listening to dinky 3x6” ones. found an awesome deal for my oem type-x aero^_^ I got lucky and most of the stuff was already primered and ready to go for paint. it also just so happen to come with LED’s for my position lights!usually they look yellow-ish and like poo in general.lol   picked up some raybrig H4 housings and some 5900k Ploarg Halogen bulbs(not in pictures) then I got my Japanese plates to use at the track. lol Apparently my car will be from Sapporo wayy up in hokkaido. lol epic vacuum sealed spec stage 1 clutch and lightweight steel flywheel. my type-x tail-lights^_^ I still need to get the rps13 carbon center piece for it though apparently the nissan factory worker that was doing QC on them thought it’d be funny to leave me with a smiley face. lol pulled the POS single cam KA24e to start working on the engine bay.(yes it’s going to be painted as well) getting ready to start degreasing the engine bay shiny clleeaan^_^ yeah btw this is a horrible picture I had to take with my phone since I forgot my camera. lol Well, that’s about it up until now. I’m waiting on my type-x lip to show up from japan and other than that I just have to get some primer on the car, then have it shipped off to paint^_^ Hopefully you guys enjoy the build so far. I’ll be updating this along the way as I make more progress on it. lol lemme know your guys thoughts or suggestions in the comments or chatbox!

Got some PBM subframe risers to correct for subframe squatting, a full set of front and rear pillowball arms powder coated in metallic midnight purple by Yamato Garage(they look blue I this pic), and finally I sprayed the subframe,rear knuckles and LCA’s in silver.

My 97’ Q45 rotors for the front, S14 non-abs rotors for the rear. Both are 5lug, and slotted . Also I have Porterfield Q45 pads for the front, and Hawk HPS for the rear.

Here’s a sample shot with all the rear end stuff bolted on. I have Megan Racing coils I will eventually put on, but for painting purposes I’m leaving the stock stuff on for now.

picked up an awesome 6.5” peaker adapter and JCV speakers! yaay now I can actually hear things up front. instead of listening to dinky 3x6” ones.

found an awesome deal for my oem type-x aero^_^ I got lucky and most of the stuff was already primered and ready to go for paint.

it also just so happen to come with LED’s for my position lights!usually they look yellow-ish and like poo in general.lol

 

picked up some raybrig H4 housings and some 5900k Ploarg Halogen bulbs(not in pictures)

then I got my Japanese plates to use at the track. lol Apparently my car will be from Sapporo wayy up in hokkaido. lol

epic vacuum sealed spec stage 1 clutch and lightweight steel flywheel.

my type-x tail-lights^_^ I still need to get the rps13 carbon center piece for it though

apparently the nissan factory worker that was doing QC on them thought it’d be funny to leave me with a smiley face. lol

pulled the POS single cam KA24e to start working on the engine bay.(yes it’s going to be painted as well)

getting ready to start degreasing the engine bay

shiny clleeaan^_^ yeah btw this is a horrible picture I had to take with my phone since I forgot my camera. lol

Well, that’s about it up until now. I’m waiting on my type-x lip to show up from japan and other than that I just have to get some primer on the car, then have it shipped off to paint^_^ Hopefully you guys enjoy the build so far. I’ll be updating this along the way as I make more progress on it. lol lemme know your guys thoughts or suggestions in the comments or chatbox!

posts.title: Yuki: More Goodies!
posts.markdown:
Hey everyone! just thought I’d update you all on some parts I recently got in for yuki^_^ Everything’s comin along really well, and all I need now is to go down and buy paint, then get her sprayed in midnight purple. If everything goes smoothly Yuki should be finished by the 27th of this month just in time for the annual Golden Gardens meet and XXX Root-beer drive in meet! anyways, here’s some pics of the progress. lol

Here’s my epic race queen air fresheners I just got in the mail!

type-x sidemarkers!!! wee! they even came with the pigtails too.

the holy grail of type-x stuff! my front lip!! sadly, it’s not the oem polyeurothane, but hey I only paid 300 bucks for it shipped from Yahoo Auctions Japan. So, you can’t beat that price.

Last but not least I picked up a set of these baby’s! Work CR-Kai’s in 17x9 +15. shoutout to my buddy ricky for not painting them silver! The car above isn’t mine, but it gives you an idea of what they should look like. Since this car has the type-x front and rear stuff.

Here’s the actual wheels I’ve got and what they look like on my buddies car.

 

well, that’s about it for now. I’ll update with more pics once I start getting into the paint later on this month. hope you enjoyed the pics! ja ne!

posts.title: Yuki: Misc. Updates
posts.markdown: Hey guys, Hopefully you all haven't run away from the lack of posts. I wanna thank everyone for giving me their input on the schedule. I've decided to go ahead and remove it so I stick to making posts at my leisure. This way, I'm not rushing or fighitng to come up with things to post. lol Anywho, I did some more work on Yuki this past weekend^_^ check it out! Managed to fit my rear Tanabe strut bar on without even removing the interior panels!! Also, a quick shoutout goes to Yuta Akaishi from the Japanese Drift Team HeartBreaker for offering these decals in return for donating to help those affected by the tsunami/eartquake in Japan. IF you have time, head on over to his blog at http://yuta-akaishi.blogspot.com/ Took some pictures before heading into work for some overtime this past saturday. I finally got the rest of the type-x aero on! I've since lowered roughly an inch all the way around though. another shot at 6am before work. :p There are still 2 things with the car as a whole that I really need to fix. First is there's alot of backlash in my Kaaz 2-way. So, whenever I go around a tight corner with the clutch engaged it feels like the entire rear-end is going to explode. haha I'm going to pull it apart this coming weekend and check if the shims are on the right sides, if not hopefully it's just my final gear that got pwned. My buddy has a spare open diff, so I'll try stealing his pumpkin and seeing if that works. The second thing is my transmission. The syncro's are worn pretty bad, and you really have to granny shift the thing everywhere. haha Although the brand new SPEC Clutch and Lightweight flywheel do make a big difference. I have a feeling that the 2-way smacking all over the place will eventually cause my tranny go get KO'ed as well. So, I'll be getting it rebuilt within the next month or so hopefully :p Well... that's it for now. Hopefully once I finish getting the tranny rebuilt I can give Yuki some track time! haha

Well... that's it for now. Hopefully once I finish getting the tranny rebuilt I can give Yuki some track time! haha

posts.title: Shop Preview: Complete Garage RE-Sanai
posts.markdown: Hey guys! Hopefully your all enjoying the new stuff Derrick and Ashley have been helping me out with. Recently, I've been talking with my friend Eichi Ishii who is the shop manager for a shop in Maebashi-shi, Gunma Prefecture, Japan called Complete Garage RE-Sanai. I figured it'd be cool to do a preview post for you guys. I'm going to be vising this shop in person when I go visit japan this winter, so I'll do a full write-up once that time comes. For now though, here's a preview of what's to come!^_^ You can visit their facebook page, or the website in the following links! Enjoy! Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Complete-Garage-RE-Sanai/142074525809490 Website: http://www.re-sanai.com/   Garage RE-sanai works mainly with rotaries like the RX-7(FD3S and FC3S) and is actively involved in various motorsports events like Tokyo Autosalon and Super GT. Specifically, the GT300 class.     Here is Eichi’s personal car. nothing too special about it, which is why I like it. It’s very simple and clean^_^ the blue and yellow are two really good colors for this car I think.   I’ve always loved the look of FC’s and this one with the Watanabe’s looks PERFECT!   They have cusom car packages that customers can have built to suit their tastes. For example, the below car is called a Reiden package. It comes with specific wheels/tire, aero, interior, and motor packages.   If you look REAALY closely, you can see this beast sitting inside the garage in the picture with the FC above. It’s an old school rx-3. Here’s another oldie rx-7, which in this case is an FB. personsally I don’t like the bodysyle much because it reminds me of a bigger version of the Lotus Elan. But, some people really like this car. lol More FC goodness^_^ I think so far this is my favorite car. lol Here’s a completely stock looking rx-8 looking to get some upgrades. *squints* I think  I see a subaru in there…0_o Here’s another FD that’s somewhat similar to Eichi’s car. I really like the front bumper that’s on this one. lol
posts.html:
Hey guys! Hopefully your all enjoying the new stuff Derrick and Ashley have been helping me out with. Recently, I've been talking with my friend Eichi Ishii who is the shop manager for a shop in Maebashi-shi, Gunma Prefecture, Japan called Complete Garage RE-Sanai. I figured it'd be cool to do a preview post for you guys.

I'm going to be vising this shop in person when I go visit japan this winter, so I'll do a full write-up once that time comes. For now though, here's a preview of what's to come!^_^

You can visit their facebook page, or the website in the following links! Enjoy!

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Complete-Garage-RE-Sanai/142074525809490

Website: http://www.re-sanai.com/

 

Garage RE-sanai works mainly with rotaries like the RX-7(FD3S and FC3S) and is actively involved in various motorsports events like Tokyo Autosalon and Super GT. Specifically, the GT300 class.

 

 

Here is Eichi’s personal car. nothing too special about it, which is why I like it. It’s very simple and clean^_^ the blue and yellow are two really good colors for this car I think.

 

I’ve always loved the look of FC’s and this one with the Watanabe’s looks PERFECT!

 

They have cusom car packages that customers can have built to suit their tastes. For example, the below car is called a Reiden package. It comes with specific wheels/tire, aero, interior, and motor packages.

 

If you look REAALY closely, you can see this beast sitting inside the garage in the picture with the FC above. It’s an old school rx-3.

Here’s another oldie rx-7, which in this case is an FB. personsally I don’t like the bodysyle much because it reminds me of a bigger version of the Lotus Elan. But, some people really like this car. lol

More FC goodness^_^ I think so far this is my favorite car. lol

Here’s a completely stock looking rx-8 looking to get some upgrades.

squints I think  I see a subaru in there…0_o

Here’s another FD that’s somewhat similar to Eichi’s car. I really like the front bumper that’s on this one. lol

posts.title: Yuki: XJG Photoshoot
posts.markdown:
Hey everyone! My buddy Darrick Snyder of XJGphoto and Mugenjou came into town a few weeks ago before he was deployed out to Misawa, Japan for the Air Force. He took some epic shots while he was here, so all the credit the the exception of a few go to him. You’ll see what I mean by that further down in the post

btw, in this pic directly below, that’s me walking away from Yuki like an action star from an explosion all while rocking a k-on shirt! ^_^ I’m just that awesome, what can I say! haha

Domo and Yuki chillin at the airport waiting for Darrick to show up.

gotta love some of the overcast up here in the Northwest! it makes for some really great shots!

*sigh* still need to paint my front fender wells>_<  The location we found was pretty awesome and completely on accident too. My buddy was telling us there was a good park to take scenic type photos up on beacon hill in Seattle. However, we ended up running into this awesome dead-end. haha

I think the this shot really shows how well the type-x aero flows with the car <3

It started to rain jus as we were getting mid-way through the shoot at this spot

Yuki Longing to go back across the water to the motherland.

I really wish I had my nissan badge on here >_< this is down at the ferry landing by my house in Mukilteo,WA and I’ve always wanted to take pics here because of how wide open, and close to the water it is. Sadly, I just never had the right camera. haha

This rolling shot, and the one below it are unique. Usually the driver drives the car, and the photographer takes the rolling shots. This time, it was the other way around. haha Darrick really wanted to drive my car, and since he’s one of my best friends I trusted him enough not to plow the thing into a ditch. Luckily he didn’t, and turns out I’m not that bad behind a camera myself hehe looks like I’ll need to upgrade before my trip to Japan this summer!

*drools……*

Last but not least, an awesome pic of the LED’s in my cluster. I’ll see if I can scour up a few other pics from him. But, they look really blue in this. This pic is pretty sweet though, but since the bulbs are 6k, they have more white than blue in them.

posts.title: Yuki: Amsoil = best tranny fluid ever?
posts.markdown:
Just a quick update, I finally got around to swapping out Yuki’s Transmission fluid today with some Amsoil 75w90 GL-4 fluid. So far, after driving it today I can’t believe how much of a difference this has made!

Props go out to Ken(slider2828) for recommending this stuff to me, since I had always assumed most synthetic fluids were roughly the same. Even though my tranny already felt pretty good since its been rebuilt, its even better with the new fluid. Feels like I just drove it off the production lot and smooth as butta! haha Here’s a pic of the stuff I got. For those of you in Washington State, I picked my stuff up at Action Autoparts. Apparently they carry a bunch of other amsoil products too.

Anyways, like I was saying make sure you get this stuff. the FSM for s13’s recommend GL-4 fluid, and I think amsoil also makes some stuff in GL-5.

posts.title: Yuki: Type-x Cluster
posts.markdown: Hey everyone, Looks like I finally got some new goodies for Yuki. My buddy sold me a Type-x cluster he had laying around. These are pretty hard to come by because they only came on the 96-98 180sx's in Japan, so i'm pretty happy I scored one so easily. lol However, I'm probably going to replace the Carbon Fiber trim panel with just a standard black one. To get this thing to work, apparently I need an S14 temp and speed sensor. The plugs on the back are different, but according to a few threads i've read over on zilvia there's some 95 Maxima plugs that will work. After that its just a matter of putting the wiring together. I Also found out, to convert the KMH to MPH I need to solder in a resister to the back of the circuit board. So, nothing too difficult. I think this will be a nice winter project for me to tackle from inside the warm house instead of being out in the cold garage/shop like last year. haha :p

posts.title: Yuki: Swift Springs Preview
posts.markdown: Lookie what I got in the mail today!^_^ props to Ken for suggesting I get these swift springs before doing my corner balancing. So far there's some noticeable differences between the springs that come with my Megan Racing Street coilovers and these Swift springs. They feel about half the weight, and also the coils look slightly smaller, and better spaced apart. I plan on doing a full write up on these things and how to install them tomorrow.

posts.title: Yuki: Type-x Lip!

posts.title: Yuki: Swift Springs, Corner Balance, and Alignment
posts.markdown: Hey everyone! First off, i'd like to say Happy New Year, and hopefully this next one is better than the last for all of us.^_^ Hopefully everything had a good holidays/new year as well. With that said I'll make it a goal to be a bit more active around here this year. lol Anyways, I recently had some upgrades on Yuki that I wanted to share and have just been super lazy in posting them. I had heard great things from friends about how much of a difference getting a corner balance on your car was. So, I decided to fork up the cash and try it out. Luckily before doing so, Ken started talking to me and convinced me to get some new swift springs before going through with the corner balance. I was able to pick up a set for a great deal of $377 shipped for both sets from the guys over at Touge Factory to replace the old crappy ones on my Megan Street series coilovers. Here's the 2 sets springs I ended up getting. Front: 65MM(2.5") Inner Diameter, 8k(448lbs) Spring Rate, 178mm(7") Length Rear: 65mm(2.5") Innder Diameter, 6k(336lbs) Spring Rate, 203mm(8") Length Here's a quick before shot when I got started replacing them. Got the coil all dissassembled Now, here's another piece that ken helped me out on. As you can see from the picture above, the collar that the spring rests on, has this stupid little plastic washer. Ken reccomended I change them out to some thrust bearings. This will enabled the coil to spin freely under compression. Since what you don't want is the spring to compress, then get binded on that plastic washer while still trying to compress.I was able to pick them up for $25 bucks a piece here from Summit Racing and they're 65mm(2.5") for the inner diameter. 1 Quantity is basically 2 thrust bearings, and 4 washers. So you'd need one for each corner of the car. Here's a quick shot of everything together in the front. You can really tell how much of a difference the thurst bearings make since the spring is able to freely spin now. It's also important to note where the perch was at before doing this. you don't want to have all this extra room or looseness at the top of the spring. lol Here's a quick before shot of the rear and the after shot of the rear Here's a quick comparison of the two different srings. One big thing that stands out between the two is the number of coils, coil thickness and the weight of the coils. I took both of them down to the post office to get accurately weighed. I'll list the specs here below. One thing to note, is I found out oddly enough that I actually had S14 rear springs with my megan coilovers. So, my before spring length was 220mm so the weight was vastly heavier than the swifts. I'd assume though that if the spring was 200mm it would weigh at least 3lbs. Front: Megans=2.88lbs(180mm), Swift=2.41lbs(180mm) Rear: Megans=3.58(220mm), Swift=2.5(200mm) Comparison for the front springs Comparison of the rear springs. Overall the feeling with these springs is a WORLD of difference. I'd highly reccomend them as an upgrade if you don't feel like shelling out 1.6k+ for upper teir coilovers. This hands down takes a set of budget coils and makes then a ton better. You really notice it driving at around 35-45mph. The slight vibrations and small bumps are totally eliminated with the swift springs. I had my megan dampening set to 15 on both the front and rear when I tested this. Okay, that was rather long winded. Now, moving onto the corner balance. I ended up getting mine done at a place locally here in seattle called Truline. They had great customer service, guys who have experience in working with cars that have pillow ball suspension links, and aftermarket suspension. I also got my alignment, and wheel balancing done while I was there. For everything it ended up running me about $450 bucks. One cool feature they have is High-Speed balancing. It's basically where they balance the front wheels while they're still bolted to the car. I ended up doing this on the front of the car, and just a normal balance for the rear. Moving onto the alignment, yet again Ken helped me out for which specs were optimal for the S13. After checking out the Nissan Road Race forum the specs I went with are below. The amount of camber you use is totally up to the wheel setup/personal preference really. When it was all said and done, Front: Toe: 0 Degrees Caster: 7.5 Degrees Camber: 3 Degrees Rear Toe: .2 Degrees Camber: 2.5 Degrees Going with the smaller wheel base and setting the caster to 7.5 degrees is a noticeable difference and makes the car alot more responsive and fun to drive! Moving onto the corner balance, all I can say is WOW. They loaded the car with dead weight for the driver, and basically set the car to where weight is spread out evenly across all 4 wheels. This can change over time due to suspension, and things like the chassis flexing and bending over time(It is a 21 year old car). In the corner the car feels alot more predicable and there's a TON more grip now then before. It's almost scary how much better the car feels now. For comparison, my buddy who owns a track prepped AE86 recently drove my car and commented on how it handled very similar in terms of response and stability while cornering.

Anyways, I recently had some upgrades on Yuki that I wanted to share and have just been super lazy in posting them. I had heard great things from friends about how much of a difference getting a corner balance on your car was. So, I decided to fork up the cash and try it out.

Luckily before doing so, Ken started talking to me and convinced me to get some new swift springs before going through with the corner balance. I was able to pick up a set for a great deal of $377 shipped for both sets from the guys over at Touge Factory to replace the old crappy ones on my Megan Street series coilovers. Here's the 2 sets springs I ended up getting.

Front: 65MM(2.5") Inner Diameter, 8k(448lbs) Spring Rate, 178mm(7") Length

Rear: 65mm(2.5") Innder Diameter, 6k(336lbs) Spring Rate, 203mm(8") Length

Here's a quick before shot when I got started replacing them.

Got the coil all dissassembled

Now, here's another piece that ken helped me out on. As you can see from the picture above, the collar that the spring rests on, has this stupid little plastic washer. Ken reccomended I change them out to some thrust bearings. This will enabled the coil to spin freely under compression. Since what you don't want is the spring to compress, then get binded on that plastic washer while still trying to compress.I was able to pick them up for $25 bucks a piece here from Summit Racing and they're 65mm(2.5") for the inner diameter. 1 Quantity is basically 2 thrust bearings, and 4 washers. So you'd need one for each corner of the car.

Here's a quick shot of everything together in the front.

You can really tell how much of a difference the thurst bearings make since the spring is able to freely spin now. It's also important to note where the perch was at before doing this. you don't want to have all this extra room or looseness at the top of the spring. lol

Here's a quick before shot of the rear

and the after shot of the rear

Here's a quick comparison of the two different srings. One big thing that stands out between the two is the number of coils, coil thickness and the weight of the coils. I took both of them down to the post office to get accurately weighed. I'll list the specs here below. One thing to note, is I found out oddly enough that I actually had S14 rear springs with my megan coilovers. So, my before spring length was 220mm so the weight was vastly heavier than the swifts. I'd assume though that if the spring was 200mm it would weigh at least 3lbs.

Front: Megans=2.88lbs(180mm), Swift=2.41lbs(180mm)

Rear: Megans=3.58(220mm), Swift=2.5(200mm)

Comparison for the front springs

Comparison of the rear springs.

Overall the feeling with these springs is a WORLD of difference. I'd highly reccomend them as an upgrade if you don't feel like shelling out 1.6k+ for upper teir coilovers. This hands down takes a set of budget coils and makes then a ton better.

You really notice it driving at around 35-45mph. The slight vibrations and small bumps are totally eliminated with the swift springs. I had my megan dampening set to 15 on both the front and rear when I tested this.

Okay, that was rather long winded. Now, moving onto the corner balance. I ended up getting mine done at a place locally here in seattle called Truline. They had great customer service, guys who have experience in working with cars that have pillow ball suspension links, and aftermarket suspension. I also got my alignment, and wheel balancing done while I was there. For everything it ended up running me about $450 bucks. One cool feature they have is High-Speed balancing. It's basically where they balance the front wheels while they're still bolted to the car. I ended up doing this on the front of the car, and just a normal balance for the rear.

Moving onto the alignment, yet again Ken helped me out for which specs were optimal for the S13. After checking out the Nissan Road Race forum the specs I went with are below. The amount of camber you use is totally up to the wheel setup/personal preference really. When it was all said and done,

Front:
Toe: 0 Degrees
Caster: 7.5 Degrees
Camber: 3 Degrees

Rear
Toe: .2 Degrees
Camber: 2.5 Degrees

Going with the smaller wheel base and setting the caster to 7.5 degrees is a noticeable difference and makes the car alot more responsive and fun to drive!

Moving onto the corner balance, all I can say is WOW. They loaded the car with dead weight for the driver, and basically set the car to where weight is spread out evenly across all 4 wheels. This can change over time due to suspension, and things like the chassis flexing and bending over time(It is a 21 year old car).

In the corner the car feels alot more predicable and there's a TON more grip now then before. It's almost scary how much better the car feels now. For comparison, my buddy who owns a track prepped AE86 recently drove my car and commented on how it handled very similar in terms of response and stability while cornering.

posts.title: Yuki: HID's, Q45 calipers & Kenwood Deck
posts.markdown: Hey everyone, Yuki recently got some new Kensun 6k HID's, Q45 calipers,and a Kenwood deck so I figured I would post up about it. haha HID's aside, the box they came in was super awesome. too bad it didn't come with a "Warning: TOP SECRET" label on it. lol   Recently, one of my Halogen bulbs went out, so I decided to make the jump to some 6k bi-xenon HID's. We ran into some issues with my stock harness and realized that a couple of the copper connectors inside my plug were broken. Luckily, I just so happened to buy a little soldering iron at ACE Hardware the other day so, my buddy Mike put his soldering skills to the test. :p Overall I'm pretty happy with these HID's. I have them in a set of Raybrig Purple/Blue housings and the resulting color is this cool Evergreen/Blue combo. haha My only gripe, is the cutoff line isn't quit what I would've liked, but its better than alot of other housings out there. *shrugs* I Figure its not bad when these housings were only designed for Halogen bulbs in the first place. haha I also ended up replacing both front Q45 calipers. Come to find out, both sides had a seized piston even though they were only 4-6 months old.... The passenger side stated to get a bunch of rust on it, and when I checked behind the piston boot, it was caked in there. So, something tells me whoever put these back together didn't do a very good job. Let's hope I have better luck with these calipers. Granted, these are Iron, so rust is to be expected. Maybe once I take care of my SR, i'll switch to some aluminum Z32's or 350z brembo's ;) Also, my stopping power is ALOT better now that I actually have use of all 4 pistons. haha I'm actually surprised with how well I can stop without locking up the fronts now. Lastly, I went on over to Car Toys on Lynnwood,WA the other day to see what they had for CD decks. I recently got an iPhone4s and wanted a newer deck to replace my old sony so I could take advantage of Bluetooth audio, and something hands free to talk on the phone when I'm driving. This Kenwood deck ended up being the result. Quick shot of the deck installed. I was at my friend John's place after buying it, and he was kind enough to solder everything, and heat shrink it for me.^_^ Notice the external mic sitting by Yuki-chan? One cool feature I really like about this deck is the hands free, and auto answer features! I actually had a kenwood deck in my first 240, and the one thing I think they did really well was navigation of settings and all that shtuff. This deck, also follows that same concept. so when you go into settings like.. 3 layers deep. all you need to do is push the back button 3 times to get back to the main menu so to speak. I really like this type of setup over the Sony deck I had. Anyways, this is getting long winded. lol So far, I'm happy with the deck, but the settings don't appear to be right. The bass overloads both my front 6" speakers and rear 6x9" ones. So, I'm heading over to Mike's place today to get stuff fine tuned, and also test out his 10" sub. My 6x9"s are pretty old, so maybe they'll need replacing soon as well. lol

posts.title: New Helmet: Ayrton Senna Tribute, HJC AR10-II
posts.markdown: Hey everyone, Motorsport season is about to get started here in the northwest and a few months back I was in the market for a new helmet. After doing my research I finally decided on a HJC AR10-II. This helmet overall was comfortable, and still looked pretty good for the price. Another bonus was the fact it had a different variety of cheek pads to choose from. Having recently seen the new movie/Documentary Senna(click here for my review), I decide I would paint my helmet with the same overall theme as Senna's as a tribute. I contacted Nick Kennell over at Sinistair Kustoms who I knew through my friend to see if he would be able to come up with a design similar to that of ayrton's without copying it completely. The end result was amazing, and so far I'm really happy with it. Here's some pics that show the journey the helmet went through, along with the end result. Enjoy! *note* to see bigger versions of the images below, just click on them.   Getting everything lined up with some masking tape to see what type of lines I wanted   Laying the Primer down   Base coat of white! Taping off for the main stripes First set of color in Yellow. Laying down the two main stripts with white stripes on the edge Finished product with reverse colored pinstripes! I ended up Adding a personal finishing touch with the Senna "S"-Curves Logo! Overall I'm really happy with how the helmet turned out. The blue looks a tad too bright in certain lighting but, other than that Nick did an awesome job painting it! Now all I need is a Red racing suit and I'll be set! :p Update: I ended up also picking up a smoked shield that looks awesome!
posts.html:
Hey everyone,

Motorsport season is about to get started here in the northwest and a few months back I was in the market for a new helmet. After doing my research I finally decided on a HJC AR10-II. This helmet overall was comfortable, and still looked pretty good for the price. Another bonus was the fact it had a different variety of cheek pads to choose from.

Having recently seen the new movie/Documentary Senna(click here for my review), I decide I would paint my helmet with the same overall theme as Senna's as a tribute.

I contacted Nick Kennell over at Sinistair Kustoms who I knew through my friend to see if he would be able to come up with a design similar to that of ayrton's without copying it completely. The end result was amazing, and so far I'm really happy with it. Here's some pics that show the journey the helmet went through, along with the end result. Enjoy!
note to see bigger versions of the images below, just click on them.

 

Getting everything lined up with some masking tape to see what type of lines I wanted

 

Laying the Primer down

 

Base coat of white!

Taping off for the main stripes

First set of color in Yellow.

Laying down the two main stripts with white stripes on the edge

Finished product with reverse colored pinstripes!


I ended up Adding a personal finishing touch with the Senna "S"-Curves Logo!

Overall I'm really happy with how the helmet turned out. The blue looks a tad too bright in certain lighting but, other than that Nick did an awesome job painting it! Now all I need is a Red racing suit and I'll be set! :p

Update: I ended up also picking up a smoked shield that looks awesome!

posts.title: Yuki: Purple Rain Pt.2
posts.markdown:
hey guys^_^ just thought I’d throw out some updates for yuki. lol I got back from the paint booth last night after finally seeing her in purple. Man… words cannot describe how amazing this color is. The pictures just don’t do it justice. Also, these are phone pics, so once I get everything all put together I’ll be sure to get some proper pics taken. lol


Depending on how the light hits it, this car looks black, purple, or blue. I can’t wait to get everything bolted on and see how it looks in the sunlight!

checking to see how the purple contrasts with the bronze. overall it looks awesome!

We also got the whole engine bay sprayed in the same color^_^ unlike most S13 owners I like my car to be all one color. Instead of it being purple on the outside, then popping the hood and seeing red or something. lol

The car should be done curing at some point tomorrow, then we’ll roll it  out of the shop, and start bolting all the other pieces to it, and dropping the motor in. Stay tuned for more updates as this thing gets finished up^_^

posts.title: Japan Trip: Day 2 (Gunma Prefecture, Complete Garage Re-Sanai, Mt.Akina)
posts.markdown: Okay, so it took me a couple days to get this one uploaded just because I was so busy while I was in Gunma. haha A full gallery of all of my pictures can be seen at the bottom of the post after the jump! Day 2 of my trip started early. Having to meet my friend Eichi up at the Shin-Maebashi station in Gunma around 10am required me to getup around 5am, and get on the train by 6 to beat the morning rush. Spotted this AKB48 store while at the station in Harajuku. Funny story actually as to why I had to stop there instead of continuing on towards gunma.... I forgot this little guy. My present for Eichi which was smoked salmon. haha It didn't hit me until I had gotten to the Harajuku station, so I had to get off the train, and go back for it. lol After that, more chaos ensued at Omiya station north of tokyo.(top middle in the image) I had a little bit of trouble trying to figure out which train I needed to take because the line for Orange colored trains went into two opposite directions. My final destination was Shim-Maebashi station. After missing the first train in the proper direction, I figured out what was going on, and managed to get on the right one. I'll post about my route below: JR Yamanote Line(Light Green): Meguro -> Ikebukuro JR Saikyo Line(Turqoise): Ikebukuro -> Omiya JR Takasaki Line (Orange): Omiya -> Takasaki JR Takasaki Line (Orange): Takaksaki-> Shim-Maebashi After arriving in Maebashi, Eichi was waiting for me with his blue Mazda RX-7(FD3s). This is his personal car, and also doubles as a shop car featuring all parts from his shop Complete Garage Re-Sanai. First task of the day was to head over to the shop, and check out all the awesome rotary goodness. Inside the shop I was greeted with a surprise! Their Time Attack car driven at Tsukuba Circuit by none other than Tarzan Yamada himself. If I remember correctly, Eichi said it did a time of 58 seconds and had about 600hp. After a bit of shooting, we grabbed some drinks from this cool shop owned vending machine. It seems to not like foreigners though since we put in 150Yen($1 USD), and instead of giving a lemon drink, it gave us Mello Yello which was about 30yen cheaper. Wondering why it decided to steal money, Eichi called up the Vendor to get them to come out and fix it. While waiting for the maintenance guy to show up, I went and took a few more shots After about 10-15 minute, this guy showed up to fix the machine, and give us our money back. Which I thought was really nice. After closing up the shop, we headed over to meetup with Eichi's friend Terushige(Teru for short). At that same time, the handle seemed to had broken on the FD..:( and his window also doesn't work, so he can't jump in Nascar style either. Luckily, Teru had some tools stashed away in his Curren and helped fix the cable in the FD's door. It's also worth noting that the Curren has the same platform as the GT-Four Celica, except its FF, and has a slightly different look to it. After fixing the door issue, we headed over to a Pudding/Dessert Cafe called Crayon. Apparently I was the first foreigner ever to set foot in the place, which was kind of cool. haha Eichi then introduced me to the owner Okada-san, and said he also drove a RX-7. Interested I asked "what does it look like." well, a short walk around the side of the shop answered that question. The person in black in the background is Okada-san, and this is his 800hp touge attacking machine. When I asked him if he drives this at the circuit, he simple replied "no, only on the touge."..0_o There were two things that really stood out to me about this car(other than the 800hp). This awesome Carbon Drag style wing was one of them The second thing, was this GIGANTIC turbo. haha that pretty much explained the 800hp. The inlet on that thing was bigger than my entire fist!! Okada-san had one last surprise for us before we left. A Shiny new 2011 Nissan GTR! ^_^ While it was stock, it still looked super nice. lol After the meeting Okada-san and his awesome cars, we got some lunch. I had Katsudon with some cold soba noodles and dipping sauce which was actually alot of food for only 880Yen! After lunch Eichi and I headed up to the legendary Mt.Haruna(Akina) which was roughly 30 minutes away. It looks EXACTLY like is does in the anime, even the water tower behind us is the same. haha I took a couple more fancy pics of the rx-7, before heading to another familiar place.... Yup, that's right. Lake Haruna(Akina)!! ^_^ The Lighting here was really odd because it would go from light to dark every couple minutes. lol As we were leaving I took a couple more pictures, and its sort of hard to see here, but there were black doughnut circles all over the place from people coming here at night and playing around drifting and doing doughnuts. haha Later that night, after we got back to Eichi's place, Teru-san stopped by with a surprise, His Rx-7! this one, like eichi's was running a 13BT, and had about 1.4bar(17 psi) of boost making about 400hp. As we were sitting at Eichi's place talking with Taru, he got a message from his friend that she was making Korean food and hanging out with some of his other friends and girlfriend, and invited us to come try some. So we headed over to a bar/lounge called Clover that one of the friends owns. After talking to them, they were all really nice, and surprised I came to Gunma all the way from Seattle. oh and also that I spoke japanese. haha The food above is Called bibimbap, and it was rice with hamburger, egg, onions, and some other misc stuff. It was really good, and I actually couldn't eat all of it, since I was still full from having a late lunch. They also had a Super Famicom there as well, with a bunch of games including Rockman. lol After eating and talking for a bit, we realized it was already 11pm. Since we had to getup around 4am to get started on going to ebisu circuit in the morning. We decided to call it a night, and get some sleep.       [gallery link="file" columns="4" orderby="post_date"]

posts.title: Japan Trip: Day 3 (Team Orange Drift School @ Ebisu Circuit)
posts.markdown: For Day 3 of my trip, Luckily I was able to save up some money, and also get some help to attend the Team Orange Drift School at Ebisu Circuit! Eichi and I got up around 4am, and headed out to Fukushima prefecture around 5. Naturally, with a car like his, you don't want door dings, so you make sure nobody parks next to you. :p This 7-11 is within walking distance from the Apartment. So, we stopped in to grab a few things before hitting the road for the 3hour road trek up north. Breakfast consisted of Milk Tea made by Kirin of all companies. haha I thought they only made beer..*shrugs*. I also had gotten some Tamago Pan(Egg bun), but had eaten both of them before realizing I Should've taken a picture. So, next time I'll make sure to do so. There were alot of tunnels along the way, some of which went on for a solid 2,000meters here's a shot from inside the tunnel There was some really nice scenery out here, and personally I like it a bit more out in the country compared to the city in Tokyo. lol We tried to catch up to this S15, which looked really nice, but the guy was going pretty deng fast. lol A few more cars spotted on the highway. This time it was a R33 and a 180sx. Really pretty road leading into Ebisu Circuit AT LAST! Ebisu!! We arrived a bit early, so I walked around and did some exploring. Here's is a picture of the Drift School Couse, with the Touge course above it, and the Higashi(East) course to the right behind it. The Higashi course is mainly used for grip driving and is featured in Best Motoring and Hot Version. After a little bit, we met up with Andy from Powervehicles.com and Naoto Suenaga From Team Orange. For those that don't know, both of these guys are profressional drifters and know what they're doing. This would be my weapon of choice for the day. a Nissan Silvia with .9bar(12 psi) of boost. in this pic, they were trying to fix an issue with the tire stem, since it was leaking air slowly. This car also had drift essentials like steering wheel, aftermarket gauges, bucket seat, coilovers,exhaust and an LSD. After a few quick pointers, they had me do doughnuts around those stacked cones. Doing left turn doughnuts was no problem, but right side ones was a completely different story. After some struggling with it, I finally was able to do it consistently both directions. Sadly, there's no pics of the rest of my skid-pad sessions, but I'll just break down what happened anyways. After doing doughnuts, they started me for doing e-brake entry into doughnuts around some cones. Once again, left handers were no problem. But, the right handers proved to be an issue. Than, to add fuel to the fire, it started to rain and I had to learn on the fly how to drift in the wet vs. dry. Having done neither before, this step was the most challenging I think. After a while I finally got the techniue down, and we moved on to doing figure eights. These went pretty well, and got a couple more advnaced techniques taught since I was progressing so well throughout the morning. After a while we decided to break for lunch, then afterwards it would be time to hitup the Drift Land Course. We went up to this resterraunt that was located at the top of the circuit. The inside was really nice, and they had all different kinds of food, ice cream, and other misc things in there. I ordered up some Miso Chyashu(pork) Ramen. It was very, VERY good, and the best ramen i've ever had. However, I could barely eat any of it sadly :( This was because I get motion sickness pretty easy. Read books in the car, riding on planes, and yes...drifting. When I'm driving its not quite as bad as when I ride shotgun, but after about 4 hours of driving it was starting to take its toll.   After barely touching my lunch, we went down to the PowerVehicles.com shop/area to see all the cool drift missiles and cars that were sitting around. I don't have any pics of my driving the Drift Land Course, but there's video footage at the bottom of the post. However, I did manage to get some tandem action in with Suenaga-san himself! lol Once we wrapped up for the day, Suenaga-san gave me a t-shirt as a gift, as well as a ride-along in his personal S14 on the Touge Course. All I have to say, is damn.....there's a reason why this guy is a pro. The things had does while in that car is unbelievable. Big thanks and shout out to Suenaga-san, and the rest of Team Orange as well as Andy and Emily from Powervehicles.com! Both of them made this a great experience and if you have a little bit of extra money, I highly reccomend going out to do this! It costed me aout $1,000USD and that covered the car, and full tank of gas, and a set of spare tires(that I never used due to the rain). We stopped along the way back to Gunma to get some gas at Eneos! while getting gas we ran into this awesome Datsun Bluebird. Sadly, the owner was nowhere to be found. :( Last stop for the day was at the Super Autobacs store in Maebashi. On the way into the parking lot, we spotted this S15 tucked away on the side. I'm not sure what's up with people and those ugly chrome tails though. >_< This autobacs had some cool stuff, including a bunch of Drift Tengoku and SuperGT DVD's. They also had all other kinds of goodies there. There's more pics of stuff in the gallery below. ^_^ This is the price you pay for drifting 4 hours straight, before finally remembering you brought gloves...T_T After a long, tiring and painful day of drifting I was ready to get some sleep, and rest. I was already pretty sore from driving all day. The next day is going to involve packing up to head back to Tokyo, and sifting through all the footage/pics I took. lol Here's some video footage of the Drift School! http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL44636DDBC5A4B411   [gallery link="file" columns="4" orderby="post_date"]

posts.title: Japan Trip: Day 4 (Media editing and downtime)
posts.markdown: Day 4 was pretty uneventfull,and started by waking up, and being super sore from doing the Drift School the day before. I then packed up and took the train back to Tokyo. After getting back back to Tokyo, I decided to grab some lunch from 7-11, then start sifting though my massive media pile from the past 2 days. haha The chicken sandwich on the right was great! I wish we had it in the US :( These are all the goodies and stuff I got while in Gunma and Ebisu Circuit. Many thanks to Eichi for giving me some awesome stuff, showing me aroung Gunma, driving all the way up to fukushima, and letting me stay at his place for a few nights! ^_^ Tomorrow I plan to meetup with my friend Ken and have Yakiniku, play some video games, and go hitup the park for some skateboarding and football.

posts.title: Yuki: Updates Fall 2011
posts.markdown:
Hey everyone, just figured I post up some updates that have gone on with yuki over the past coupe months

First off I got the Transmission rebuilt since it was grinding and making all kinds of trouble trying to start in first gear. Turns out the crank pilot bushing was an auto one still and pretty beat up. lol I also went with a new slave cylinder, pivot bushing, throwout bearing ontop of a shiny B&M shifter,HKS shift return springs, and a tomei shift knob. Overall the newly rebuilt tranny feels AMAZING. Sadly, I didn’t do any of the work for it myself. The guys over at Z Sport in Everett,WA did it for me.

One of the things that really impressed me with Z Sport was the fact that the owner sent me a hand written card thanking me for bringing the car in, and some things he really liked about my car. Ontop of that, they showed me some of the best customer service I’ve seen yet from a shop. So, I’ll definitely be going to them for things I need in the future! Here’s a quick pic of the Thank You card they sent me.

I’m pretty happy with the results so far, the shifter feels very smooth and the throw is super short and precise. Initially the HKS shift spring I used was the “Soft” version which is 150% harder than stock, so it took some getting used to but after a week or so it feels great! The “Hard” ones that were included were 300% stiffer over stock. I’ve installed the Hard ones before in a friends car and it was just miserable to try and shift with it. haha Well, enough of my babbling. Here’s some shtuff!


B&M Awesomeness!^_^

This is the Ver.2 model that has a bit less chattering as the older one.

Fancy HKS shift springs

frsport.com was liquidating a bunch of their tomei products a while back, so I jumped on the deals and got this Tomei Duracon knob for 28 bucks shipped!!

Another thing I recently got was this Scroth Ralleye 4 harness. I got this specific model for 2 reasons. One being that is the ONLY harness on the market that’s DOT approved and legal. The second reason I got this harness was because unlike others, this one can be mounted to the rear seat belt points. Usually, if you mount them there, its beyond a 45 degree angle and can lead to nasty things like spinal compression in the event of an accident.

I’ll be sure to get some more pics of them actually installed along with my shift knob. I’ve just been lazy. hehe

 

Here’s a circuit sports coolant reservoir I got recently as well. lol

Last but not least, the MOST IMPORTANT upgrade of them all is the Yuki sweatband!! haha
posts.html:
Hey everyone, just figured I post up some updates that have gone on with yuki over the past coupe months

First off I got the Transmission rebuilt since it was grinding and making all kinds of trouble trying to start in first gear. Turns out the crank pilot bushing was an auto one still and pretty beat up. lol I also went with a new slave cylinder, pivot bushing, throwout bearing ontop of a shiny B&M shifter,HKS shift return springs, and a tomei shift knob. Overall the newly rebuilt tranny feels AMAZING. Sadly, I didn’t do any of the work for it myself. The guys over at Z Sport in Everett,WA did it for me.

One of the things that really impressed me with Z Sport was the fact that the owner sent me a hand written card thanking me for bringing the car in, and some things he really liked about my car. Ontop of that, they showed me some of the best customer service I’ve seen yet from a shop. So, I’ll definitely be going to them for things I need in the future! Here’s a quick pic of the Thank You card they sent me.

I’m pretty happy with the results so far, the shifter feels very smooth and the throw is super short and precise. Initially the HKS shift spring I used was the “Soft” version which is 150% harder than stock, so it took some getting used to but after a week or so it feels great! The “Hard” ones that were included were 300% stiffer over stock. I’ve installed the Hard ones before in a friends car and it was just miserable to try and shift with it. haha Well, enough of my babbling. Here’s some shtuff!


B&M Awesomeness!^_^

This is the Ver.2 model that has a bit less chattering as the older one.

Fancy HKS shift springs

frsport.com was liquidating a bunch of their tomei products a while back, so I jumped on the deals and got this Tomei Duracon knob for 28 bucks shipped!!

Another thing I recently got was this Scroth Ralleye 4 harness. I got this specific model for 2 reasons. One being that is the ONLY harness on the market that’s DOT approved and legal. The second reason I got this harness was because unlike others, this one can be mounted to the rear seat belt points. Usually, if you mount them there, its beyond a 45 degree angle and can lead to nasty things like spinal compression in the event of an accident.

I’ll be sure to get some more pics of them actually installed along with my shift knob. I’ve just been lazy. hehe

 

Here’s a circuit sports coolant reservoir I got recently as well. lol

Last but not least, the MOST IMPORTANT upgrade of them all is the Yuki sweatband!! haha

posts.title: Japan Trip: Day 6 (Tonchan and Shinjuku)
posts.markdown: so, today I was feeling a bit lazy, and didn't feel like venture out anywhere really. So, I mostly stayed inside during the day. lol I did go out a bit later in the afternoon though, so you can see that after the jump. So, yesterday when I went to 7-11 for breakfast, I Accidentally stumbled on these french toast slices. I tried one, and they were so good I had to have them again this morning for breakfast. :p Anyways, aside from that I didn't really do much today. I got caught up in all my anime, and was just on the computer for most of the day, until later in the afternoon. Here's I'm waiting on my ex co-worker Brian to show up at Shinjuku Station. I think the train ride over there, was the most packed its ever been since me being here. You literally couldn't move anywhere. lol We ended up going to this BBQ pork place called Tonchan and  met up with Matsumoto-san who was another co-worker. Apparently though, this place is pretty famous. we started off with these slices of pork, that is almost like a really thick bacon, but not as salty. Then, we moved on to some fried rice which was really good. It was korea style, and I forgot the name.>_< Brian (left) and Matsumoto-san(right) On the way back to the station, I saw this lantern and really wanted to take a picture for some reason. lol Lightly tuned Toyota MR-S was spotted! It's so wierd seing these giant TV's onj the side of buildings n stuff. lol it's such a huge difference here in japan between the city in Tokyo, and out in the country in Gunma. space invaders anyone? Anyways, that's about it. Tomorrow I'm gonna go to Asakusa with Matsumoto-san, and whatever else we can think of at the time I guess. lol [gallery link="file" columns="4" orderby="post_date"]

posts.title: Japan Trip: Day 7 (Omori Nismo Factory, Skytree, Asakusa, Akihabara, Tokyo Dome)
posts.markdown: day 7 of the trip was probably the most tiring since it involved walking around literally the entire day! more stuff after the jump. Matsumoto-san was kind enough to take me around Tokyo to check out some stuff for the day since it was a Saturday and he had the day off. I met him outside me hotel and we headed over to Omori to go check out the Nismo Factory. We thought it opened at 11am, and had some time to kill so he showed me a few cool places since he lives in this area. First of which is the Isuzu building, which had a flea market/swap meet going on outside. This place was HUUUGE! Afterwards, we went to this huuge grocery store area called Ito Yokado. Outside I spotted a few cool looking bikes. This Suzuki was one of them. This old school honda was probably my favorite bike i've seen thus far. Inside there was some awesome looking food, and some weird stuff like this Fish head. lol Along the way I saw this cool Lexus Celsior First stop of the day was the Nismo Factory Shop in Omori The first thing I noticed when entering was this SuperGT 350Z chilling off in the corner. After getting distracted, they have little lounge area with some awards on the back wall, and a crank, some rods and pistons encased there in plexiglass. The wing on this car was HUUGE! Here you can see a better shot of just how much wider they made the car as well The cockpit of this car had soo many switches and buttons I would get hella confused trying to drive this and focus on everything else. lol Naturally, a car of this caliber had a full Carbon underpanel for downforce purposes One thing I thought was really cool is the way the center nut on these wheels is designed. Trying to get creative with my photos. haha They also had this cool timeline of achievements along the wall next tothe 350Z Here's a quick shot of when the Omori factory first opened! A quick glimpse into the store-front of the shop. Yeah, you know just some titanium exhaust, ohlins coilovers, and $2,000 Big brake kits all sitting under a hella expensive Snap-on Toolbox. No big deal. The welds on this exhaust were really cool looking Over to the left there was some Track cars being worked on, some racing DVD's and.... These custom Nismo build RB26DETT's... Also, this VQ37 which I know someone who would want it very badly in their S-chassis ;) a quick shot of some R35's and 370z's being worked on Last here's a picture of some posters, and goodies you can buy here in the corner. Next it was over to Ueno to the Flea masket area called Ameyoko(アメ横） to grab some lunch. The place we went to was a sushi place, but I forget the name. :p Outside there were some strays waiting for food too. haha Inside of the place was pretty small, but smelled really good. Sushi for lunch, which all came to around $10 bucks, and left me pretty full for the most part. The far left one was actually Sea Urchin, and tasted really good! The stuff on the far right is egg FYI. This clean NSX was spotted on our way going to the Skytree. The giant golden thingy is a flame and apparently used to stand straight up, but cops thought it looked too much like poo, so they asked the owners of the building to turn it on its side. Once we got to the sky tree area they had this cool little Studio Ghibli shop. Skytree! it's about 2,080 feet tall. I also felt the need to take a picture of this guys' awesome photographers pose while trying to take a picture of the skytree. These water bottles are pretty cool. they're recyclable, and are able to shrink down by crumpling it. Next stop after the skytree was asakusa. This temple apparently was build around 650ad oh yeah, newsflash, there's a crap ton of people in tokyo! Next stop after Asakusa was Akihabara. I'll be going there again later in the week, so more pictures will come then as well. This place has a Cafe and gift shop for an all girl pop group called AKB48. Next to the ABK48 cafe/shop was the Gundam Cafe! This rx-8 was chillin outside, and had a nice sounding exhaust note. Outside there was this mini-statue that said "please don't touch", but these guys thought it'd be funny to mess with the gundam to make him give everyone the finger. haha here's a quick shot of the inside. As well as some lady stuffing her face. lol They had this really cool feature going the whole time on the tv there. Next stop in Akihabara was the UDX parking lot to search for some itasha! At first I was a bit discouraged, since there were no itasha and the first parking level, but there was this nicely tuned rx-7. Finally we found some itsha! This one is a Nissan S15 and was running stock boost, with a Trust turbo. I forget the specific model, but it was still a bottom mount though. lol I forget this guys' name. But, after talking with him about his s15, and showing him my S13 I realized something. In the US, if you take pics of somebody's car, and try to go talk to them, Half the time, the owner won't be very friendly, and start mean mugging you. However, in japan, people are very nice and don't mind talking about stuff. Ran into another Nissan Itasha. This one is a Kouki S14, but the owner was nowhere to be found. Up on the surface, This Toyota Chaser was spotted! Of course what akihabara trip would be complete without meido! ^_^ I'll be going back here again to find a tsundere maid cafe, so I'll have more pics in a few days. For now, check the gallery for others. On the way back to the station, I ran into another rx-8. After Akiba, Matsumoto-san took me to this place that had Tsukemen Ramen. This is just like normal ramen, except the noodles are seperate. So, you don't run into the problem of soggy noodles towards the end! ^_^ I got the extra noodle size and it consisted of 1lb of ramen goodness! haha Last stop for the day was the Tokyo Dome, which is home to the Yomiuri Giants baseball team located in Tokyo. This roller coaster I thought was pretty inense since it actually went through the ferris wheel. lol   Day 8 I ended up taking a trek with my buddy Derek out to the Mt.Fuji area, and also managed to check out Daikokufuto on the way back into tokyo. So, look forward to that sometime tomorrow morning hopefully.^_^ haha [gallery link="file" columns="4" orderby="post_date"]
