posts.title: Japan Trip: Day 8 (370z Touge, Fuji Speedway, Karting, Fuji-Q Highland, Daikokufuto)
posts.markdown: So, for day 8 my friend Derek from Pacific Coast Auto Imports was nice enough to rent a 370Z for us to take out to the Mt.Fuji area and do some exploring/touge runs! Those of you looking to import cars from Japan go over to the site, and shoot him an e-mail! ^_^ The day started off with meetup up with Derek and his family over at Yokohama station, then picking up the NIssan 370Z rental car. Sadly, the rental place had disabled the switches to turn off annoying driver aids like TCS(traction control). So, it was a bit hard to have dori action or do doughnuts with it, but still a very fun car overall. :p One thing that really tripped me out while driving is these style traffic lights. This one basically means you can turn left, and go straight, but not turn right. the light will change to yellow, then go back to red, and a green right arrow will appear. On our way to Fuji we ran into this Chevy shop called Marcelo in Yokohama. This corvette had some aweosome pearl flakes in it! Derek tryin to act like a baws with some glasses he found under the hood of this camaro. This was on a sunday, so the shop was all closed up. lol Lastly there was an awesome Dodge Challenger R/T sitting there with a nice purple paint job. As we were heading to the freeway, we spotted this slammed VIP Honda Odyssey. After driving about an hour, and completely missing our exit, we decided to make a quick stop in this PA. Luckily we did, because an older guy pulled up in his brand new Subaru BRZ! We finally arrived at Fuji and decided to grab some lunch at this supermarket before hitting the touge. After we came out, there was this clean Celica sitting next to us with Speedline wheels, and some wierd clear gascap thingy. lol Lunch for the day consisted of Pizza with corn on it, which actually wasn't too bad! After breaking for lunch, we ran into yet another surprise. This tiny little drift shop called Auto Garage Replica. At the time, these guys were working on this S15, and the rx-7 there in the background. This NSX Type-R was tucked away in the corner. I wanted it SOOO BAD! This tuned kei car seemed a bit out of place here at this drift shop. I Believe it was a Nissan March. This March was no joke either, it was a fully gutted racecar. Why? well..because RACECAR of course. Time do DO WORK on Ashigara Pass! The road start off super narrow. so ontop of adjusting driving RHD and this being a bigger car than what i'm used to, it was a bit difficult to go balls to the wall knowing there's bikers n whatnot around. Some evidence of late night drift action! I managed to take home a piece of tailight that somebody left behind from trying to get a super entry drift, and losing a fight with the gaurdrail. haha naturally there were pieces of rubber, and chunks lining the outside of the road here. lol The view of Mt. Fuji here was really cool. It was a bit sad, that because of the humidity, you couldn't see everything as clear as it would be back in Washington State. Once we got to the top, we ran into this guy who was cruising on a little Honda Baja 50cc bike. Uphill he said its a nightmare, but downhill is lots of fun. Turns out this guy is a Prototype Engineer at Nissan. We tried to get him to spill the beans on the S16 Silvia, but all he could say is "maybe" with a wry smile. So, something tells me that there's one coming ;) I Believe his name was Hanataro, but i could be wrong. Its hard to remember names for me for some reason. lol After some Touge we originally, had planned to go to Fuji-Q Highland to check out the Evangelion World exhibit. However, we ran into this awesome kart track called APG(Auto Paradise Gotenba) on the way there, and decided to stop and take a quick peek. It looked like we had just came in while they had a qualifying session underway. Most of the kids driving seemed to be from ages 7-12 or so. even though these kids were young, they were hauling around this track. These kids had some really nice lines, and a couple really good passes in the braking zones like pictured above. We noticed this stack of rental cars chilling in one of the bays. So, we went down to ask the manager if it was possible to rent them. Turns out it was, but only from 4:30-5:30 that day. It was roughly 3pm when we check the time. We then asked him "how long does it take to get to Fuji-Q Highland?". His response was about 45 minutes. Then, we asked "well, what about fuji speedway?". This answer of 15 minutes we liked a bit more. There was a ton of traffic during the day however, so we weren't quite sure of 15 minutes was accurate. The manager (who's name escapes me) was nice enough to draw us a map of a shortcut on how to get to fuji. APG is where we were at, and the circled blip at the top is fuji speedway. oh, and the swastica symbol in japan is actually used to Temples. We decided to pull into the entrance to the template for a couple quick photo's. We didn't go all the way inside, but from the super long entrance road, it probably was pretty big. Fuji Speedway! According to Derek, you normally have to pay an entrance fee at the gate just to get in. However, this was a Sunday and for some reason, nobody was at the gate. So, we were able to drive right in, and head up to the grandstands without anybody saying anything. lol This is one of the cool things I like when compared to US tracks. Ones here, are just open for anybody that want to use them, even worldwide known ones like Fuji Speedway. There a surprise about this Levin a bit later in the post....^_^ Some guys working on a Ferrari racecar checking tire pressure or temp I assume. Here there's a NSX making mince-meat out of a nissan kei car,and hunting down what looks to be a Porsche 911. nice rear end shot of that Ferrari. It was moving pretty quick down that front straight compared to other cars. haha We left the grandstand to see if we would be able to get into the pit area. along the way back to the car we saw this beetle filled with Mamashiba! Also along the way we found this poor Toyota Supra that apparently met its demise with one of the track walls :( Upon entering the pit area with no resistance, we found this super rare Austin Martin 777 getting gas from a wacky Eneos employee. haha a quick overview heading into the main paddock area This super sexy Ferrari Enzo was spotted and the guy looked to be packing up to leave already. I'm not sure what cars these were, but they looked awesome! so if somebody could fill me in somewhere in the comments section, it would be appreciated! ^_^ Here's a cool shot of a Kouki S14, having to get the front dumper, and splitter removed in order to get it onto the truck. Also, here in the corner is that red Levin I mentioned earlier. Let's go over and talk to him! Here's a quick interior shot of the car. It's pretty standard, but still clean at the same time. This car sees double duty as a drift car, and a grip car. The owner of this little Levin(nicknamed Anna) is Miura-san of Garage Miura from down in Shizuoka. Why is this guy so cool might you ask? It's just an ordinary levin with a standard 4age right? well.... We asked if it was possible to get a ride along in his car, but he replied saying that the track time for his session is already over. But, he said we can go around on the outskirts of the track and have a bit of fun. I  was already super pumped about being able to ride in it, when he said "do you wanna drive?" I was completely dumbfounded that he would let some random foreigner from Seattle drive his car. After babying it around a few corners, he said "you can revv it up to 8k rpms". so, on one of the straights, I Really got on it, and man this car sounded amazing! It had dual 40mm carbs on it, so the response was great! Me trying to explain that 86's in the US are expensive as hell, and Miura-san responding with "oh, I only paid $300 for mine stock." I wish deals were like that in the US. haha A quick picture with Miura-san again before heading back out to the Karting track! Those interesting in seeing more about his car you can view his Minkara page in the link below! http://minkara.carview.co.jp/userid/764570/profile/ Derek's all fired up! I'm....stil trying to figure out what's going on... oh right! helmet on, okay now I got it. ^_^ My time was a :59.792 and the record for that day was 58.366. So, I think if I had a bit more experience with this track I might be able to shave another second off. One thing that was fun, is these were the fastest karts i've driven yet, so flying into the first corner was a ton of fun. lol Also, I believe the manager's name is written there to the left. so, if anyone could translate that kanji for me it'd be appreciated! ^_^ It's worth noting some of those custom karts from earler were getting times in the 44 second range. lol quick photo before we leave of Derek, the manager, and myself. He was really nice, and when I asked him about my lap times he said, they were okay. haha personally I thought they were pretty damn good for being in a rental, and never driven the course before. I actually ended up lapping Derek, although he spun on the corner as I was coming up to challenge him. maybe next time we'll be able to have more of a battle! haha ;) Next stop for the day was Fuji-Q Highland! there was one problem though, apparently the park seemed to be closed. The entrance was wide open though, so we walked in to take a look and try to find Evangelion World. Along the way we found this cool Hamtaro boat ride. lol We finally made it to our destination! but, as we feared it was already closed! :( my buddy mike was really looking forward to pics from this, so I felt kinda bad. But, I made it up to him by getting some awesome stuff the following day at the Toyota History Garage. So, look for that a bit later. ;) After some walking around to check out other closed down attractions, we headed back to the exit. Except there was one problem....we somehow got locked in! 0_o So, we had to resort to using our old school playground skills to escape. haha here you can see our lone 370Z chillin in the parking lot. We were pretty much done in the Fuji area, and proceeded to go find some food, before going back to the Yokohama area for one last stop. We decided to hitup this mcdonalds by the freeway and surprisingly, after about 8 days in japan, this was my first time finally going there. lol I ended up ordering Large size for everything, since it seems mcdonalds in Japan is basically a step down from what we have in the US. lol When we were leaving to go back to Yokohama this Subaru Rally car was chillin outside. Its funny how often you run into awesome cars over here compared to in the US.   Our final stop for the day was the legendary Daikokufuto PA just across the Rainbow Bay Bridge. While I didn't get any pics of the bridge, Derek got some video footage of my driving over it, so I'll upload that and link to it here in a bit. Just look for the video link at the bottom of the post! As as were walking around this super loud Wangan tunes 86 showed up. You can tell he's serious by all the crazy functional aero stuff he has done to the car. especially the splitters on the top of the door. lol Here you can see more crazy aero with his front canards, and splitter. All these parts are one-off, and he showed us some video on his phone of him driving the C1 Loop. All I can say, is this dude has balls of steel! Driving this car at 200km/h+ would scare the crap out of me. lol The next car we ran into was this super clean Hakousuka Skyline! We went and talked to the owner, and asked him to open the hood to see what was inside, since it didn't sound quite right. To our surprise it had a L28 from the Datsun/Nissan 240z, except this specific one had been over bored to make it an L30 which 3 Litres of awesome-ness! Here we were talking to the owner of this nice looking Toyota Altezza who says he's making about 450hp on 1.4 bar of boost which is about 20psi or so. Here's a better close-up of the Beams 3SGTE motor running a Trust turbo, but I forget which specific model. lol I never noticed how cool the tach on these altezzas looked. I'm not sure of this one, is specific only to japan, but I really liked how the overall speed was in the center, with smaller gauges inside, and rpm off to the side there. Since it was already a bit late, and all the trains stopped running at midnight, we had to book it out of there, to make my trains in Yokohama. I wanna give a huge thanks to Derek for showing me around all over the place, and renting the 370Z for the day! I've got video from this day, so I'll sort through it and get it uploaded a it later. so sit tight for now on that. :p [gallery link="file" columns="4" orderby="post_date"]
posts.html:
So, for day 8 my friend Derek from Pacific Coast Auto Imports was nice enough to rent a 370Z for us to take out to the Mt.Fuji area and do some exploring/touge runs! Those of you looking to import cars from Japan go over to the site, and shoot him an e-mail! ^_^

The day started off with meetup up with Derek and his family over at Yokohama station, then picking up the NIssan 370Z rental car. Sadly, the rental place had disabled the switches to turn off annoying driver aids like TCS(traction control). So, it was a bit hard to have dori action or do doughnuts with it, but still a very fun car overall. :p

One thing that really tripped me out while driving is these style traffic lights. This one basically means you can turn left, and go straight, but not turn right. the light will change to yellow, then go back to red, and a green right arrow will appear.

On our way to Fuji we ran into this Chevy shop called Marcelo in Yokohama.

This corvette had some aweosome pearl flakes in it!

Derek tryin to act like a baws with some glasses he found under the hood of this camaro. This was on a sunday, so the shop was all closed up. lol

Lastly there was an awesome Dodge Challenger R/T sitting there with a nice purple paint job.

As we were heading to the freeway, we spotted this slammed VIP Honda Odyssey.

After driving about an hour, and completely missing our exit, we decided to make a quick stop in this PA. Luckily we did, because an older guy pulled up in his brand new Subaru BRZ!

We finally arrived at Fuji and decided to grab some lunch at this supermarket before hitting the touge. After we came out, there was this clean Celica sitting next to us with Speedline wheels, and some wierd clear gascap thingy. lol

Lunch for the day consisted of Pizza with corn on it, which actually wasn't too bad!

After breaking for lunch, we ran into yet another surprise. This tiny little drift shop called Auto Garage Replica.

At the time, these guys were working on this S15, and the rx-7 there in the background.

This NSX Type-R was tucked away in the corner. I wanted it SOOO BAD!

This tuned kei car seemed a bit out of place here at this drift shop. I Believe it was a Nissan March.

This March was no joke either, it was a fully gutted racecar. Why? well..because RACECAR of course.

Time do DO WORK on Ashigara Pass!

The road start off super narrow. so ontop of adjusting driving RHD and this being a bigger car than what i'm used to, it was a bit difficult to go balls to the wall knowing there's bikers n whatnot around.

Some evidence of late night drift action!

I managed to take home a piece of tailight that somebody left behind from trying to get a super entry drift, and losing a fight with the gaurdrail. haha

naturally there were pieces of rubber, and chunks lining the outside of the road here. lol

The view of Mt. Fuji here was really cool. It was a bit sad, that because of the humidity, you couldn't see everything as clear as it would be back in Washington State.

Once we got to the top, we ran into this guy who was cruising on a little Honda Baja 50cc bike. Uphill he said its a nightmare, but downhill is lots of fun. Turns out this guy is a Prototype Engineer at Nissan. We tried to get him to spill the beans on the S16 Silvia, but all he could say is "maybe" with a wry smile. So, something tells me that there's one coming ;) I Believe his name was Hanataro, but i could be wrong. Its hard to remember names for me for some reason. lol

After some Touge we originally, had planned to go to Fuji-Q Highland to check out the Evangelion World exhibit. However, we ran into this awesome kart track called APG(Auto Paradise Gotenba) on the way there, and decided to stop and take a quick peek.

It looked like we had just came in while they had a qualifying session underway. Most of the kids driving seemed to be from ages 7-12 or so.

even though these kids were young, they were hauling around this track.

These kids had some really nice lines, and a couple really good passes in the braking zones like pictured above.

We noticed this stack of rental cars chilling in one of the bays. So, we went down to ask the manager if it was possible to rent them. Turns out it was, but only from 4:30-5:30 that day. It was roughly 3pm when we check the time. We then asked him "how long does it take to get to Fuji-Q Highland?". His response was about 45 minutes. Then, we asked "well, what about fuji speedway?". This answer of 15 minutes we liked a bit more. There was a ton of traffic during the day however, so we weren't quite sure of 15 minutes was accurate.

The manager (who's name escapes me) was nice enough to draw us a map of a shortcut on how to get to fuji. APG is where we were at, and the circled blip at the top is fuji speedway. oh, and the swastica symbol in japan is actually used to Temples.

We decided to pull into the entrance to the template for a couple quick photo's. We didn't go all the way inside, but from the super long entrance road, it probably was pretty big.

Fuji Speedway!

According to Derek, you normally have to pay an entrance fee at the gate just to get in. However, this was a Sunday and for some reason, nobody was at the gate. So, we were able to drive right in, and head up to the grandstands without anybody saying anything. lol This is one of the cool things I like when compared to US tracks. Ones here, are just open for anybody that want to use them, even worldwide known ones like Fuji Speedway.

There a surprise about this Levin a bit later in the post....^_^

Some guys working on a Ferrari racecar checking tire pressure or temp I assume.

Here there's a NSX making mince-meat out of a nissan kei car,and hunting down what looks to be a Porsche 911.

nice rear end shot of that Ferrari. It was moving pretty quick down that front straight compared to other cars. haha

We left the grandstand to see if we would be able to get into the pit area. along the way back to the car we saw this beetle filled with Mamashiba!

Also along the way we found this poor Toyota Supra that apparently met its demise with one of the track walls :(

Upon entering the pit area with no resistance, we found this super rare Austin Martin 777 getting gas from a wacky Eneos employee. haha

a quick overview heading into the main paddock area

This super sexy Ferrari Enzo was spotted and the guy looked to be packing up to leave already.

I'm not sure what cars these were, but they looked awesome! so if somebody could fill me in somewhere in the comments section, it would be appreciated! ^_^

Here's a cool shot of a Kouki S14, having to get the front dumper, and splitter removed in order to get it onto the truck. Also, here in the corner is that red Levin I mentioned earlier. Let's go over and talk to him!

Here's a quick interior shot of the car. It's pretty standard, but still clean at the same time. This car sees double duty as a drift car, and a grip car.

The owner of this little Levin(nicknamed Anna) is Miura-san of Garage Miura from down in Shizuoka. Why is this guy so cool might you ask? It's just an ordinary levin with a standard 4age right? well....

We asked if it was possible to get a ride along in his car, but he replied saying that the track time for his session is already over. But, he said we can go around on the outskirts of the track and have a bit of fun. I  was already super pumped about being able to ride in it, when he said "do you wanna drive?" I was completely dumbfounded that he would let some random foreigner from Seattle drive his car. After babying it around a few corners, he said "you can revv it up to 8k rpms". so, on one of the straights, I Really got on it, and man this car sounded amazing! It had dual 40mm carbs on it, so the response was great!

Me trying to explain that 86's in the US are expensive as hell, and Miura-san responding with "oh, I only paid $300 for mine stock." I wish deals were like that in the US. haha

A quick picture with Miura-san again before heading back out to the Karting track! Those interesting in seeing more about his car you can view his Minkara page in the link below!

http://minkara.carview.co.jp/userid/764570/profile/

Derek's all fired up!

I'm....stil trying to figure out what's going on...

oh right! helmet on, okay now I got it. ^_^

My time was a :59.792 and the record for that day was 58.366. So, I think if I had a bit more experience with this track I might be able to shave another second off. One thing that was fun, is these were the fastest karts i've driven yet, so flying into the first corner was a ton of fun. lol Also, I believe the manager's name is written there to the left. so, if anyone could translate that kanji for me it'd be appreciated! ^_^ It's worth noting some of those custom karts from earler were getting times in the 44 second range. lol

quick photo before we leave of Derek, the manager, and myself. He was really nice, and when I asked him about my lap times he said, they were okay. haha personally I thought they were pretty damn good for being in a rental, and never driven the course before. I actually ended up lapping Derek, although he spun on the corner as I was coming up to challenge him. maybe next time we'll be able to have more of a battle! haha ;)

Next stop for the day was Fuji-Q Highland! there was one problem though, apparently the park seemed to be closed. The entrance was wide open though, so we walked in to take a look and try to find Evangelion World.

Along the way we found this cool Hamtaro boat ride. lol

We finally made it to our destination! but, as we feared it was already closed! :( my buddy mike was really looking forward to pics from this, so I felt kinda bad. But, I made it up to him by getting some awesome stuff the following day at the Toyota History Garage. So, look for that a bit later. ;)

After some walking around to check out other closed down attractions, we headed back to the exit. Except there was one problem....we somehow got locked in! 0_o

So, we had to resort to using our old school playground skills to escape. haha

here you can see our lone 370Z chillin in the parking lot. We were pretty much done in the Fuji area, and proceeded to go find some food, before going back to the Yokohama area for one last stop.

We decided to hitup this mcdonalds by the freeway and surprisingly, after about 8 days in japan, this was my first time finally going there. lol

I ended up ordering Large size for everything, since it seems mcdonalds in Japan is basically a step down from what we have in the US. lol

When we were leaving to go back to Yokohama this Subaru Rally car was chillin outside. Its funny how often you run into awesome cars over here compared to in the US.

 

Our final stop for the day was the legendary Daikokufuto PA just across the Rainbow Bay Bridge. While I didn't get any pics of the bridge, Derek got some video footage of my driving over it, so I'll upload that and link to it here in a bit. Just look for the video link at the bottom of the post!

As as were walking around this super loud Wangan tunes 86 showed up. You can tell he's serious by all the crazy functional aero stuff he has done to the car. especially the splitters on the top of the door. lol

Here you can see more crazy aero with his front canards, and splitter. All these parts are one-off, and he showed us some video on his phone of him driving the C1 Loop. All I can say, is this dude has balls of steel! Driving this car at 200km/h+ would scare the crap out of me. lol

The next car we ran into was this super clean Hakousuka Skyline! We went and talked to the owner, and asked him to open the hood to see what was inside, since it didn't sound quite right.

To our surprise it had a L28 from the Datsun/Nissan 240z, except this specific one had been over bored to make it an L30 which 3 Litres of awesome-ness!

Here we were talking to the owner of this nice looking Toyota Altezza who says he's making about 450hp on 1.4 bar of boost which is about 20psi or so.

Here's a better close-up of the Beams 3SGTE motor running a Trust turbo, but I forget which specific model. lol

I never noticed how cool the tach on these altezzas looked. I'm not sure of this one, is specific only to japan, but I really liked how the overall speed was in the center, with smaller gauges inside, and rpm off to the side there.

Since it was already a bit late, and all the trains stopped running at midnight, we had to book it out of there, to make my trains in Yokohama. I wanna give a huge thanks to Derek for showing me around all over the place, and renting the 370Z for the day!

I've got video from this day, so I'll sort through it and get it uploaded a it later. so sit tight for now on that. :p

posts.title: Japan Trip: Day 9 (Giant Gundam, Toyota MegaWeb and more Akihabara)
posts.markdown: Day 9 of my trip was mostly spend hanging out with my buddy Darrick around the Odaiba area and going to Akihabara as well. First step of the day involved heading over to Haneda Airport to pickup my buddy Darrick. Afterwards, we took the new Yurikamome across the rainbow bay bridge over to Odaiba.   After getting off at the right station, we decided to hunt around Aqua City for the mcdonalds and grab some lunch. The bigger building with the ball on it, is actually the main HQ for Fuji TV. We got a bit distracted and somehow ended up Tebowing infront of the statue of liberty.haha I found this familiar shop called Daiso, which they have in Seattle. However, this one was HUGE compared to the previous ones ive seen. We finally made it to mcdonalds to grab some food, and were joined by this little guy. ^_^ We decided to headout after lunch to try and find the giant gundam. Along the way, this clean caged porsche was spotted. Also this wagon sporting some TE37's.   Finally found him! the thing was massive!   We managed to get lucky and catch the Gundam just as the whole light/smoke show was starting. We were a bit dissappointed to find out that, it only did those things, plus the head moved. We had thought the arms n stuff moved as well. oh well... EDIT: Totally forgot to include this photo of my Tebow'ing infornt of the gundam! haha I decided to go checkout the Gundam Cafe here in Odaiba to see what was different from the one in Akihabara. Luckily I did, because they had this little combo snack, plus a limited edition Gundam head which I ended up getting. ^_^ After the gundam stuff, we headed down the road to another attraction called Palette town. Which, due to the nice rainbow colored sign, looks very warm and welcoming......right? We finally had found the Toyota History Garage over at the MegaWeb area. They had some really old school iconic cars lined up here! For example, this 1974 TA27 Toyota Celica. or this 1967 Toyota Celica 2000GT! The next room was a long hallway of display cases, with Toy models, magazines, and other misc stuff to buy. Here's a really cool RS Turbo R31 Skyline we spotted for 19,900Yen(roughly $200) Check out that awesome F1 Steering wheel/Clock! Here's a little Ayrton Senna model that was sitting on the counter as I was checking out to buy a few things. They even had a cool Delorean like from Back to the Future! hmmm a Gran Prix Garage? let's see whats down here... Going down the stairs there was this really cool Castrol Toyota Celica GT-FOUR painting. Well, I wasn't dissappointed. Sitting here was a Formula 1 car driven by Alan Mcnish, that look really smaller than I thought it would in person. But, it was something really awesome to see. They had this really cool overhead video, complete with real time telemetry on the laptop, and info there on the steering wheel. I took video of this for a bit, so check the link at the bottom of the post. :p     Next up was this completely MINT showroom Toyota Corolla Levin from 1983. words cannot begin to describe how cool of an experience this was. I really wanted to see what it looked like inside the engine bay though. >_< I couldn't get over how cleanthis thing was. lol This version was also a GTV which is the highest model you could get. Moving onto the outside stuff, this poor Castrol Toyota Celica GT-FOUR longs for the day it can drive in a rally stage again. Even though the car was a bit battered, and rusted, it seemed to be in pretty good shape for the most part. 'gotta love the engrish on the intake piping cover! haha Also outside was this cool looking 24hour LeMans car. Back upstairs they had this SuperGT Toyota Supra and Red Bull F1 car from 2005. Back in the other building by the Toyota City Showcase, they had test drives setup along this small course. We asked about testing the new 86, but it would involve waiting a solid 3-4 hours. So, we decided to go play with the display models instead. lol The red one on the left was Automatic, and the Silver one to the right was Manual. SMH, Epic Fail Toyota... you just had to put the stupid boxer motor in it....*sigh* This picture is misleading. While I was giving a thumbs up, I should've been giving thumbs down. While this interior does look much better than the stupid crap we're getting from the Scion FT-86. It still kinda fails with the steering wheel felling like a musting, and almost everything being covered in suede. Overall I just think that Toyota didn't listen to the right people when they were working on building this car..>_< They also had this cool GT5 simulator setup for people to try. back in another store they had some cool F1 helmets worn by Jean Alesi Also this Personal steering wheel signed by Michael Schumacher. a quick overview shot of the second building which was called Toyota MegaWeb. Next stop for the day was the giant Super Autobacs store in Shinonome. notice the Toyota Chaser there in the corner? This Super Autobacs was very similar to the one up in Gunma, except this one just had a bit more stuff. Especially Bubble Shifters! Sadly, they were alot stricter with taking pictures and I was forced to use my phone, which doesn't always focus properly. lol On our way out this Silvia was heard, and the guy was checking something with the engine since he kept revving it. There's a video link below at the bottom of the post for this. ^_^ This is one of the reasons I would much rather live outside the city like in Yokohama or even Gunma than directy in Tokyo. There's just too many damn people. lol This was taken on our way to Akihabara. back at the UDX Parking area we spotted this wierd Mercedes Smart car thingy.. more S15 Itasha awesomeness! This time its Yui from the show Angel Beats who's in the band Girls Dead Monster. This clean MR-S was hanging around as well. We decided to go back up to street level to check more stuff out, and ran into this meido wearing neko-mimi. she looks lost, maybe we should help her. :p We decided to go to this regular Maid Cafe since I couldn't find any Tsundere ones on Darrick's iPhone. However, when we entered they made sure we knew that there was no english(which wasn't a problem) and that there's also a 5,000Yen($5 USD) seat fee. The place was pretty packed, and we figured we've seen enough maids, so we decided not to stick around. They didn't allow cameras in there obviously, so I wasn't able to take any pictures, but just from watching for a few minutes, its pretty cool and full of moe-overload. haha After scoping out Akihabara, we went back to my hotel to rest up for a bit before going to grab dinner. Once we popped the TV on, I noticed that the Yokohama Bay Stars were playing. lol We ended up eating at this Family Resteraunt since they had the most variety, and Darrick's a pretty picky eater. lol I totally forgot to take a picture of my Beef stew I ordered, but luckily I remembered the Cheescake Pudding Parfait I ordered. One thing that was funny, is darrick has asked if the parfaits will be big. I told him "nah, it'll be a little small probably." well, for mine that was the case, but not his. haha The ice cream on his was suuper sweet, so neither he nor I could eat all of it. lol Day 10 will probably be spent catching up on all of my blogging form the past 3 days, and sending Darrick off to Narita Airport. Here's video of stuff from today: http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLD2175AE82FF33523&feature=view_all   [gallery link="file" columns="4" orderby="post_date"]

posts.title: Japan Trip: Day 10 (More Media editing and downtime)
posts.markdown: Day 10 was another down day for me. Most of it involved catching up on blog posts, seeing darrick off to Narita Airport, and grabbing some food with my friend Yoshi again. Breakfast for the day consisted of more awesome french toast, a cream bun, some starberry yogurt, and more milk tea. :p Darrick got.......ice cream. lol after chilling at my hotel for a while, and catching up on some blogging, we took the JR Yamanote Line over to Shinagawa station, so he could catch the Narita Express train, that goes directly to the airport. some stupid looking guy trying to throw dueces at me through the train..*shrugs* :p After a long day of catching up with blogging, I decided to try this vietnamese place by my hotel. Their Pho was actually pretty good, and I really liked whatever noodles they used. It had this pretty cool view from the window of the main street too. Yoshi replied to my message I sent him about getting a bit late, and I had already eaten dinner. But, I met up with him anyways, and he had this huge burger, while I had something a bit smaller. I ended up getting the apple pie, which was HELLA SMALL. It was good, but jeez..I was pretty dissappointed. one thing I wont miss about japan, is the small portion sizes. while, sometimes its nice if you're not hungry, i'd rather have extra to be able to take home for lunch or something. lol That's about it for day 10. I've noticed every couple of days I need to have one of these downtime days just to recharge, and catch up on everything. lol [gallery link="file" columns="4" orderby="post_date"]

posts.title: Japan Trip: Day 5 (more Yakiniku, Tama River park, Random Car Spottings)
posts.markdown: Today was pretty laid back, and just involved hanging out with my friend ken at his place for most of the day.   Woke up around 7am to nice weather once again. One thing that's kind of annoying is i've only been able to sleep like 6-8 hours here. I guess it could be due to the humidity n stuff, but generally at night its alot more enjoyable than during the day IMO. A quick shot of the street below, since I don't think I've gotten one yet. Breakfast consisted of more of the awesome Kiriin Milk Tea, French Toast, a Sweet Bun, Peach Yogurt, and some fruit. That French toast was BOMB, and I'm for sure going back tomorrow to get more. haha The yogurt even had a cool little straw, along with small slices peaches in it. ^_^ While I was waiting for my friend Ken at Kawasaki Station, I spotted this awesome old school car on a flatbed. It was lowered n everything, But, sadly I wasn't able to get my phone out in time to get a closer shot. :( Awesome view ontop of the bridge while heading back to his place Once arriving, I met his wife Sutomi who was very nice and later had a present for us all to try. Shortly after, we busted out the food and began cooking. It's worth noting that Ken's friend Charles brought some SUPER GOOD marinated chicken pictured above with the blue lid. I thought I got a picture of it, but I guess I was too busy eating it. haha Everybody throwing stuff on the grill, and waiting, which was the worst part of it knowing how good it tasted. lol This type we had was Kalbi which is a specific type of cut from the cow, since its beef and all. lol Just a closer shot of stuff on the grill. lol Before heading out, Sutomi had made us some custom Carmel/Chocolate bread. It was really good. I think so far, one of the biggest highlights of my trip has been the food. haha Afterwards, we went to throw the football around, and skate at the nearby park for a while. It started to get dark, so we decided to head back to the station, and head home. But, the city background looked really cool at dusk. I guess I have photographer skills sometimes.. haha One cool thing about where ken lives is that the river below literally seperates living in Kawasaki area vs. Tokyo Metropolis area. Originally he had to pick between a place on either side of the river, but decided on the tokyo side due to some extra benefits it provided. Here's the sign saying you're entering into Kawasaki. I kept having to struggle to take quick pictures as we were heading back to the station. This one, is a Honda Civic Type-R passing by. This one was really hard to get, but I wanted to snap a pic for my friend Mike. I didn't notice it at first, and by the time I had my camera out it was almost too late. But, yeah, its a Toyota Celica that was lowered and had HID's,exhaust, decent sized wheels, and some low profile type kit. Super clean subie that passed by us. Again, another case of my camera being in my bag, and me having to be a kung-fu master to pull it out in time, and time a picture. I'm gonna have to work on my shutter speed n stuff though. They keep coming out slightly blurry >_< After getting off at my station and walking back to my hotel I head this guy coming from a mile away! 2jz twin turbo Toyota Supra(JZ80). It sounded so sexy...*drools* oh, and speaking of sexy. This Ferrari 599 California(Thanks to Teru-san for the correction) was just chilling across the street from my hotel. went across the street to get a better look. :p Is it just me, or do those headlights look awfully similar to a 370Z. lol Finally, going back across the bridge it looks like some traffic was starting to build up on the other side of the street. In this pic there's a pretty cool looking Alfa-Romeo(center in white) along with an Nissan(infiniti) VIP car(slightly above to the right in white), but I'm not sure of the model. lol Tomorrow, I don't have much planned. I'll probably hang out at the hotel, work on more footage, watch some anime, and then go meet some old co-workers for dinner. [gallery link="file" columns="4" orderby="post_date"]

posts.title: Japan Trip: Days 12-13 (Yebisu Garden Palace, Random Stuff from Kawasaki)
posts.markdown:
Hey All, Sorry for the lack of posts. I actually had one last japan post to do here before getting into some other stuff. However, I recently started up school for the summer, got a new job, and had some other things that have taken up most of my time/focus.(Ken knows what i'm talking about) ;) haha Well, with that said, lets go back in time a little bit! haha My second to last day here in japan is a pretty boring one. Today was mostly spent venturing around with not much to do, and finishing up on my blog stuff. lol Found this really cool can of orange soda when I was at AGP over in the Fuji area. I was going to try and keep it, but broke down during lunch and decided to just drink it. haha After a quick lunch, I decided to take a stroll down the main road in Meguro to go check out the Yebisu Garden Palance that Ken had kept raving about. haha Along the way, I found a couple opportunity's to get some good shots. Also managed to spot this cool 80's Mecedes. Although I'm not quite sure what model it was..Any guesses? This really wierd looking building caught my eye. haha reminded me from something out of a Dr.Seuss book. :p I noticed closer I got, the ritzier and more fancy things were getting. Outside of one of the hotels was this nice waterfall thing. Sapporo Beer Station! this area was really cool and seemed to be like its own mini-town within tokyo. haha Panning over to the left more, there's a shot of the corridor that goes down some stairs and is lined with places to eat, and little shops. Everything was pretty expensive, so I decided to just look around instead of buying anything. haha Further ahead, there was this courtyard with a mansion behind it. I later realized this is actually a restaurant! 0_o Another thing I noticed, is alot of businessmen seemed to come here for lunch since it was overall really pretty and one of the few quiet places in the city to sit and enjoy your afternoon. lol Another shot, this time looking backwards. On the way back to my hotel I spotted this wierd looking building with a giant red ball stuck into the side. Now, most of you are probably wanting to know what it was. Same here, so I decided to go check it out! yep, definitly wierd aright....HDS...? Maybe its some crazy building for a secret government orginization that fights with mechs!!??? oh....it's just a driving school....OR IS IT!!?? Managed to snap a picture of this R35 GTR after passing the driving school. I got a bit of a laugh as I passed this Subaru Dealer on the way home. This Celica seemed completely out of place! Maybe it was trying to convince that BRZ to come over and be a Toyota. :p Dealerships in general are SUPER small in japan compared to here in the US, where we have rows and rows of cars lined up outside. I bet your wondering where they're supposed to store all the new cars right? well... Mostly the same way they store bikes! racks on racks on racks! haha After getting back to the hotel, I was trying to figure out where I should eat at. I decided to try MosBurger since it was close-by. When I went in there, they had a picture of a normal cheeseburger. I could read the whole menu just fine without the pictures, but was feeling a bit lazy, so I just ordered that. Now, here's the wierd park. See that wierd "chili" like substance in my burger? THEY ALL COME WITH THAT. I don't quite get why since its not mentioned on the menu, but I guess its a mosburger special thing. Also, another thing I noticed is there's alot of places that have melon soda in japan, which tastes awesome. The  burger on the other hand, was a bit crappy for the price I paid, but...it filled me up, so no complaints I guess.

Day 13

My last day in japan was pretty uneventful, but after checking out of my hotel, I went back over to my buddy Ken's place to hang out with him and his wife for a bit. After trying to think of something to do, we finally agreed on going to the movies, and getting some food, since my flight wasn't until later that night. Here I finally got a picture of the japanese movie theatre. The seats and inside overall is alot better kept, then the ones here in the US. lol They had this cool Doraemon popcorn box for kids. I was almost tempted to buy one just for the hell of it. haha Afterwards we went to another burger joint called Freshness Burger that Ken and his wife assured me I wouldn't be disappointed. Sure enough, I wasn't, and while the burger seemed a bit small, it was pretty loaded. The price was a bit steep though comapred to here in the US for a burger. It was 1,132Yen which works out to being about $14USD. Get used to this when in Tokyo though, because this is a pretty average price here. haha This place had a cool sign with Do As Infinity's signature on it! ^_^ We ended up finding a store that was very similar to Spencer's here in the US, and they had some wierd stuff. haha Yeah.......basically a giant poo hat. lol Here's a sign for a store that sold a bunch of Ultimate Muscle stuff. haha Oh yeah, manequinns in japan are wayyy cooler than the boring ones we have in the US. haha Well, that's about it from my trip! Here's a quick shot of me in LA for my layover on the way to Seattle. Overall I'm really glad I was able to take this trip, meet and hangout with everybody over there, and I had a blast! I'm for sure going to come back again to japan sometime next year! [gallery link="file" columns="4" orderby="post_date"]

posts.title: Yuki: Upgrades Summer 2012
posts.markdown: Hey guys! So i've finally gotten some time to make a progress report on Yuki since coming back from Japan! ^_^ More pictures, and shtuff after the jump! Anyways, first thing up was to get my sound system in order. While having my 6x9 speakers in the rear, and 6" ones in the door was good, sometimes I like to hear bass without fear of killing my speakers. So, I enlisted the help of my buddy mike for some suggestions on getting a sub woofer After checking out Mike's setup in his Toyota Celica, I decided I really liked it and wanted something similar. This is the Infinity Basslink 2.0, which is just a newer version of the one he has. One thing that I really liked about this unit, is the fact that it has the amp built into it, and also it features dual-sided 10" subs. Overall this setup is really nice because you can tune it to just have light bass(what I like) or crank it up, and get some really good hard hitting stuff. Ignore my dirty hatch, and skateboard, but this is basically how it sits for now. Unfortunately, with the s13 hatch, there really isn't any good places to bolt stuff in the hatch without drilling. Seeing as my gas tank is there, I don't feel like doing that. haha The sub is heavy enough that is doesn't move around, but just incase I grabbed an old elastic belt I had, and wrapped it around the strut tower just to prevent it from playing pin-ball in my hatch. haha After getting that little upgrade, my music sounds alot more complete, and it was time to move onto another minor project i've been putting off since wintertime. Which was, my coilovers. Remember those torsen bearings I installed when I did the swift springs + corner balance? well...I sort of neglected them and the winter time turned them into rusy bearings that popped everytime I turned the wheel at slow speeds or a standstill. This didn't jive very well with the ladies...so...I finally got it taken care of. haha Here's a before shot of how they looked...not very pretty I know. lol I think if I had greased these with something they would've lasted a bit longer. One thing that sort of concerned me is how the pressure from one of the springs actually cut into the washer there on the right. I'm not sure if that's a result of too much pre-load, so I'll have to double check the pre-load on my fronts next time I do an oil change or something. Here's everything all nice and clean. I ended up just putting the plastic washer back for now, as they don't make ugly popping noises, and work just fine for now. haha One thing I have to say, is I'm rather surprised with these Megan Racing coils. I've had them now since about 2009, and i've done track days as well as DD, and they've showed no signs of having any issues *knock on wood*. For 800 bucks, not a bad deal. Eventually I'd like to upgrade to some KW coils, but for now these will do just fine.^_^ Anyway, moving on, I decided I had enough of my brakes rusting up. Same thing started happening as before, and my passenger front caliper started rusting up again. So, I then made up my mind to go full aluminum for brakes, and made that as being my next priority. I looked through my options, and almost settled on doing a full Z32 swap with aluminum stuff, but then my buddy ricky mentioned some nonsense about Cadillac CTS-V brakes for the fronts. well...turns out he was right! 0_o I picked up these set of 4-piston brembo's which are exactly the same caliper found on the EVO VIII for $150 bucks brand new from gmpartsdirect.com. Only downsite is it didn't come with the pins n stuff, so I had to order that from autozone for $20. Using these plus a bracket that Mazworx makes for $100 bucks, and some Evo VIII pads and rotors, you have a bolt up kit in the front for the S13! This is basically the same performance wise as doing the Evo VIII brake swap, but for a fraction of the price! Also, one thing I liked is these calipers were already silver, so I wont have to paint them :p As for the rear, I decided to stick with an aluminum Z32 setup but swapping out stock Steel knuckles for some Z32 Aluminum ones. I plan to swap out the old bushings for some SPL spherical ones to get smoother suspension movement, and prevent binding. This enables me to still keep things simple swap wise since its very popular, as well as reduce some unsprung weight! Also, with this total setup, I'm able to get some aggressive pads all around. That was one big thing I sort of didn't like about the Q45 setup, is not a very wide range of pads to choose from in the front. On that note, I plan to go with these Project Mu HC+ pads. I've ran Project Mu pads before in the past(B-Spec), and aside from the natural fade that occured while driving hard on stock s13 brakes, I felt like they dusted a bit too much. But, other than that I was very happy with them! Below you can see a nice chart showing their overall range of use, and these are the best pads in terms of temperature use! 0-800degree's is awesome! compared to the B-specs 0-500 temp. Also, according to this chart, research i've done, and past experience with Project Mu pads, I'll get the best of both worlds in terms of having a good pad for both street and track use! ^_^ As for rotors, I plan to go with these DBA 4000 series slotted rotors for now. I'd really love to rock 2-piece aluminum rotors as well, but they're a bit expensive and I would like to put that money into other things. haha Going this route with the 4-piston CTS-V fronts and 2-piston Z32 rears actually helps out my overall brake bias. I was talking with Ken the other day about this, but realized some of my numbers were incorrect from memory and I had to re-calculate my numbers. For a reference, a stock s13 has a 70% brake bias towards the front. I have no chart for this anymore, and I'm too lazy to remake it. So, just trust me. haha My current setup with a 15/16" BMC, and Q45 front calipers actually pushes me to 81% bias. This explains the big problem i've been having with the fronts locking up wayy too soon. I currently Have Federal 595's which are a pretty decent tire, so its not a matter of having some crappy all-season tire. lol I don't have ABS, so I do expect there to be some lockup if you just slam on the brakes obviously. lol Switching to this CTS-V front and Z32 rear setup, actually settles things back down to a solid 74%. I think this will feel better overall and help balance the car out alot more under hard braking. Along with this, I plan to get a new sit of Dunlop Direzza Star Specs, which should also help provide a bit more grip as well under braking. Especially because for camber I'm running 3 degrees in the front and 2 in the rear. So, straight line braking isn't as great as it could be. I've also been tossing around the idea of trying a new set of wheels. Possibly some Enkei RPF-01's due to them being Forged, alot lighter than my current wheels, and balancing out a bit nicer. We'll see about those though a bit later on in the summer. Anyways, I've got the calipers already for the brake stuff, so now its just a matter of collecting all the remaining pieces, and bolting everything on! Getting this brake stuff finished up is my main goal for this summer. Once that's taken care of, I have some suspension bits, I'd like to replace before finally stashing away the rest of my money for importing an ae86, and my sr20vet motor swap in yuki! ^_^

I'm not sure if that's a result of too much pre-load, so I'll have to double check the pre-load on my fronts next time I do an oil change or something.

Here's everything all nice and clean. I ended up just putting the plastic washer back for now, as they don't make ugly popping noises, and work just fine for now. haha One thing I have to say, is I'm rather surprised with these Megan Racing coils. I've had them now since about 2009, and i've done track days as well as DD, and they've showed no signs of having any issues knock on wood. For 800 bucks, not a bad deal. Eventually I'd like to upgrade to some KW coils, but for now these will do just fine.^_^

Anyway, moving on, I decided I had enough of my brakes rusting up. Same thing started happening as before, and my passenger front caliper started rusting up again. So, I then made up my mind to go full aluminum for brakes, and made that as being my next priority. I looked through my options, and almost settled on doing a full Z32 swap with aluminum stuff, but then my buddy ricky mentioned some nonsense about Cadillac CTS-V brakes for the fronts. well...turns out he was right! 0_o

I picked up these set of 4-piston brembo's which are exactly the same caliper found on the EVO VIII for $150 bucks brand new from gmpartsdirect.com. Only downsite is it didn't come with the pins n stuff, so I had to order that from autozone for $20.

Using these plus a bracket that Mazworx makes for $100 bucks, and some Evo VIII pads and rotors, you have a bolt up kit in the front for the S13! This is basically the same performance wise as doing the Evo VIII brake swap, but for a fraction of the price! Also, one thing I liked is these calipers were already silver, so I wont have to paint them :p

As for the rear, I decided to stick with an aluminum Z32 setup but swapping out stock Steel knuckles for some Z32 Aluminum ones. I plan to swap out the old bushings for some SPL spherical ones to get smoother suspension movement, and prevent binding. This enables me to still keep things simple swap wise since its very popular, as well as reduce some unsprung weight! Also, with this total setup, I'm able to get some aggressive pads all around. That was one big thing I sort of didn't like about the Q45 setup, is not a very wide range of pads to choose from in the front.

On that note, I plan to go with these Project Mu HC+ pads. I've ran Project Mu pads before in the past(B-Spec), and aside from the natural fade that occured while driving hard on stock s13 brakes, I felt like they dusted a bit too much. But, other than that I was very happy with them! Below you can see a nice chart showing their overall range of use, and these are the best pads in terms of temperature use! 0-800degree's is awesome! compared to the B-specs 0-500 temp.

Also, according to this chart, research i've done, and past experience with Project Mu pads, I'll get the best of both worlds in terms of having a good pad for both street and track use! ^_^


As for rotors, I plan to go with these DBA 4000 series slotted rotors for now. I'd really love to rock 2-piece aluminum rotors as well, but they're a bit expensive and I would like to put that money into other things. haha

Going this route with the 4-piston CTS-V fronts and 2-piston Z32 rears actually helps out my overall brake bias. I was talking with Ken the other day about this, but realized some of my numbers were incorrect from memory and I had to re-calculate my numbers. For a reference, a stock s13 has a 70% brake bias towards the front. I have no chart for this anymore, and I'm too lazy to remake it. So, just trust me. haha

My current setup with a 15/16" BMC, and Q45 front calipers actually pushes me to 81% bias. This explains the big problem i've been having with the fronts locking up wayy too soon. I currently Have Federal 595's which are a pretty decent tire, so its not a matter of having some crappy all-season tire. lol I don't have ABS, so I do expect there to be some lockup if you just slam on the brakes obviously. lol

Switching to this CTS-V front and Z32 rear setup, actually settles things back down to a solid 74%. I think this will feel better overall and help balance the car out alot more under hard braking.

Along with this, I plan to get a new sit of Dunlop Direzza Star Specs, which should also help provide a bit more grip as well under braking. Especially because for camber I'm running 3 degrees in the front and 2 in the rear. So, straight line braking isn't as great as it could be. I've also been tossing around the idea of trying a new set of wheels. Possibly some Enkei RPF-01's due to them being Forged, alot lighter than my current wheels, and balancing out a bit nicer. We'll see about those though a bit later on in the summer.

Anyways, I've got the calipers already for the brake stuff, so now its just a matter of collecting all the remaining pieces, and bolting everything on! Getting this brake stuff finished up is my main goal for this summer. Once that's taken care of, I have some suspension bits, I'd like to replace before finally stashing away the rest of my money for importing an ae86, and my sr20vet motor swap in yuki! ^_^

posts.title: Yuki: Misc Photos
posts.markdown: one more post for the weekend! I've got a few misc photo's that i've been meaning to stick up here as well! ^_^ so here they are. lol First one is actually from back before I left on my japan trip. lol My buddy Ricky(white shirt) and John(black shirt) went to grab food at the mall nearby. When we came out this Supra happened to be sitting next to my car. we were pretty blown away when this chick started walking towards is, and unlocks the car. We stood and chatted with her for a bit, but sadly the car was an auto...:( I recently got a new job since coming back from japan, and one thing I did understimate was how expensive parking was downtown! >_< My old job paid for parking, so I never had to worry about it. I finally found a couple good spots that have parking for alot cheaper if you get there before 9am. I work at 6, so this isn't a problem for me. haha Here's one that was on the rooftop, so I thought it was a good time to snap a quick picture. haha My friend Kyle managed to find my car at Formula Drift Round 5 here in Seattle,WA last weekend! quick shot I wanted to take of Yuki hanging out behind the Falken Tire rig which again is at Formula D. :p My friend Eriko grabbed a picture of me as we were leaving a Japanese study group I regularly attend at the Univeristy of Washington. I managed to trick her at first into thinking I was driving on that side! ^_^ haha Chillin at a meet over at Golden Gardens park in downtown Seattle. hmm..what's this? I wonder who's follow me.... Turned out it was my dad, who caught me as I was coming home form work. lol My buddy Bryan actually took this one, as we were hanging out at Ricky's place. I really like this center garnish, it makes the car look wayy better IMO Giving yuki a quick bath while the weather is nice here. haha yummmm...^_^

posts.title: Yuki: cts-v/z32 brake swap finished!
posts.markdown:
After spending many hours in frustration over the weekend and the past couple days, I've finally completed my CTS-V/Z32 brake swap! write-up and more pics after the jump! いまはちょっといそがしいから。あとで、にほんごかきますよ！;) Note: If you haven't checked out my progress posts regarding the brake swap, its worth doing so! there's some good information regarding z32 anchor bolts, brake bias, and other stuff! http://domofactor.com/2012/07/yuki-upgrades-summer-2012/ http://domofactor.com/2012/10/yuki-cts-vz32-brake-swap-progress/ First off, I laid everything that the swap requires. Even tough i've covered it before, I'll relist everything that I needed for my swap, and the prices so you can see just how much bang for buck this swap is! Front: $130/caliper 2004-2007 Cadlillac CTS-V calipers: http://www.gmpartsdirect.com $180/rotor 2003-2005 Mitsubishi Evo DBA 4000 Series rotors: http://www.horsepowerfreaks.com $227 2003-2005 Mitsubishi Evo Project Mu HC+ pads: http://www.horsepowerfreaks.com $130 Mazworx CTS-V caliper brackets: http://www.mazworx.com/product/brakes/brake-kits/mazworx/street/cadillac-ctsv-caliper-adapters-s13s14 *Note: front knuckles are just OEM S13 ones since my previous knuckles were drilled out bigger to accept the massive 97' Q45 caliper bolts. Front Total= $977 Rear: $125/caliper($60 core charge) 1990-1996 300zx/z32 calipers: Autozone $203 1990-1996 300zx/z32 Project Mu HC+ pads: http://www.nissanparts.cc/catalog/?section=1336 $140 1990 300zx/z32 used ebrake assembly and rotors http://northwestnissans.com $68 1990-1996 300zx/z32 2+2 left ebrake cable: http://www.frsport.com/Nissan-Genuine-OEM-E-Brake-Cable-300ZX-2-2-LEFT-S13-with-Z32-brakes_p_12763.html $68 1990-1996 300zx/z32 2+2 right ebrake cable: http://www.frsport.com/Nissan-Genuine-OEM-E-Brake-Cable-300ZX-2-2-RIGHT-S13-with-Z32-brakes_p_12762.html $50 S13 to Z32 ebrake conversion bracket: http://www.canadanissan.com/showthread.php?232835-300zx-n-a-Z32-Rear-E-brake-assembly-completed-amp-S13-2-2-Z32-E-Brake-Cable-Brackets Rear Total= $779 Misc: $104 S13 to Z32 conversion brake lines: http://www.frsport.com/DIF-300ZX-Front---Rear-Brake-Lines-Conversion-Kit-for-S13-S14_p_7747.html $18/bottle 3 Bottles of Motul RBF600 DOT4 fluid: http://www.frsport.com/Motul-RBF-600-Factory-Line-Dot-4-Racing-Brake-Fluid_p_6409.html Misc Total= $104

Grant Total: $1861

Overall, doing a full brake overhaul of this caliber for under 2k is a great deal IMO. Especially considering a set of front STI or EVO Brembo calipers will run you 300-400 bucks for a set of used ones. I could have cut costs even more by getting a set of used z32 calipers or some cheaper pads both front and rear. But, I felt it was important to get as much new parts as possible to start fresh. Here's a quick shot of the driver's side before the swap Driver's side rear before the swap I got started with taking everything apart, but forgot the one cardinal rule when it comes to taking LCA's off of the knuckle. When you pound on a ball joint or anything with threads for that matter....ALWAYS LEAVE THE NUT ON!!! I forgot this sadly, and by the time I realized what I had done...it was too late. bye-bye nismo LCA..:( I'll replace the balljoin eventually, but for now I needed a new one ASAP! I managed to get a replacement after searching around for a couple days from Greg over at Felton's Auto Parts here in Snohomish,WA. I managed to get a new LCA with the balljoint and bushing already pressed in for about $60! 0_o I forgot to take a picture of the new LCA, but its nothing special really. Once I got that, I was able to keep chugging away at the swap. I was a little bit confused with how the bracket went on at first. I had thought it went behind the knuckle initially, so I got out my dremel to start gruming away the extra chunk of metal, then realized it didn't need to be done. Mazworx didn't send any instructions for how the bracket goes, and which bolt goes where, but after a little bit of playing with it, I was able to figure it out. This is how the bracket should fit on the passenger side. Upper knuckle hole(non threaded hole on bracket) = longest bolt Lower knuckle hole = smallest bolt Bottom hole on bracket = medium size bolt The only real unexpected hiccup I ran into with this swap was having to grind down these ribs on the caliper in order for the bracket to fit. On this caliper, I just used a small electric dremel, but it took a little while. So, I ran next door and borrowed my neighbors 6" bench grinder for the next one, which made quick work of the soft aluinum! The bracket should sit flush like so another angle of how the bracket should sit for the passenger side caliper. old and busted. Note the rust on this caliper even though its probably only 6 months old...just another great reason to switch to aluminum. new hotness! I did run into one issue with the Z32 conversion lines in the front, and the angle they have to take coming out of the caliper. Because they ended up being a bit too long and didn't seem to flow very smoothly, I ended up retaining my Q45 lines since they have a 90 degree bend in them. When I get time, I'll take a picture of it so you can see how I routed things to prevent it from rubbing on anything, or getting stretched at full lock. props go to my buddy john though for thinking of this idea. Before, I had them routed slightly different, and it wasn't as ideal. here you can see the 90 degree inward bend I was talking about, and how with a straight stainless line running downward, it might cause some problems. I attached the lines to the upper portion of the knuckle using a few zipties, and the metal connector section of the brake line to prevent any rubbing issues.   Before shot of the stock s13 brakes in the rear. This one was pretty straightforward since the Z32 swap stuff is already pretty well documented. One interesting tidbit, is I was able to get to the bolts for the knuckle by just removing all the the suspension arms, pulling out the axel a bit from the hub, and getting a stocket with an extension inside the half-circle grooves on the axel. Another thing I found out, is I was able to also replace the ebrake brackets without taking the driveshaft or center console out. Just make sure you loosen the adjuster nut on your ebrake handle all the way so you can re-attach the new lines easier. :p quick comparson shot of the rear rotors. I totally forgot to do this with the fronts, but up above are the old Q45 fronts which are 11.5" rotors. The Z32 rears are 11", and the stock s13 ones are 10". My fronts with the Evo VIII rotors are now 13"! ^_^ Got everything bolted up with no issues, and the ebrake works perfectly. got everything tightened down, and bled! Time to go bed in the pads, and test everything

Impressions

First off, I'll explain that these brakes barely even stopped when I first pulled out of the driveway. I just did a few test stops from 10mph, and naturally there wasn't much bite there. I proceeded to drive around my neighborhood, and did about 10-15 stops with medium braking from 30mph and about 20-30 seconds between each stop. After that, I left the brakes cool down for about 5 minutes. then went out and did about 5-10 stops from 45-50mph with another 30 seconds between each one. I'd say just before I switched to the 50mph stops is when I felt the brakes really start biting, and working properly. Overall, these stopping power this swap provides is AMAZING! the brake balance for this swap when combines with my 15/16" Brake Master Cylinder feels perfect! when I really lay into the brakes, I'm able to modulate the pressure pretty well compared to just instantly locking like i've heard with some full Z32 swaps. One thing to take note of, is these pads because they're meant to be used in both track and street applications, they have a slight squeel to them when coming to a stop. But, anybody that's owned high performance pads similar to Hawk HP+ or something similar will understand what i'm talking about. I also noticed that the the steering seems to be a tad bit heavier in the front. I think if I had gone with some 2pc rotors, that would have kept the feeling about the same. So, possibly switching to that, as well as some lighter forged wheels in the future will help with eliminating some of that. My one complaint, is compared to my Q45 brakes, there's a bit less pedal pressure. But, I think it'll just take some getting used to. There's still pretty good pressure, just not what i'm used to from before. I'm going to run everything for this week, then sometime next weekend, I'll do a final flush of everything using my Motul fluid. I found out, I had some extra fluid laying around. so, instead of using my Motul, I used that stuff for now.

$68 1990-1996 300zx/z32 2+2 right ebrake cable: http://www.frsport.com/Nissan-Genuine-OEM-E-Brake-Cable-300ZX-2-2-RIGHT-S13-with-Z32-brakesp12762.html

Here's a quick shot of the driver's side before the swap

Driver's side rear before the swap

I got started with taking everything apart, but forgot the one cardinal rule when it comes to taking LCA's off of the knuckle. When you pound on a ball joint or anything with threads for that matter....ALWAYS LEAVE THE NUT ON!!! I forgot this sadly, and by the time I realized what I had done...it was too late. bye-bye nismo LCA..:( I'll replace the balljoin eventually, but for now I needed a new one ASAP!

I forgot to take a picture of the new LCA, but its nothing special really. Once I got that, I was able to keep chugging away at the swap.

I was a little bit confused with how the bracket went on at first. I had thought it went behind the knuckle initially, so I got out my dremel to start gruming away the extra chunk of metal, then realized it didn't need to be done. Mazworx didn't send any instructions for how the bracket goes, and which bolt goes where, but after a little bit of playing with it, I was able to figure it out. This is how the bracket should fit on the passenger side.

Upper knuckle hole(non threaded hole on bracket) = longest bolt

Lower knuckle hole = smallest bolt

Bottom hole on bracket = medium size bolt

The only real unexpected hiccup I ran into with this swap was having to grind down these ribs on the caliper in order for the bracket to fit.

On this caliper, I just used a small electric dremel, but it took a little while. So, I ran next door and borrowed my neighbors 6" bench grinder for the next one, which made quick work of the soft aluinum!

The bracket should sit flush like so

another angle of how the bracket should sit for the passenger side caliper.

old and busted. Note the rust on this caliper even though its probably only 6 months old...just another great reason to switch to aluminum.

new hotness!

I did run into one issue with the Z32 conversion lines in the front, and the angle they have to take coming out of the caliper. Because they ended up being a bit too long and didn't seem to flow very smoothly, I ended up retaining my Q45 lines since they have a 90 degree bend in them. Before, I had them routed slightly different, and it wasn't as ideal.

here you can see the 90 degree inward bend I was talking about, and how with a straight stainless line running downward, it might cause some problems.

I attached the lines to the upper portion of the knuckle using a few zipties, and the metal connector section of the brake line to prevent any rubbing issues.

 

Before shot of the stock s13 brakes in the rear. This one was pretty straightforward since the Z32 swap stuff is already pretty well documented. One interesting tidbit, is I was able to get to the bolts for the knuckle by just removing all the the suspension arms, pulling out the axel a bit from the hub, and getting a stocket with an extension inside the half-circle grooves on the axel.

Another thing I found out, is I was able to also replace the ebrake brackets without taking the driveshaft or center console out. Just make sure you loosen the adjuster nut on your ebrake handle all the way so you can re-attach the new lines easier. :p

quick comparson shot of the rear rotors. I totally forgot to do this with the fronts, but up above are the old Q45 fronts which are 11.5" rotors. The Z32 rears are 11", and the stock s13 ones are 10". My fronts with the Evo VIII rotors are now 13"! ^_^

First off, I'll explain that these brakes barely even stopped when I first pulled out of the driveway. I just did a few test stops from 10mph, and naturally there wasn't much bite there. After that, I left the brakes cool down for about 5 minutes. then went out and did about 5-10 stops from 45-50mph with another 30 seconds between each one. I'd say just before I switched to the 50mph stops is when I felt the brakes really start biting, and working properly.

Overall, these stopping power this swap provides is AMAZING! the brake balance for this swap when combines with my 15/16" Brake Master Cylinder feels perfect! when I really lay into the brakes, I'm able to modulate the pressure pretty well compared to just instantly locking like i've heard with some full Z32 swaps. One thing to take note of, is these pads because they're meant to be used in both track and street applications, they have a slight squeel to them when coming to a stop. But, anybody that's owned high performance pads similar to Hawk HP+ or something similar will understand what i'm talking about. I also noticed that the the steering seems to be a tad bit heavier in the front. I think if I had gone with some 2pc rotors, that would have kept the feeling about the same. So, possibly switching to that, as well as some lighter forged wheels in the future will help with eliminating some of that.

My one complaint, is compared to my Q45 brakes, there's a bit less pedal pressure. But, I think it'll just take some getting used to. There's still pretty good pressure, just not what i'm used to from before. posts.title: Yuki: Maintenance, and new S15 torsen diff
posts.markdown: Spent some time doing general maintenance this weekend on yuki as well as picking up a new differential! ^_^ I changed my oil, and when I decided to check some other things, I realized my spark plugs looked like this! 0_o Replaced the Spark Plugs with a brand new set of NGK's, and now the motor runs alot smoother, and has better power. :p Quick comparison of the two plugs. lol After changing my plugs, I went out and picked up with S15 Torsen(Helical) Differential. It came with a set of new Nismo ring gear bolts, OEM s15 half-shafts, and OEM bearings. There's about 10k on the diff, so its already been broken in! These ring bolts, had to be sent over from Japan since they don't stock them here in the US. New bearings everything all together, before it was installed. For Those that don't know, the Tosen diff, or Helical style, is basically a 1 way diff. Check out the video below to see how it works. but basically, using a set of gears, if one wheel comes off the ground, or has less torque than the other, the load is shifted to that wheel. Using this diff for now instead of a clutch-type like OS Giken gives me the advantage of not having to do any maintenance other than change the oil, have a quiet diff since I still daily drive this car, but still provide a locked diff under accelleration to be able to do some drifting and grip driving.
posts.html:
Spent some time doing general maintenance this weekend on yuki as well as picking up a new differential! ^_^

I changed my oil, and when I decided to check some other things, I realized my spark plugs looked like this! 0_o

Replaced the Spark Plugs with a brand new set of NGK's, and now the motor runs alot smoother, and has better power. :p

Quick comparison of the two plugs. lol

After changing my plugs, I went out and picked up with S15 Torsen(Helical) Differential. It came with a set of new Nismo ring gear bolts, OEM s15 half-shafts, and OEM bearings. There's about 10k on the diff, so its already been broken in!

These ring bolts, had to be sent over from Japan since they don't stock them here in the US.

New bearings

everything all together, before it was installed.

For Those that don't know, the Tosen diff, or Helical style, is basically a 1 way diff. Check out the video below to see how it works. but basically, using a set of gears, if one wheel comes off the ground, or has less torque than the other, the load is shifted to that wheel. Using this diff for now instead of a clutch-type like OS Giken gives me the advantage of not having to do any maintenance other than change the oil, have a quiet diff since I still daily drive this car, but still provide a locked diff under accelleration to be able to do some drifting and grip driving.

posts.title: Yuki: Engine issues, Fuel Upgrades and Drifting Debut!
posts.markdown: hey everyone, I've been pretty busy as of late with my new job as a DevOps Engineer @ SEOmoz. So, finding a good chunk of time to sit and push out new posts has been difficult. haha Luckily, Derrick has been holding down the fort until now. Since its saturday, and I don't have much else to do, how about I share some progress I've made with yuki over the past month. So, recently as some of you may know, i've been having some really annoying idle and hesitation issues with my KA24DE since around mid-december. Its almost as if my engine realizes its going to get replaced soon, and is throwing a fit as a result. haha either way, i've been trying to hunt down this issue by doing all sorts of things. I was starting to get at my wits end with this, and only has a few more options left to try. Since the idle issue I was having only occured after the car had warmed up, I tried changing out the IACV, which didn't really help me much. Next, I decided since I'm going to be going SR soon anyways, I might as well replace the fuel pump and filter. I decided to upgrade to Deatschwerks' new turbin style 255lph fuel pump, and OEM Z32 fuel filter. I also happened to check my distributor cap & rotor only to find, that my rotor was...well..broken. lol I'm still kind of amazed the thing even ran! Either way, I thought for sure, doing these things would fix my problem...well....not quite. Having basically given up on trying to fix my KA in time for the Evergreen Drift School event, I decided to go get some new tires mounted up to my S14 SE wheels, and drive the car as it was. But, apparently my motor had other plans. The night before the drift even, my motor completely died on the way home from work, and I ended up having to wait for the tow-truck for 3 hours! >< Luckily, I had enough ride height, to get on/off without the need for ramps. :p Later that night, my friends and I found the problem to be the brand new rotor I bought for my distributor just stopped working. After putting my old broken one on, the car fired right up! So, on the way to the track in the morning I bought a another new one just incase. haha At Last! I finally managed to have Yuki make her debut at the track, and a drift event to boot! lol People were actually very surprised this was my first time ever drifting on that track, and second time drifting ever. Props go to Andy and Suenaga-san from the Team Orange Drift School for helping me progress so much in such a short amount of time! I have a review post from when I went over to Ebisu for it here! I also thought it would be funny and a good idea to run my japanese plates I had instead of my regular street plates to prevent any issues with insurance. plus, these ones look way cooler and give me +5 hp! ;) A big thanks to my friend's Gaelen Norman over at Big Boy Media and Eddi Hughes from CodeSleepShred.com who both gave me some great pointers and help throughout the day. Apparently, Gaelen has deemed me the "E-brake master" based on my constant use of it instead of clutch kick or doing regular transitions. haha soon enough, i'll learn to rely on it less though. :p Anyways, here's some footage from both myself, and Eddi of the event. FYI, the footage from eddi was all blooper stuff. but, it made me realize I'll need some steering angle upgrades possibly in the future. Alot of other guys did the bank since they've driven there before. But, since I was having engine issues, and this was my first time out with Yuki, and my first time at that track, I decided to play it safe and stay away from the bank. ;) I ended up having a blast in my first event, and can't wait for more track driving for both grip and drifting this year!

Props go to Andy and Suenaga-san from the Team Orange Drift School for helping me progress so much in such a short amount of time! I have a review post from when I went over to Ebisu for it here!

Alot of other guys did the bank since they've driven there before.
