posts.title: Japan Trip 2.0: Day 13 (Shibuya,Harajuku and Ginza)
posts.markdown: Day 13 I had much more energy after getting a power nap and some extra sleep. lol The weather was awesome and I mostly did a bunch of exploring with friends. First up for the day  was for to  meetup with my friend Kosuke and do some exploring around Shibuya. Here you can really see how packed it is at the famous Shibuya Crossing near the Hacihko statue. you can see how popular of a meetup spot this is. One thing I found that helps, is being very specific in the meetup spot. For example, in this case I said at the hachiko statue, infront of the green train. This makes it alot easier for people to find you and vice-versa! ^_^ After meeting up with Kosuke, we went off to grab some Curry for breakfast. This is the haamburger curry breakfast. Most times when you order food, you can specify Omori(big portion). I'm glad they offer this, since sometimes regular meals aren't enough for me. Also, another thing that's pretty cool is most places always give you miso soup with your meal. After breakfast we made our way across town to go check out Harajuku. One thing that's really nice,especially in the city is how smooth the roads are! Next time I come here, I'm for sure going to bring my skateboard to get around instead of walking. lol Having some of these sections with shade proved a nice relief from the sun! One thing that sort of caught me off guard  was this free public wifi! Usually you need to go to a coffee shop or something, so this is something I think would be really cool to implement in other countries! Once at Harajuku, this familiar Ford Fiesta was spotted! Turns out Ken Block is hosting a gymhana event going on in Odaiba soon, so the jdm monster girls, and the rest of the monster team were out promoting and hanging out free drinks. Something tells me people like that alot better than pointless tissues. :p A quick shot of one of the main popular streets in Harajuku. Sadly, this was a weekday. So, not much was going on during the day. :\ another thing I noticed in japan is some wierd store names...this one i'm not sure why its called happy room, but it kinda makes me want to go there. lol It was pretty hot out, so we decided to stop off in this cafe callded Pearl Lady to grab some bubble tea. Little did we know, Fuji TV was actually shooting for their afternoon news segment! 0_o At first I was kind of excited that my drink would be on national TV! But then, just like these two high school girls, Me and Kosuke were actually interviewed...in Japanese! 0_o Luckily I didn't mess anything up, but the TV staff were pretty amazed I was able to listen and reply to questions in japanese. lol Sadly, my friend didn't record the show, so I don't have any footage of it. But, the name of the program I believe was Super News. After gabbing some bubble tea, we headed over to the train station to part ways. It was great seeing him again, and I can't wait to visit again! Later that afternoon I metup with my friend Teppei to have dinner, and explore some sections of Ginza! One thing I still can't quite get over is how awesome Japan, and Toko specifically is at night. It doesn't really compare to any other cities i've been to so far. One things I was a bit surprised with, is there weren't quite as many nice cars as I expected there to be on a saturday night. lol Luckily, this pretty clean BMW M3 was potted though. I have no idea what kin dof car this is, but it looked cool. :p Apparently, you can eat puffer fish in japan. But, from what Teppei tells me, yo need a special license to  serve it since it contains poison and needs to be handled a certain way. Its safe to say, I wasn't feeling quite that risky this time to eat there. :p Instead we ended up grabbing some yakitori at this place, which was pretty good! The ordering system was pretty similar to some places in Seattle. You pick what you want on the menu, then write it down on the piece of paper. I ordered some chicken, and potato salad. After eating food I was pretty familiar with, Tappei decided to have me try some wierder stuff. lol This one is chicken skin, and gizzard. The taste was actually totally fine, but the consistency I didn't really like. Next up was some chicken hearts. Which, again tasted good, but the texture was not my thing. lol After eating, we did some more exploring. Another thing that's pretty cool is how many different clubs, bars, and places to hangout there are in tokyo! Not sure why, but I really liked this shot. lol I did spot a number of Audi's like the one below, as well as tons of BMW's and Mercede's. Again, you just can't be the atmosphere that some of these tiny back alley resteraunts have! >< Apparently, Japan has its very own Hooters as well! 0_o I'll have to go check it out next time. lol Spotted this pretty clean AMG Mercedes... ...and this newer Subaru Impreza One thing that's pretty cool is we got some free sushi for helping out some Europeans and the Sushi chef solve an issue with their bill. For our troubles, we were given some free sushi! Also, its worth noting how cheap the sushi is!! I also took a risk, and decided to try a Natto roll. I don't rally mind Natto itself, but the sushi was actually really good! One thing that also is pretty neat is most sushi places will give you green tea after your meal! After getting sushi, we called it a night, and headed out at Shimbashi station. One downside to taking the train in tokyo late at night, is they stop at midnight. So, getting on the train, Especially the Yamanote line around 11-12 is always a chore from it being crazy crowded. >< The following day was the last one I had to be in tokyo, so I made some plans to grab food, and do some shopping for friends.

posts.title: Japan Trip 2.0: Day 14 ( Shibuya, Wangan and Daikokufuto)
posts.markdown: Day 14 was my last day in Tokyo and man was it ever a long one. Check out everything after the jump! The day started off pretty well, spotting this clean blacked out R35! First stop of the day was to get lunch with my friend Miki for some Mexican Food. It was actually pretty nice weather out, but my phone was being wierd. So, some of these pics are foggy. :( The burrito was actually really good, and tasted like a regular mexican food over in seattle After lunch, I headed over to Shibuya to do some shopping for friends As usual, it was pretty crowded, but.... There was this random looking Rolls Royce chillin on the side of the street. While in shibuya, I also got a quick glance of this really clean S15! Next stop was to head over to Tokyo station to pickup some gifts from Tokyo Bannana, and to checkout a couple interesting stores I heard about.. Yep, the Tomica store! This is the same one featured in the Speedhunters article here. Sadly, there wasn't really very many interesting things this time..:\ I then took the train over a few stops to Akihabara to go check out Yodabashi Camera to see what other goodies they have. It's a bit wierd having big stores like this be on 8 or 9 Floors, instead of one or 2 huge ones like in the US. lol This time, there were plenty of interesting Tomika models to drool over! for example, they even had ones like this Toyota 86(Scion FRS/Subaru BRZ) I then made my way over to the Hobby section, and was blown away how many awesome models they had! Some of you might have noticed this awesome Senna model. I was really close to buying it, but it was a bit pricey at 54 bucks. :p Moving down the line they had some other awesome cars like this R31 with...Michael Bay explosions..? and a sweet N2 Toyota AE86. Naturally, they also had some Itasha models as well! They also had some more expensive Die Cast models, but these were even more expensive ranging from $50-$500! 0_o Another thing I wanted to snap a quick picture of, is in japan, they use booth babes for EVERYTHING. It's kind of awesome. :p After doing some shopping, I had some time to kill before more Shenanigans that were going to take place that day. This Tropicana grapefruit soda was AMAZING!  My friend Kensaku(ken) was nice enough to drive all the way out to Meguro from Kakegawa to hang out!  We went to find a parking spot nearby, and went to get some food since he hadn't eaten dinner yet. We ended up going into this place that had AMAZING tonkatsu. I had the Black Pepper, and Garlic pieces, which I would later regret....alot... Also, the rice came in these cool wooden containers! After getting food, we decided to hitup the Roppongi area since I didn't quite get time to go over there yet. While driving around this Ferrari 458 Italia was spotted! I kinda found this bumper sticker funny, and this sort of thing is rare in japan on regular cars. lol Another shot of downtown Roppongi Its hard to believe that this girl actually had the same pace as us throughout the city for about 10-15 minutes. We kept getting stuck at red lights, and she would catch up to us on her bike. lol I felt like I was back in California for a second when I spotted this old school lowrider with underglow! We then went over to cruise through the red light district, when we spotted one of his friend's cars. Apparently he likes to go there pretty often. :p We made a short pitstop somewhere in tokyo(I forget the name), so Ken could pickup some contract thing from one of his co-workers. While the contract exchange was going on, this pretty clean Mark II Chaser with BBS wheels pulled out from the alley infront of us. haha Its such a shame we don't have awesome 2JZ 4-door cars in the US..:( By this time it was already around 1am, but I kind of wanted to go back to check out Daikokufuto again. So, we hopped in the Kei car beast, got on the legendary C1 Loop to do some late night wangan runs! I'm still blown away at how smooth these roads are even after 20+ years of people racing on them. lol Those of you who have plated Tokyo Extreme Racer, or other japanese racing games know how annoying, but also useful these lane seperators can be. Its worth noting shoving another car into these in real life at 300km/h is probably not a very good idea. :p hmm...stay on the C1 loop, or hitup the legendary Wangan/BayShore route... We decided to hop off the C1, and head towards Daikoku. Along the way, we ran into this super popular tunnel that's been featured many times in various Option videos like this one One thing that really jumped out at me, is why Ken kept putting his hand on his visor from time-to-time. Turns out, that when speed cameras take pictures, they MUST have a picture of your license plate AND your face. If you hide you face, they can't legally give you the ticket!!! much nicer than here in the US. lol We finally arrived at Daikokufuto, but decided to do some scouting around on the outer areas to see if there was any drifting going on. Years back, ken used to go drifting here alot, so we went to check out some old spots he knew of. We noticed this modified scooter, which looked pretty  cool Also spotted another Mark II Chaser We kept finding cars scattered here and there, but no real action going on. We stopped off at a small convenience store to grab some snacks, and decide whether to give up an head back to daikoku, or do some more exploring. By this time, it was already almos 2am, and I had to wake up in another 3 hours. >< Apparently, there was a big accident recently in the area when a car was drifting and slammed into a big crowd of people, killing a few. so, they moved on to some other areas. :\ We followed around this R33 Skyline for a bit, before heading back over to daikoku Yet another skyline spotted! Its kind of funny how common they are over here compared to the couple that we have over in Seattle. While it wasn't quite as crowded this time even though it was a saturday night, there were still plenty of interesting cars to check out. One of them being this Peugot or Citroen that had a huuge wing. lol Here's the R32 that we spotted a few pictures above! There were a small group of FD's also gathered around. All of them were pretty clean too! This red one I especially thought looked awesome. Off in the corner was this guy in another FD doing some quick tuning on his laptop, before heading out for some more wangan runs I assume. I chatted with him for a bit, bit he didn't seem to be in the mood. lol One car that was REALLY unexpected was this Mclaren MP4-12C! Its hard to describe how amazing this car looks and sounds in person! A par of these nice Supras were also found off in the corner. At some point, I really would love to ride in one of these guys! Oddly enough, just as we were leaving was first time seeing a R34 during this trip! haha One thing I didn't realize was that they turn the lights off on Tokyo Tower after midnight in order to save power. By this time it was already 3am, and I needed to get some kind of sleep before Derek came banging on my hotel door at 6am. lol I can't wait to get back out to the Wangan in a proper car, and do some high speed runs! ^_^  Huge thanks to Ken for driving around everywhere, and coming out to Tokyo to meetup!   [gallery columns="4" ids="10339,10338,10337,10336,10335,10334,10333,10332,10331,10330,10329,10328,10327,10326,10325,10324,10323,10322,10321,10320,10319,10318,10317,10316,10315,10314,10313,10312,10311,10310,10309,10308,10307,10306,10304,10303,10302,10301,10300,10299,10298,10297,10296,10295,10226,10219,10218,10217,10216,10215,10214,10213,10212,10211,10210,10209,10208,10207,10206,10205,10204,10203,10202,10201,10200,10199,10198,10197,10196,10195,10194,10193,10192,10191,10190,10189,10188,10187,10186,10185,10184,10183,10182,10181,10180,10179,10178,10177,10176,10175,10174,10173,10172,10171,10170,10169,10168,10167,10166,10165,10164,10163,10162,10161,10160"]

The day started off pretty well, spotting this clean blacked out R35!

First stop of the day was to get lunch with my friend Miki for some Mexican Food. It was actually pretty nice weather out, but my phone was being wierd. So, some of these pics are foggy. :(


The burrito was actually really good, and tasted like a regular mexican food over in seattle

After lunch, I headed over to Shibuya to do some shopping for friends

As usual, it was pretty crowded, but....

There was this random looking Rolls Royce chillin on the side of the street.

While in shibuya, I also got a quick glance of this really clean S15!

Next stop was to head over to Tokyo station to pickup some gifts from Tokyo Bannana, and to checkout a couple interesting stores I heard about..

Yep, the Tomica store! This is the same one featured in the Speedhunters article here. Sadly, there wasn't really very many interesting things this time..:\

I then took the train over a few stops to Akihabara to go check out Yodabashi Camera to see what other goodies they have. It's a bit wierd having big stores like this be on 8 or 9 Floors, instead of one or 2 huge ones like in the US. lol

This time, there were plenty of interesting Tomika models to drool over!

for example, they even had ones like this Toyota 86(Scion FRS/Subaru BRZ)

I then made my way over to the Hobby section, and was blown away how many awesome models they had!

Some of you might have noticed this awesome Senna model. I was really close to buying it, but it was a bit pricey at 54 bucks. :p

Moving down the line they had some other awesome cars like this R31 with...Michael Bay explosions..? and a sweet N2 Toyota AE86.

Naturally, they also had some Itasha models as well!

They also had some more expensive Die Cast models, but these were even more expensive ranging from $50-$500! 0_o

Another thing I wanted to snap a quick picture of, is in japan, they use booth babes for EVERYTHING. It's kind of awesome. :p

After doing some shopping, I had some time to kill before more Shenanigans that were going to take place that day. This Tropicana grapefruit soda was AMAZING! 

My friend Kensaku(ken) was nice enough to drive all the way out to Meguro from Kakegawa to hang out! 

We went to find a parking spot nearby, and went to get some food since he hadn't eaten dinner yet.

We ended up going into this place that had AMAZING tonkatsu.

I had the Black Pepper, and Garlic pieces, which I would later regret....alot...

Also, the rice came in these cool wooden containers!

After getting food, we decided to hitup the Roppongi area since I didn't quite get time to go over there yet. While driving around this Ferrari 458 Italia was spotted!

I kinda found this bumper sticker funny, and this sort of thing is rare in japan on regular cars. lol

Another shot of downtown Roppongi

Its hard to believe that this girl actually had the same pace as us throughout the city for about 10-15 minutes. We kept getting stuck at red lights, and she would catch up to us on her bike. lol

I felt like I was back in California for a second when I spotted this old school lowrider with underglow!

We then went over to cruise through the red light district, when we spotted one of his friend's cars. Apparently he likes to go there pretty often. :p

We made a short pitstop somewhere in tokyo(I forget the name), so Ken could pickup some contract thing from one of his co-workers.

While the contract exchange was going on, this pretty clean Mark II Chaser with BBS wheels pulled out from the alley infront of us. haha Its such a shame we don't have awesome 2JZ 4-door cars in the US..:(

By this time it was already around 1am, but I kind of wanted to go back to check out Daikokufuto again. So, we hopped in the Kei car beast, got on the legendary C1 Loop to do some late night wangan runs!

I'm still blown away at how smooth these roads are even after 20+ years of people racing on them. lol

Those of you who have plated Tokyo Extreme Racer, or other japanese racing games know how annoying, but also useful these lane seperators can be. Its worth noting shoving another car into these in real life at 300km/h is probably not a very good idea. :p

hmm...stay on the C1 loop, or hitup the legendary Wangan/BayShore route...

We decided to hop off the C1, and head towards Daikoku. Along the way, we ran into this super popular tunnel that's been featured many times in various Option videos like this one

One thing that really jumped out at me, is why Ken kept putting his hand on his visor from time-to-time. Turns out, that when speed cameras take pictures, they MUST have a picture of your license plate AND your face. If you hide you face, they can't legally give you the ticket!!! much nicer than here in the US. lol

We finally arrived at Daikokufuto, but decided to do some scouting around on the outer areas to see if there was any drifting going on. Years back, ken used to go drifting here alot, so we went to check out some old spots he knew of.

We noticed this modified scooter, which looked pretty  cool

Also spotted another Mark II Chaser

We kept finding cars scattered here and there, but no real action going on.

We stopped off at a small convenience store to grab some snacks, and decide whether to give up an head back to daikoku, or do some more exploring. By this time, it was already almos 2am, and I had to wake up in another 3 hours. >< Apparently, there was a big accident recently in the area when a car was drifting and slammed into a big crowd of people, killing a few. so, they moved on to some other areas. :\

We followed around this R33 Skyline for a bit, before heading back over to daikoku

Yet another skyline spotted! Its kind of funny how common they are over here compared to the couple that we have over in Seattle.

While it wasn't quite as crowded this time even though it was a saturday night, there were still plenty of interesting cars to check out. One of them being this Peugot or Citroen that had a huuge wing. lol

Here's the R32 that we spotted a few pictures above!

There were a small group of FD's also gathered around. All of them were pretty clean too!

This red one I especially thought looked awesome.

Off in the corner was this guy in another FD doing some quick tuning on his laptop, before heading out for some more wangan runs I assume. I chatted with him for a bit, bit he didn't seem to be in the mood. lol

One car that was REALLY unexpected was this Mclaren MP4-12C!

Its hard to describe how amazing this car looks and sounds in person!

A par of these nice Supras were also found off in the corner.

At some point, I really would love to ride in one of these guys!

Oddly enough, just as we were leaving was first time seeing a R34 during this trip! haha

One thing I didn't realize was that they turn the lights off on Tokyo Tower after midnight in order to save power. By this time it was already 3am, and I needed to get some kind of sleep before Derek came banging on my hotel door at 6am. lol I can't wait to get back out to the Wangan in a proper car, and do some high speed runs! ^_^  Huge thanks to Ken for driving around everywhere, and coming out to Tokyo to meetup!

posts.title: Japan Trip 2.0: Day 15/Final (Idler's at Tsukuba Circuit)
posts.markdown: So finally my last day of the trip arrived, and I really didn't want to leave. Luckily, I had saved some of the most fun for last, and headed back up to Tsukuba Circuit for the day to Cheer on Hideki and his AE86 participate in Idler's Games! ^_^ First off, I'd like to kick myself in the butt, for not verifying some pictures trasnferred over to my laptop before deleting them off the SD card. >< I had borrowed one from Hideki to use while I had my go-pro footage recording so I could still take pictures. But, when I got back home, I realized all of the pictures I had THOUGHT copied over, were all corrupted...T_T Anyways, the day started off with Derek coming by and picking me up in this SWEET Nissan Largo!  It even came with a KA24DE!! 0_o After getting some breakfest we setup on the 2hour drive from Tokyo to Tsukuba Circuit. Some of you who read my posts from the last trip, probably recognize this building. :p We also drove by the giant Skytree Tower While on the road we spotted one of the Eneos fuel trucks Also was one of those tricked out japanese 18 wheelers. lol I forget what they're called though. Just like last time there's plent of small tuning shops with awesome cars scattered outside the track, such as this Audi. After parking and walking towards the track, we spotted Hideki's trailer! Its pretty cool since its a double decker, but the best part of it.... yes, even their trailer truck has bucket seats and a harness! haha if you'll recall there was a little Nissan pickup that I thought was interesting because it had bucket seats in it. Also spotted was this awesome official Tsukuba Circuit S15 Pace Car!! Once entering the circuit pit area that awesome feeling came over me where I still couldn't quite believe I was here at Tsukuba for Idlers. I also think its cool they provide these small gas stations on the track. I noticed this last year at Fuji speedway, and again here at Tsukuba. It makes it much easier than having to make a run miles away. lol One of Derek's friend's Ben and his wife who run a car importing business in Canada also came along. When we first entered, we immediatly were drawn to the new purple RWB creation. This thing is simple amazing, and you can see its creator Nakai-san catching a quick nap over in the corner. Even Derek agrees that huge double stacked wings make for great way to escape the heat! haha Its also pretty cool how the turbo is just hanging off the back like that. lol Moving on, we ventured further down into the pits, and ran into some surprises... Like this little Honda a super clean Z That was driven by this kid. haha just kidding :p and for the first time, I saw a TVR in person. This thing is...beautiful! The interior was also amazing on this car. lol oh yeah, and we can't forget this massive V8 under the hood There was also this super rare Austin Martin. Not sure why, but this official Idlers porsche reminds me of a Hot Wheels car. lol We spotted a section with a bunch of 86's and figured Hideki was among them somewhere. After a few minutes we spotted his car and eventually him. I think its safe to say Ben doesn't fit in these very well. lol Here's a quick shot of the engine bay. The one thing i've always liked about cars in japan, is their simplicity. I turned my attention to the car infornt of his, and noticed it also had a Garage Miura sticker on it... Turns out his dad(Yasuhiro-san) also enjoy's driving 86's around the track and has been racing 86's and other cars for around 30 years. His dad's setup was running this new blacktop 4AG swap, so we was a bit unsure of how the car would perform. The car was still running a parial interior, but just by looking at the cluster you can tell its a racecar first and foremost. Also, it doesn't seem like his dog liked me hanging around, so we moved on to check out some other stuff. haha There were also a bunch of these mini-f1 cars that were called Formula Kei To my surprise, they were actually running SR engines! 0_o also, anybody spot the Williams replica paintjob in the corner? I think its safe to say, porsche's dominated the attendance at this event. lol I thought it was funny how almost everybody was in the pits, and not in the grandstands. That means, more people actually went to the pits to check out cars, and interact with the drivers. After the first Qualifying session where hideki managed to lock up 7th, we headed into the cafeteria to get lunch. Excuse the horrible photo, but it was actually pretty corded in there, but the AC felt reaaaly good. lol I ended up eating the some Gyudon and miso soup. While we were eating, plentyof other classes were still going, and the track was pretty much being used almost all day long! While I was on vacation, I realized I didn't take any pictures of my comapny's mascot Roger the robot. So, I figured this was a good chance to snap a few while I had all my things with me. This is also a good section to mention, I totally missed getting almost all of the action pictures since they were part of the corrupted batch I mentioned earlier...T_T I'm going to have to skip ahead towards the end since I don't have any shots really after this point. Hideki ended up with a GREAT start in the race to pull up to 5th, but tire wear caught up to him, and he fell back to 7th place in the end. He had won this race in the past in 2010 and again in 2012. But, he still had some awesome driving to keep the 2 guys off of him for most of the race, and really pumped me up to go do some driving of my own! I'll include some videos of his Qualifying and Race at the bottom of the post. Hideki also introduced me to one of his Friend's Suzuki-san from the shop Orange Planning ended up qualifying 1st, and managed to hold off the other car for almost the entire race to take the win. Sadly, I don't have any pictures of his car..T_T but the setup for his engine was pretty interesting as It used a combination of different toyota engines, such as an AE101 bottom end. They had people get up on the podium and pose for pictures and whatnot shortly before. Before the race, Suzuki-san joked that if he won I can just take his place on the podium. haha Another thing I thoguth was pretty neat, is they also get a picture of all drivers who participated in the race. After doing the ceremonies, it was time to go through the pits and cleanup. The best thing about owning hatch backs, is how much stuff you can cram back there. lol After packing up, I grabbed something cool to drink and to keep me awake. haha This latte I bought was AMAZING. one thing that threw me off is with japanese vending machines, some give you the option for cold or hot drinks. I wasn't paying attention and accidentally ordered the hot one which I later gave to somebody. lol d As you can tell, I look pretty tired. So, I managed to hitch a ride on the back hatch back to the parking lot area. :p The whole time this guy in the truck seemed to have a good laugh at my hanging off the back of this loaded up 86. lol After a few short minutes we passed through this tunnel underneath turn one. Hopefully, I'll get to see Tsukuba Circuit again, but as a driver instead! ;) While outside on the parking lot we also spotted this super awesome rally style Evo. Overall, it was hot, but I had a great time visiting Tsukuba again and can't wait to go back!! Derek and Ben ended up leaving part way throughout the day. But, Wataru and Azusa were nice enough to give me a ride all the way to Haneda Airport even though they live here near Tochigi. Its also worth noting Natsuko and her friend who's name I forget also came out to cheer on Hideki. >< We loaded up the in DoriNeko Mobile.... And caused shenanigans the whole way there! haha Once we got the the airport, it was only around 7pm, and my flight wasn't until midnight. They didn't have anything going on that night, so they were hanging out with me in the airport until my flight. Haneda is actually a really nice airport, and its location is smack dab in the middle of tokyo. I totally forget what this was called, but it was rice with egg and pork...I think. lol its about 3 weeks after as I write this so I can't quite remember. lol Before heading off to go check in, we made a stop at the Hello Kitty store, and were a bit surprised with some of the things we found...0_o After checking my bags in, and parting with everyone, my Japan trip was finally coming to a close sadly. The one thing I took away from this trip, is that Japan really is AWESOME. If given the chance, I would LOVE to live here. I can't wait to come back, perhaps i'll come back a bit sooner than waiting an entire year again. lol Hopefully you guys enjoyed these posts! ^_^ Its worth noting, I had such an itch to do some racing from watching hideki and everyone else race, that as soon as I got off my plane, I dropped my bags off at home, and headed straight for the Go-Kart track! haha [gallery columns="4" ids="10350,10351,10352,10353,10354,10355,10356,10357,10358,10359,10360,10361,10362,10363,10364,10365,10366,10367,10368,10369,10370,10371,10372,10373,10374,10375,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,"]

posts.title: Japan Trip 2.0: Day 4 (Nikko Circuit)
posts.markdown: Hi everyone, Recently Alexi Smith over at Nori Yaro told me there was a Wind's Auto drift day going on at Nikko Circuit. So, I decided to make the 2.5hr trip up there for the first time to check it out! It's worth noting before I start, that halfway throughout the even, I realized my camera settings were totally jacked up. >< so, some of the pictures came out wayy too light. haha At first I really didn't feel like going just because I had previously went to the same area in Tochigi for Tsukuba just a few days earlier. But, then I remembered how much crap I would've gotten had I not gone. :p So, I grabbed a few things at the convenience store before heading out in the morning. On thing I noticed is that the Pringles here in japan taste totally different! they're less salty. My friend Shunji in seattle is ALWAYS buying pringles, so I guess thats why. haha I started off with taking the shinkansen from Tokyo Station. Turns out I had about 30minutes to kill before my train, so I did a bit of exploring outside the station. There was this cool courtyard area with small waterfalls that I ran into. I didn't want to wander too far, so I just posted up on this street corner to see if I could snap any cool things that drove by. :p Sadly, there was nothing that exciting, and after a while I made my way back to the train station. One thing I always forget to take pictures of are these JR ticket machines. They're really easy to use in both japanese and english. You can also recharge your SUICA card here, which is basically like a rechargable card. I finally decided to get one this time around, and its much easier than dealing with a bunch of tickets. If I haven't already mentioned it....there's a TON of people here in tokyo. lol   Inside the station, they have another special gate for the shinkansen, with people to help you out so you don't end up on the wrong train or something. lol   After being on the train for a couple hours, I finally arrived at Utsunomiya, and was suprised with how many taxi's were lined up outside. Luckily, I happened to pick the perfect one! Along the way, I had a great conversation with Yama-san about various things about the US and Japan. He was even nice enough to cut my fare off early, and I only paid part of what I was really supposed to! ^_^ Between the shinkansen and the taxi fare I was supposed to pay, you're looking at around $100 just to get to Nikko Circuit. Sadly, Yama-san doesn't use facebook, or mail or anything, but hopefully he enjoys reading this! Also, he recently had a baby 3 months ago, so congratulations to him! When I first walked into the area, I was a bit shocked to believe I was actually AT Nikko. The one thing I also enjoyed, is unlike events in the US. It's FREE to come and hangout in the pits, and watch the event. You only pay if you're going to be driving. Also, the prices on food/dinks weren't hiked up, and were actually super cheap. This super clean Nismo styled 180 caught my attention Also, here's one of the Wind's Auto owned R32's a quick shot looking back on the part of the pit area There certainly were some unusual drift cars out there today, like this SW20. He also had some pretty amusing stickers which you can catch out farther down below! Here this EVO was getting in some AWD drifting action. It was really wierd watching this car drift since there was hardly any countersteer, even though he had the angle. haha Also, this D1 machines from Thailand was tearing it up all day long! Whoever was driving this chaser also drove like his life depended on it. Some of the "mantries" these guys take going into this first corner is nuts! I also spotted this Missle Chaser from the shop Tokonatsu Factory! I also really loved the kit on this type-x S13 that looks like it was also participating in Tsuchiya's new series The Drift Muscle Also, I unexpectedly spotted Daigo Saito just chillin along the pit wall. lol   It's kind of hard to tell in this picture, but the paint on this S15 was super epic with a ton of pearl in it. lol   More awesome angle from this D1 machine was was making well over 1000HP with a built up 2JZ motor. Since there was a short break in the middle of the day, I decided to take some scenery pics with no cars on the track. Shortly after arriving I actually ran into Andy and Emily Grey from Powervehicles! Andy and Team Orange Driver Naoto Suenaga are the ones who gave me pointers when I attended the Team Orange Drift School last year! For this interested in that post, it can be found here Sadly, Andy's white chaser ran into a powersteering issue earlier in the day, so he had to retire. Luckily, Emilys blue one was still up and running strong. So, I was able to get some ride along footage with her at the bottom of this post! One thing that I noticed on alot of the cars, especially S-chassis, was the very simple mods. Brakes were pretty much stock, with upgraded pads. However, the one thing I did notice, is people actually spent money on quality parts like JIC, DG5, Tomei, ProjectMu, ect. This s14 took me back to the early 2000's for some reason. haha These 86's sounded super awesome flying by as well. It's funny when you stop and think that these only have 1.6L compared to the 2.xL of other motors like RB's, JZ's, ad SR's out on the track. quick shot back at the entrance area This pretty clean Bilstein 86 was also doing some laps. Although it seemed like he wasn't going very hard on it. lol Just because it's a new car, that doesn't stop some people though apparently! 0_o While I was on my way to go watfch some more action from the other side of the track, some body came pulling up with their bumper dragging along.... oh hey, look! It's Daigo Saito just trearing up Chaser Missle's as usual. haha Shortly after, it looked like somebody spilled oil on the track. So, all of the drivers went out to help cleanup the mess. This is the one big difference I notice even on Drift Tengoku videos. In the US, we had set corner workers that do this, and the drivers end up just relaxing. But, its kind of nice to see most of the drivers all pitching in to do their part in fixing up the track. They also had this mini street sweeper thing come in to spread out some of the powder, which is used to suck up some of the oil spilled on the track. Afterwards, it seemed like the track turned into a rally stage! 0_o Even though they could barely see anything, people were charging flat out into the first corner!! haha Some people like this guy were even getting some nice weight transfer going on before the flick to get it sideways. Shortly after, these guys started getting some pretty good tandem battles going lap after lap I noticed this SW20/MR2 pulled into the pits, so I went to take a picture of its awesome Pedo Bear sticker. :p They also started getting some good drift trains going on with daigo leading the pack. Except someting looked a tad off....but I couldn't quite figure out what it was... :p Shortly after, the MR2 also joined in on the fun I didn't catch this miata running much, but it seemed really simple and well done. Here Emily and Andy go out for another sesstion. It was really interesting riding in her car. It feels soo different compared to drifting my s13. Due to the amount of weight, and wheelbase, and how you can see the suspensio is setup with a really slow rebound in the rear, it had a really nice squat to it when going through the corner. This also gave it a ton of front grip as well it felt like. I can see why alot of D1 setups have been switching to using something similar like this now! Another quick shot from the front of this Drift Muscle 180! Emily using some front brake action on corner entry! More of the usual, This Toyota Altezza just eating pavement for lunch breakfast and dinner! >< This red 180, was killing it on entires all day long, and even got a couple nice reverse entries in as well. I meant to go ask him what setup he was using for knuckles, but I totally forgot. lol Here's a couple nicer panned out shot of Emily doing her thing. I was pretty surprised when she said this was only her 6th time actually driving here. This red Silvia was also super clean as well..hopefully he never crashes it. haha Finally got an action shot of the nismo inspired 180 from earlier! I forgot who was driving this Toyota Supra, but it sounded AMAZING. There were a number of guys from the shop Red-K as well sporting their signature red overalls, and this sweet looking R34. I figured it would be a cool to get shot of my helmet from pit wall. :p Daigo and the Drift Muscle 180 were really going at it towards the end there, and I also managed to capture Robbie Nishida in a picture. haha I managed to talk with him for a bit, and he's a really cool guy. I'll look forward to meeting up with him again when him and his Achilles team come to Seattle for Formula Drift! After about 6 hours of what seemed like non-stop driving, people finally started packing up to head home. Notice the super legid trailer in the back that's carrying the Thailand D1 Altezza and Daigo Saito's missle. One thing I thought was hilarious was this s13,  which was originaly white, but had been painted black. It got some reverse colored tire battle scars from his fight earlier with Daigo. haha It was great meeting Andy, Emily, and the rest of some of the guys from Powervehicles.com, and hopefully I can come back up to ebisu to visit sometime in the future! PS- throughout the entire day I somehow managed to keep my shirt clean, then right at the end as we were cleaning up the pits, I picked up a box of milk tea, that managed to squirt my shirt as I went to throw it away...*sigh* Everybody started packing up to head home, so it was time for me to call Yama-san since I needed to wait about 30 minutes for him to show up from the station. Yama-san did me a huge favor, and cut me the same discount fare I got on the way there as well! ^_^ Along the way back to the station I saw this super clean Honda NSX As I was heading into this station there was this local band playing one of their CD's that sounded pretty awesome. Their name was Cure Rubbish. Overall it was a long and tiring day, but I'm really glad I spend the money and went out there! It's taken me about a day to sift through all my photo's and write out this blog post though. heh Here's some video footage and a full gallery below! posts.html:
Hi everyone,

Recently Alexi Smith over at Nori Yaro told me there was a Wind's Auto drift day going on at Nikko Circuit. So, I decided to make the 2.5hr trip up there for the first time to check it out! It's worth noting before I start, that halfway throughout the even, I realized my camera settings were totally jacked up. >< so, some of the pictures came out wayy too light. haha

At first I really didn't feel like going just because I had previously went to the same area in Tochigi for Tsukuba just a few days earlier. But, then I remembered how much crap I would've gotten had I not gone. :p So, I grabbed a few things at the convenience store before heading out in the morning. On thing I noticed is that the Pringles here in japan taste totally different! they're less salty. My friend Shunji in seattle is ALWAYS buying pringles, so I guess thats why. haha

I started off with taking the shinkansen from Tokyo Station. Turns out I had about 30minutes to kill before my train, so I did a bit of exploring outside the station.

There was this cool courtyard area with small waterfalls that I ran into.

I didn't want to wander too far, so I just posted up on this street corner to see if I could snap any cool things that drove by. :p Sadly, there was nothing that exciting, and after a while I made my way back to the train station.

One thing I always forget to take pictures of are these JR ticket machines. They're really easy to use in both japanese and english. You can also recharge your SUICA card here, which is basically like a rechargable card. I finally decided to get one this time around, and its much easier than dealing with a bunch of tickets.

If I haven't already mentioned it....there's a TON of people here in tokyo. lol

 

Inside the station, they have another special gate for the shinkansen, with people to help you out so you don't end up on the wrong train or something. lol

 

After being on the train for a couple hours, I finally arrived at Utsunomiya, and was suprised with how many taxi's were lined up outside. Luckily, I happened to pick the perfect one!

Along the way, I had a great conversation with Yama-san about various things about the US and Japan. He was even nice enough to cut my fare off early, and I only paid part of what I was really supposed to! ^_^ Between the shinkansen and the taxi fare I was supposed to pay, you're looking at around $100 just to get to Nikko Circuit. Sadly, Yama-san doesn't use facebook, or mail or anything, but hopefully he enjoys reading this! Also, he recently had a baby 3 months ago, so congratulations to him!

When I first walked into the area, I was a bit shocked to believe I was actually AT Nikko. The one thing I also enjoyed, is unlike events in the US. It's FREE to come and hangout in the pits, and watch the event. You only pay if you're going to be driving. Also, the prices on food/dinks weren't hiked up, and were actually super cheap.

This super clean Nismo styled 180 caught my attention

Also, here's one of the Wind's Auto owned R32's

a quick shot looking back on the part of the pit area

There certainly were some unusual drift cars out there today, like this SW20. He also had some pretty amusing stickers which you can catch out farther down below!

Here this EVO was getting in some AWD drifting action. It was really wierd watching this car drift since there was hardly any countersteer, even though he had the angle. haha

Also, this D1 machines from Thailand was tearing it up all day long!

Whoever was driving this chaser also drove like his life depended on it. Some of the "mantries" these guys take going into this first corner is nuts!

I also spotted this Missle Chaser from the shop Tokonatsu Factory!

I also really loved the kit on this type-x S13 that looks like it was also participating in Tsuchiya's new series The Drift Muscle

Also, I unexpectedly spotted Daigo Saito just chillin along the pit wall. lol

 

It's kind of hard to tell in this picture, but the paint on this S15 was super epic with a ton of pearl in it. lol

 

More awesome angle from this D1 machine was was making well over 1000HP with a built up 2JZ motor.

Since there was a short break in the middle of the day, I decided to take some scenery pics with no cars on the track.

Shortly after arriving I actually ran into Andy and Emily Grey from Powervehicles! Andy and Team Orange Driver Naoto Suenaga are the ones who gave me pointers when I attended the Team Orange Drift School last year! For this interested in that post, it can be found here

Sadly, Andy's white chaser ran into a powersteering issue earlier in the day, so he had to retire. Luckily, Emilys blue one was still up and running strong. So, I was able to get some ride along footage with her at the bottom of this post!

One thing that I noticed on alot of the cars, especially S-chassis, was the very simple mods. Brakes were pretty much stock, with upgraded pads. However, the one thing I did notice, is people actually spent money on quality parts like JIC, DG5, Tomei, ProjectMu, ect.

This s14 took me back to the early 2000's for some reason. haha

These 86's sounded super awesome flying by as well. It's funny when you stop and think that these only have 1.6L compared to the 2.xL of other motors like RB's, JZ's, ad SR's out on the track.

quick shot back at the entrance area

This pretty clean Bilstein 86 was also doing some laps. Although it seemed like he wasn't going very hard on it. lol

Just because it's a new car, that doesn't stop some people though apparently! 0_o

While I was on my way to go watfch some more action from the other side of the track, some body came pulling up with their bumper dragging along....

oh hey, look! It's Daigo Saito just trearing up Chaser Missle's as usual. haha

Shortly after, it looked like somebody spilled oil on the track. So, all of the drivers went out to help cleanup the mess. This is the one big difference I notice even on Drift Tengoku videos. In the US, we had set corner workers that do this, and the drivers end up just relaxing. But, its kind of nice to see most of the drivers all pitching in to do their part in fixing up the track.

They also had this mini street sweeper thing come in to spread out some of the powder, which is used to suck up some of the oil spilled on the track.

Afterwards, it seemed like the track turned into a rally stage! 0_o

Even though they could barely see anything, people were charging flat out into the first corner!! haha

Some people like this guy were even getting some nice weight transfer going on before the flick to get it sideways.

Shortly after, these guys started getting some pretty good tandem battles going lap after lap

I noticed this SW20/MR2 pulled into the pits, so I went to take a picture of its awesome Pedo Bear sticker. :p

They also started getting some good drift trains going on with daigo leading the pack.

Except someting looked a tad off....but I couldn't quite figure out what it was... :p

Shortly after, the MR2 also joined in on the fun

I didn't catch this miata running much, but it seemed really simple and well done.

Here Emily and Andy go out for another sesstion. It was really interesting riding in her car. It feels soo different compared to drifting my s13. Due to the amount of weight, and wheelbase, and how you can see the suspensio is setup with a really slow rebound in the rear, it had a really nice squat to it when going through the corner. This also gave it a ton of front grip as well it felt like. I can see why alot of D1 setups have been switching to using something similar like this now!

Another quick shot from the front of this Drift Muscle 180!

Emily using some front brake action on corner entry!

More of the usual, This Toyota Altezza just eating pavement for lunch breakfast and dinner! ><

This red 180, was killing it on entires all day long, and even got a couple nice reverse entries in as well. I meant to go ask him what setup he was using for knuckles, but I totally forgot. lol

Here's a couple nicer panned out shot of Emily doing her thing. I was pretty surprised when she said this was only her 6th time actually driving here.

This red Silvia was also super clean as well..hopefully he never crashes it. haha

Finally got an action shot of the nismo inspired 180 from earlier!

I forgot who was driving this Toyota Supra, but it sounded AMAZING.

There were a number of guys from the shop Red-K as well sporting their signature red overalls, and this sweet looking R34.

I figured it would be a cool to get shot of my helmet from pit wall. :p

Daigo and the Drift Muscle 180 were really going at it towards the end there, and I also managed to capture Robbie Nishida in a picture. haha I managed to talk with him for a bit, and he's a really cool guy. I'll look forward to meeting up with him again when him and his Achilles team come to Seattle for Formula Drift!

After about 6 hours of what seemed like non-stop driving, people finally started packing up to head home. Notice the super legid trailer in the back that's carrying the Thailand D1 Altezza and Daigo Saito's missle.

One thing I thought was hilarious was this s13,  which was originaly white, but had been painted black. It got some reverse colored tire battle scars from his fight earlier with Daigo. haha

It was great meeting Andy, Emily, and the rest of some of the guys from Powervehicles.com, and hopefully I can come back up to ebisu to visit sometime in the future!

PS- throughout the entire day I somehow managed to keep my shirt clean, then right at the end as we were cleaning up the pits, I picked up a box of milk tea, that managed to squirt my shirt as I went to throw it away...sigh

Everybody started packing up to head home, so it was time for me to call Yama-san since I needed to wait about 30 minutes for him to show up from the station.

Yama-san did me a huge favor, and cut me the same discount fare I got on the way there as well! ^_^

Along the way back to the station I saw this super clean Honda NSX

As I was heading into this station there was this local band playing one of their CD's that sounded pretty awesome. Their name was Cure Rubbish.

Overall it was a long and tiring day, but I'm really glad I spend the money and went out there! It's taken me about a day to sift through all my photo's and write out this blog post though. heh

Here's some video footage and a full gallery below!

posts.title: Japan Trip Winter 2013: Part 1(Tsukuba)
posts.markdown: hey guys, finally, after a few months of slacking and putting this off here's my the beginning to my 3rd Japan Trip! Enjoy! So, previous cases when I went to Japan its always during the spring around May. This time, I wanted to experience what early winter was like, so I went over the New Years and X-Mas Holidays! This also gave me an extra week to spend. So, I was able to go for 3 weeks instead of the normal 2. :p Anywho, I set out from Seattle and landed at Haneda around 11:30pm. My friend Wataru and his wife Azusa were picking me up from some station over near Ibaraki. Which meant I had to transfer about 2 different times, all while hauling all my crap (suitcase, backpack, duffle bag, and a smaller suitcase). Luckily, I barely made my last transfer and arrived at the station on-time. The problem however, is I didn't yet have my rental sim card, and no wi-fi. So, I had no way to really get in touch with him. Also, he failed to tell me that this station unlike most country-side ones, has multiple exits. So, after the station started closing and I wandered around trying to get wi-fi for like an hour before finally just using my roaming with Verizon. Once he arrived, he told me his place was too small so we were gonna try and find a hotel for me, but it was too late at night, and check-in as long overdue for most places. Sooo, both him and his wife looked at each other and said "I guess all that's left is a Love Hotel". If you don't know what that is, do some google'ing. :p Anyways, once we got to the place we were like crap...who is gonna be the one to go with me to see if there was a room available. As funny as it was, his wife made Wataru go with me. So, basically 2 dudes walked into a love hotel, saw it was way too expensive for just one night, and left. haha In the end, I ended up sleeping in their car at the Convenience Store next to their place. :p Not the most comfortable, but it was fine for just one night. haha The following day, we got me checked into pretty cool older-style hotel with tatami floormats. Wataru had work and Asuza had some stuff to do, so I had a free day to wander until later that afternoon. I started off by walking around, to see what I can find, and surprisingly, this is what I run into...There was this super clean 86 sitting there, on what looked some tiny shop. I went to talk to one of the guys about it, and they said it was the owners, and had been sitting for quite some time. Some other awesome cars were sitting there too like this Evo.   As I started to walk into the main street this horrible looking FD went wizzing by :p I decided to venture off onto a side street for about 30 minutes, and take some scenery shots. by this time, it was later in the afternoon and I didn't eat lunch yet, so I stopped in at this Ramen place. The owner was actually super surprised that A) somebody non-japanese walked in and B) I spoke pretty fluent japanese. haha I ended up getting some free ice cream which was really nice of him! On the way back to my hotel I spotted some cool cars hiding around :p So, fast forward to the next day and friend Hideki from Garage Miura, and Suzuki-san from Orange Planning were going to be driving in the 86 Festival over at Tsukuba Circuit. Since Wataru is a friend of his, and also drives 86's, the plan was to head over there with Azusa who also drives an S14 Silvia. Before they came to get me, I made sure to get my fill of morning sentai tv shows! haha After Wataru came to get me from the Hotel, we headed back to his place to get Azusa. I was able to meet his brother and mom, and also snap some pics of their rides, and an evil kitty. lol [gallery link="file" columns="4" ids="10549,10548,10550,10551,10552,10553,10554,10555,10556,10557"] We then made our way over to Tsukuba Circuit which was about 15 minutes away. At the entrance, we ran into once of Azusa's friend's s13. As we headed into the circuit, there was also all the normal assortment of crazy 86's. It is interesting seeing some of the US style and parts coming over to japan now. haha [gallery columns="4" ids="10565,10566,10567,10562,10561,10559,10560,10622,10621,10563"] Once inside, we started searching for Hideki amogst the masses of 86's! for some reason, the blue pearl-ish of this one really stood out to me! We finally tracked him down after a few minutes, just as they were about to head out for Qualifying. We also found Suzuki-san next to him in he grid in the orange/black coupe. while they were running Qualifying, I headed off to check out some other cars. Lots of famous 86's were there such as CBY, Tec-Arts, Tsuchiya's personal car, and the TRD N2 racecar. The TRD car specifically was really clean and had some crazy looking headers. [gallery columns="4" ids="10577,10575,10578,10568,10607,10606,10597,10598,10600,10605,10609,10608,10580,10579,10604,10601,10602"] After qualifying, it was time to snap shot shots of the main race. Hideki was able to win his class, but I wasn't able to get go-pro footage. So, luckily Hideki took some for me with his own camera. :p Afterwards there was a pretty cool drift demo, and it was nice to see drifting back at Tsukuba after D1 left here years ago!   Lastly the main event was the N2 race. Let me just say that these things are loud, and wayyy faster that I thought they would be in person! 0_o After that we decided to head out, to go into the mountains for some sightseeing since I was leaving for tokyo later that night. So, see you again Tsukuba Circuit! We first headed up what was called the "Purple Line" of Mt.Tsukuba. This is the place in Initial D where God Hand and God Foot race at actually. haha There were already a few people up there enjoying the view as well.[gallery columns="4" ids="10623,10624,10625,10626,10628,10627"] On the way back down, we stopped off at the Tsukubajinja shrine, which was actually pretty amazing. I would've hated to go there back in the day when there were no roads. haha [gallery columns="4" ids="10623,10624,10625,10626,10628,10627,10643,10646,10645,10642,10641,10640,10639,10638,10637,10636,10635,10634,10633,10632,10631,10630,10629"] Also, got a pretty nice shot of Wataru trying to look like a badass and Azusa just looking plain cold. haha After the shrine, the last stop for the day was UP Garage! Even though this was my 3rd time in japan, I had never been there surprisingly! haha I was so surprised by how cheap the parts were! Hopefully we'll get one again over in the US, or something similar.[gallery columns="4" ids="10674,10672,10671,10670,10669,10667,10668,10666,10665,10664,10663,10662,10647,10648,10649"] Well, that's pretty much it for my Tsukuba stop of the trip! Hopefully you didn't get worn out. Since i'm writing this more than 2 months after the fact, i'm sure there's some stuff i'm missing. But, stay tuned for the Tokyo part of my series to be uploaded next within a week or so! As always, a full gallery of all the pictures are down below! [gallery columns="4" ids="10531,10532,10533,10534,10535,10536,10537,10538,10539,10540,10541,10542,10543,10544,10545,10546,10547,10548,10549,10550,10551,10552,10553,10554,10555,10556,10557,10558,10559,10560,10561,10562,10563,10564,10565,10566,10567,10568,10569,10570,10571,10572,10573,10574,10575,10576,10577,10578,10579,10580,10581,10582,10583,10584,10585,10586,10587,10588,10589,10590,10591,10592,10593,10594,10595,10596,10597,10598,10599,10600,10601,10602,10603,10604,10605,10606,10607,10608,10609,10610,10611,10612,10613,10614,10615,10616,10617,10618,10619,10620,10621,10622,10623,10624,10625,10626,10627,10628,10629,10630,10631,10632,10633,10634,10635,10636,10637,10638,10639,10640,10641,10642,10643,10644,10645,10646,10647,10648,10649,10650,10651,10652,10653,10654,10655,10656,10657,10658,10659,10660,10661,10662,10663,10664,10665,10666,10667,10668,10669,10670,10671,10672,10673,10674"]

So, after the station started closing and I wandered around trying to get wi-fi for like an hour before finally just using my roaming with Verizon.

Once he arrived, he told me his place was too small so we were gonna try and find a hotel for me, but it was too late at night, and check-in as long overdue for most places. Sooo, both him and his wife looked at each other and said "I guess all that's left is a Love Hotel". If you don't know what that is, do some google'ing. :p Anyways, once we got to the place we were like crap...who is gonna be the one to go with me to see if there was a room available. As funny as it was, his wife made Wataru go with me. So, basically 2 dudes walked into a love hotel, saw it was way too expensive for just one night, and left. haha

In the end, I ended up sleeping in their car at the Convenience Store next to their place. :p Not the most comfortable, but it was fine for just one night. haha


The following day, we got me checked into pretty cool older-style hotel with tatami floormats. Wataru had work and Asuza had some stuff to do, so I had a free day to wander until later that afternoon. I started off by walking around, to see what I can find, and surprisingly, this is what I run into...There was this super clean 86 sitting there, on what looked some tiny shop. I went to talk to one of the guys about it, and they said it was the owners, and had been sitting for quite some time.
Some other awesome cars were sitting there too like this Evo.

 

As I started to walk into the main street this horrible looking FD went wizzing by :p

I decided to venture off onto a side street for about 30 minutes, and take some scenery shots.

by this time, it was later in the afternoon and I didn't eat lunch yet, so I stopped in at this Ramen place. The owner was actually super surprised that A) somebody non-japanese walked in and B) I spoke pretty fluent japanese. haha I ended up getting some free ice cream which was really nice of him!

On the way back to my hotel I spotted some cool cars hiding around :p

So, fast forward to the next day and friend Hideki from Garage Miura, and Suzuki-san from Orange Planning were going to be driving in the 86 Festival over at Tsukuba Circuit. Since Wataru is a friend of his, and also drives 86's, the plan was to head over there with Azusa who also drives an S14 Silvia. Before they came to get me, I made sure to get my fill of morning sentai tv shows! haha

After Wataru came to get me from the Hotel, we headed back to his place to get Azusa. I was able to meet his brother and mom, and also snap some pics of their rides, and an evil kitty. lol

[gallery link="file" columns="4" ids="10549,10548,10550,10551,10552,10553,10554,10555,10556,10557"] We then made our way over to Tsukuba Circuit which was about 15 minutes away. At the entrance, we ran into once of Azusa's friend's s13.

As we headed into the circuit, there was also all the normal assortment of crazy 86's. It is interesting seeing some of the US style and parts coming over to japan now. haha

[gallery columns="4" ids="10565,10566,10567,10562,10561,10559,10560,10622,10621,10563"]

Once inside, we started searching for Hideki amogst the masses of 86's!

for some reason, the blue pearl-ish of this one really stood out to me!

We finally tracked him down after a few minutes, just as they were about to head out for Qualifying.


We also found Suzuki-san next to him in he grid in the orange/black coupe.

while they were running Qualifying, I headed off to check out some other cars. Lots of famous 86's were there such as CBY, Tec-Arts, Tsuchiya's personal car, and the TRD N2 racecar. The TRD car specifically was really clean and had some crazy looking headers.

[gallery columns="4" ids="10577,10575,10578,10568,10607,10606,10597,10598,10600,10605,10609,10608,10580,10579,10604,10601,10602"]

After qualifying, it was time to snap shot shots of the main race. Hideki was able to win his class, but I wasn't able to get go-pro footage. So, luckily Hideki took some for me with his own camera. :p

Afterwards there was a pretty cool drift demo, and it was nice to see drifting back at Tsukuba after D1 left here years ago!

 

Lastly the main event was the N2 race. Let me just say that these things are loud, and wayyy faster that I thought they would be in person! 0_o

After that we decided to head out, to go into the mountains for some sightseeing since I was leaving for tokyo later that night. So, see you again Tsukuba Circuit!

We first headed up what was called the "Purple Line" of Mt.Tsukuba. This is the place in Initial D where God Hand and God Foot race at actually. haha There were already a few people up there enjoying the view as well.[gallery columns="4" ids="10623,10624,10625,10626,10628,10627"]
On the way back down, we stopped off at the Tsukubajinja shrine, which was actually pretty amazing. I would've hated to go there back in the day when there were no roads. haha
[gallery columns="4" ids="10623,10624,10625,10626,10628,10627,10643,10646,10645,10642,10641,10640,10639,10638,10637,10636,10635,10634,10633,10632,10631,10630,10629"] Also, got a pretty nice shot of Wataru trying to look like a badass and Azusa just looking plain cold. haha
After the shrine, the last stop for the day was UP Garage! Even though this was my 3rd time in japan, I had never been there surprisingly! haha I was so surprised by how cheap the parts were! Hopefully we'll get one again over in the US, or something similar.[gallery columns="4" ids="10674,10672,10671,10670,10669,10667,10668,10666,10665,10664,10663,10662,10647,10648,10649"]
Well, that's pretty much it for my Tsukuba stop of the trip! Hopefully you didn't get worn out. Since i'm writing this more than 2 months after the fact, i'm sure there's some stuff i'm missing. But, stay tuned for the Tokyo part of my series to be uploaded next within a week or so! As always, a full gallery of all the pictures are down below!

[gallery columns="4" ids="10531,10532,10533,10534,10535,10536,10537,10538,10539,10540,10541,10542,10543,10544,10545,10546,10547,10548,10549,10550,10551,10552,10553,10554,10555,10556,10557,10558,10559,10560,10561,10562,10563,10564,10565,10566,10567,10568,10569,10570,10571,10572,10573,10574,10575,10576,10577,10578,10579,10580,10581,10582,10583,10584,10585,10586,10587,10588,10589,10590,10591,10592,10593,10594,10595,10596,10597,10598,10599,10600,10601,10602,10603,10604,10605,10606,10607,10608,10609,10610,10611,10612,10613,10614,10615,10616,10617,10618,10619,10620,10621,10622,10623,10624,10625,10626,10627,10628,10629,10630,10631,10632,10633,10634,10635,10636,10637,10638,10639,10640,10641,10642,10643,10644,10645,10646,10647,10648,10649,10650,10651,10652,10653,10654,10655,10656,10657,10658,10659,10660,10661,10662,10663,10664,10665,10666,10667,10668,10669,10670,10671,10672,10673,10674"]

posts.title: Japan Trip Winter 2013: Part 2(Tokyo)
posts.markdown: hey guys, Still working on trying to get this blog train rolling. Life has been hectic, so sorry for the slowness! :\ Anyways, lets pick up where we left off. The first section of my trip involved being up in Tsukuba for a few days. If you missed that post you can find it here! After Tsukuba, I made my way back down town Tokyo for about a week. So, my buddy Ken was nice enough to let me stay at his place again. This time, it was a bit closer towards Shinjuku which was nice. Aside from the occaisional wierdness like this, it wasn't all that bad and I had a great time! haha My one condition for staying there was that I had to bring back some various snacks that you can't find in Japan. Somehow, Ken thought putting Queso Cheese dip, and Flamin Hot Cheetos together was the best thing since sliced bread. Sadly, his stomach thought otherwise later. haha While in Tokyo, I made it a priority to visit as many people as I could. Since I was only there for a little under a week and had been there before. So, first person up on my hit list was my friend Teppei. We metup and grabbed some pretty good Okonomiyaki. Afterwards, I went to a Music store to pickup some CD's since they're alot more expensive back in Seattle. lol The next day I metup with my friend's Shin and Marina for some lunch. Surprisingly, the Italian food in tokyo is actually really awesome! On the way there, we spotted this random shop. Sometimes Tokyo never ceases to amaze me. :p For dinner that day, I metup with my friend Eriko. I totally forget the name of the dish I had, but it was pretty good. The next day I metup with Mai and Aya near their college which had some really nice looking tree's lightup at the entrance. Apparently, this is Loco Moco? WHO PUTS LETTUCE IN THAT!?I also thought it was pretty funny since the menu actually said Roco Moco. :p Ken started getting alot into film, so he followed me around most of the following day with his camera setup. First stop was a place that was actually right next to the hotel I usually stay at in Meguro called Hungry Heaven. I've seen the sign a number of times walking by it, but i've never actually gone inside until now. haha The bugers are a bit expensve, but definitely tastey! I totally forget where we went to after that since its been nearly 3-4 months after the fact, but this is what you end up dealing with in Tokyo...:( PEOPLE EVERYWHERE. this is the main reason I prefer quieter, countryside places. Cities have never really been my thing. lol While wandering around these things drove by..half mech half woman?? We Spotted this awesome tower in the distance, and thought it would be great to get some shots from there. Some of these buildings gave me vertigo just looking at them. haha We finally got to the top(52nd floor I believe), and busted out the cameras. The crazy part was you can actually feel the building sway. I guess due to the earthquakes, its neccessary. I just thought it was interested, since its totally different compared to some of the bigger buildings in seattle. There were some really great views from up there, and its kind of mind blowing just how dense Tokyo is. You don't really get the big picture from the street, but once you go higher up like this, its pretty crazy. Still feeling pretty Energetic, I hopped on the train to Yokohama to visit my friend Derek again. Since, I had some time to kill, I wandered around, and found this place! :p The Nissan Global Headquarters and Gallery Showroom!! There were mostly newer cars there, this didn't stop anybody from admiring great cars like the new 2014 GTR V-Spec, and 370Z convertible. They had this cool timeline things, that routed all over the showroom. As I followed it, I ran into something pretty cool... They had this sweet nismo ship filled with official nissan and nismo goodies!   I couldn't help myself and picked up a pair of new racing gloves! Sadly, I later learned that they are about 1 size too small..:( Nissan also had some great classics setup in the other corner of the show room as well! I noticed they had some cars outside, and I stepped out onto the patio area, then realized there were some great scenery shots to be taken. lol I got a call from Derek saying he was at the train station, so I started heading back and taking more scenery shots along the way. After getting some food we wandered around for a bit and stumbled on this 4-floor game center that was almost all filled with fighting games. haha The following day, I metup with my friend Chihiro who happened to be in town from Sendai for job hunting! That pretty much ends my Tokyo leg of the trip. It was short, and I mainly was just hanging out with friends most of the time. haha This post was a bit short on car content, so sorry if it was a bit boring. lol I've got some good stuff coming up from Shizuoka and Fuji Speedway next. So, lets see if I can manage to upload that stuff quicker than a month this time around! :p heh
