posts.title: Yuki: Boosted Goodness: Part 1
posts.markdown: Over the past 6-9 months i've been saving and piecing together parts for Yuki's new engine. Naturally, its only fitting that the platform is a SR20DET blacktop from a 1997 180sx Type-X. :p With that said, lets kick things off so I can start going over what's all there and how the build went! So, lets first start of with the motor itself. It was originally owned by my fried Joe, who was running it in his S14. However, after that got totalled out, he remembered I was looking for an SR to swap in soon, and cuz me an amazing deal. Some things already done to the motor when I got it were: -Eagle rods -CP Pistons(86.5mm) -Apexi Headgasket(87x.8mm) -APR Headstuds -Greddy Rocker Arm Stoppers -Garage Autohero Engine Balancing and Head Port -Nismo FPR and Nismo 550cc injectors -Nismo Waterpump -S15 T28 Turbo -Megan Racing Exhaust Manifold -Noname downpipe elbow -Apexi AFC Neo -Spec Stage 3 full-sprung 6-puck clutch -Fidanza Flywheel Since Joe's car was currently sitting at my friend Ricky's shop, so was the motor after it was pulled. One weekend I had some freetime, and figured I'd better start working on tearing everything down. So, I went to pick it up, and take the motor and tranny down to my house. Literally that following week, the thermostat on my KA got stuck, and while trying to limp my car home while overheating the headgasket gave out..:( It wasn't the best motor, and had its annoying times, but I had no major issues with it, and it had served me well since 2007! So, now without having a car and taking the train to work and I finally got going on things with the SR. First, I needed to go pickup an engine stand so I had something to work on. lol Next I got the motor all strapped up, and over to the stand. After getting all the turbo side stuff removed, it was time to clean things up a bit. Here's a quick before shot. aaand the after One things were all clean I started getting the turbo side pieced back together. Replacing the T28 turbo was this shiney guy. A brand new Garrett GTX2867r .64A/R. This turbo is essentially a middle step between Garrett's famous GT2871r and GT3076. The problem you're faced with these two turbo's, is you're forced to make a choice. go for low-end power, but quick spool and response. Or, deal with more turbo lag, and more top end power, but longer spool and response. While still being a bottom mounted T2 series turbo, it certain has its limitations, like interal wastebate, and maybe not making as much top end power as the T3 series. But, you'll be surprised when you see the numbers later on. :p To make sure I was getting the most out of this turbo, I contacted the guys over at DOC Race since they're relatively local, and seem to do great work! They offer a bottom mount style T2 series manifold that's hand made, but also an external wastegate flange! This will allow me to more reliably run higher levels of boost, without chances of leaks. Now, when converting internal wastegate over to internal, alot of people weld the flapper shut. But, if i'd like to sell this turbo in the future, that might be an issue. So, I did some searching and turns out they make a locker bracket for this type of things over at COBB Tuning for Subaru's. I don't have a Subaru, but a turbo is a turbo, regardless of the car its on. One thing however, is I never got a e-clip with this turbo since it was new, and I tried finding some different ones at Ace Hardware, but didn't have any luck. I did pick up some of these little metal clips, and they seem to be doing just fine after 3 months. Picked up this Copper style gasket I got everything bolted up to check clearances and lines The wastegate i'm running is a Tial MVS w/ v-band flanges One interesting piece I later found out, is According to Tial's website. This combination of Black and Red springs should equal 1bar(roughly 14.5psi). However, turns out for some reason, this is actually 1.37bar(20psi). haha I then got everything mocked up to make sure it would fit. I was originally a bit concerned with the dump pipe clearing the steering column, and would later make some small adjustments.   For exhaust related pieces, I decided to go with the Powered by MAX Cobra Downpipe. This makes the turbo elbow and downpipe all into one piece, while adding a flex section. The one thing I didn notice with this is you ABSOLUTELY must run the transmission bracket for the downpipe or else your exhaust is going to sag alo!   The buddy club exhaust sounded great(being able to hear my turbo through exhaust is the best sound in the world). but the fitment left a bit to be desired, and I needed something just a tad quieter since I still daily my car. So, I went back to the old trust Megan Racing Drift Spec that I had on my KA for about 5 years, this time in a 3" for the SR. Now on to some misc intake and exhaust related things. I picked up this Stance oversized water pump pulley since I know SR's are notorious for overheating. I also picked up this neat Mishimoto radiator cap that also has a temp guage in it, which has proved very userful. Also a HKS SSQV blowoff valve, which sounds great! Got the Greddy Type-LS front mount all mocked up. I have to say, comparing this to other kits such as CX racing and other off brand ones, paying the extra bit of money to have the fitment be dead on is totally worth it! haha The only thing I had to do with this kit was drill out the hole in the battery tray! I did have to remove my front bumper support. Since I don't have the proper tools to cut the USDM one, i'll either do it later, or try to pick up a JDM one. ;)Also, its worth noting, I had to trim a few plastic pieces off the back of the type-x bumper, but nothing too crazy. One thing that I really wanted to do was keep this car reliable. So, instead of fully building the head, I decided to just keep the internals stock, and upgradae the cams to Jim Wolf Technology S3HL cams. One thing I found helped out alot when doing this, was just zip tying the chain to the sprocket so my timing didn't get out of place. Then, to prevent the sprockets from falling down too far into the motor, I just put a socket extention down the hole to block things. Got everything apart, and inspecting stuff for any issues/wear Here you can see the lobe difference compared to stock which feature a 272 Duration, and an uncommon 11.5mm of lift. This will prevent me from being forced to the solid lifters like with most 12mm setups. Staying with the head side of things, one common issue I've seen alot of with S13 valve covers, is oil blowby. So, I decided to pick up this S13.4 valve cover. The front half is s13, the rest is s14 due to it having better oil baffles in the valve cover. To make things cleaner I picked up this Tomei spark plug cover, and also some other misc parts like heater core conversion hoses, since I daily this car and would like heat during the winter time. haha Lastly, I picked up this Radium Engineering catch can to filter out all the crap before it goes into my turbo. I'm not running it at the moment, since I still need to pickup some more AN fittings and line, but i'm looking forward to seeing how much it picks up. Now, lets move over to Fuel/Engine Mgmt! The harness I'm running is Chase Bays and to be honest, had less than stellar quality with them. I'll explain a bit later on that though. Here's one thing I noticed right off the bad. when installing my Power Enterprises 850cc injectors.   Here you can see the normal SR injector plug, with these offset slots. however... The injectors I got came with the slots even with each other. This is different compared to the old Nismo injectors I pulled, which were offset like the plug.   The fix I did for this was to just bust out a file, and grind down one side of the injector the following two directions. Once its ground down like this, the plug fits right on with no issues. I might throw some zipties or something around these though going forward. Since, after doing some doughnuts recently, I had one of my injectors pop off.   For Boost Levels and A/F's I'm running AEM Tru-Boost and AEM EUGO gauges. There's a few advantages to this. With the Tru-Boost gauge, it also doubles as a boost controller while providing a few options such as scramble boost(not using this quite yet, but might in the future), and over boost detection(kick down to wastegate pressure if it detects boost pressure getting too high). Also, the EUGO controller, allows me to run A/F data directly to the gauge, then from there send it to my ECU. Also, FYI I not running a MAF setup since its relatively old technology, and I figured its smarter and more reliable to go with a MAP setup. So I picked up an AEM 3bar MAP and IAT sensor. I ended up just running this dual-gauge pillar. However, I ran my wires a bit differently than most. Instead of cutting/drilling into my dash or pillar, I simply disconnected the plastic hose behind my cluster, and ran the wires up through the vent! To make life easier and add flexibility later down the road, I picked up a full standalone EMS series 2 ECU from AEM. I debated picking up haltech, but a majority of tuners in my area can do AEM. So, that was the difference maker, aside from the various plug-n-play sensors and gauges. One thing worth noting, is with the AEM ECU, you also need to run the CAS trigger wheel they supply with it.   At some point(this is 4 months afterwards) I made the call to start pulling the trusty old KA, and drop in the SR.     One thing I sort of forgot to do, was plug the back of the transmission..>< the result was a lake of tranny fluid all over my garage floor. haha I then got the front stuff of the motor wrapped up with the Stance pulley and GKtech fan for more colling. One thing I later found out, is once that nismo thermostat kicks open, its a bit difficult to get any heat in this thing. haha I'll report back how things are after some track days. but, so far for daily driving anyways, it takes quite a while to warm up, and is only at the first bar on the stock temp gauge. I'll probably pick up an aftermarket water and oil temp gauge shortly as well. For even more cooling, I picked up this Koyo radiator. With the KA out, I figure it was a good time to cleanup my engine bay. Sadly, it instantly got just as dirty right away, so that as a bit of a waste. I really need to plug the big holes near the firewall..:\ Here's the overall finished product!   For my battery I just ran this little Odyssey battery, and seems to be fine as long as I fire up the car once every other day. If it goes more than a full day, it will go dead. :p I threw in this bottle until I could get my intake piping for the turbo made. :p Once I had the SR in, I did notice a few clearance things. First off, the space for the wastegate is pretty cramped, but looks just barely clears. I rubbed it up against the firewall when I dropped the motor in, so that's what the mark is from. The other issue, is dealing with the dump pipe. Taking this thing on/off is seriously a huuuge pain, and I actually had to have the pipe angled down to a 45 degree angle, instead of a 90 for more clearance for the steering rack and because it was hitting up against the brake booster. My one gripe right now, is its not long enough, and could use another 45 degree bend at the end, and a straight section so it blows more towards the back end of the steering rack and not directly on it so much. After finally getting everything in and buttoned up, I seemed to have a pretty annoying issue. The car had fuel and compression while cranking over, but absolutely ZERO spark. I went through all the basics and was pulling my hair out. I was about to leave to japan in a matter of a few weeks, so I called up Alex over at Carb Connection to see if he could sort the car out for me while I was on vacation. luckily, he obliged, and I arranged for Yuki to get towed down to their shop. This post is already getting a bit long, so i'll continue things in part 2! :)

After getting all the turbo side stuff removed, it was time to clean things up a bit. Here's a quick before shot.

aaand the after

One things were all clean I started getting the turbo side pieced back together. Replacing the T28 turbo was this shiney guy. A brand new Garrett GTX2867r .64A/R. This turbo is essentially a middle step between Garrett's famous GT2871r and GT3076. The problem you're faced with these two turbo's, is you're forced to make a choice. go for low-end power, but quick spool and response. Or, deal with more turbo lag, and more top end power, but longer spool and response.

While still being a bottom mounted T2 series turbo, it certain has its limitations, like interal wastebate, and maybe not making as much top end power as the T3 series. But, you'll be surprised when you see the numbers later on. :p

To make sure I was getting the most out of this turbo, I contacted the guys over at DOC Race since they're relatively local, and seem to do great work! They offer a bottom mount style T2 series manifold that's hand made, but also an external wastegate flange! This will allow me to more reliably run higher levels of boost, without chances of leaks.


Now, when converting internal wastegate over to internal, alot of people weld the flapper shut. But, if i'd like to sell this turbo in the future, that might be an issue. So, I did some searching and turns out they make a locker bracket for this type of things over at COBB Tuning for Subaru's. I don't have a Subaru, but a turbo is a turbo, regardless of the car its on.

One thing however, is I never got a e-clip with this turbo since it was new, and I tried finding some different ones at Ace Hardware, but didn't have any luck. I did pick up some of these little metal clips, and they seem to be doing just fine after 3 months.

Picked up this Copper style gasket

I got everything bolted up to check clearances and lines

The wastegate i'm running is a Tial MVS w/ v-band flanges


One interesting piece I later found out, is According to Tial's website. This combination of Black and Red springs should equal 1bar(roughly 14.5psi). However, turns out for some reason, this is actually 1.37bar(20psi). haha

I then got everything mocked up to make sure it would fit. I was originally a bit concerned with the dump pipe clearing the steering column, and would later make some small adjustments.

 

For exhaust related pieces, I decided to go with the Powered by MAX Cobra Downpipe. This makes the turbo elbow and downpipe all into one piece, while adding a flex section. The one thing I didn notice with this is you ABSOLUTELY must run the transmission bracket for the downpipe or else your exhaust is going to sag alo!

 

The buddy club exhaust sounded great(being able to hear my turbo through exhaust is the best sound in the world). but the fitment left a bit to be desired, and I needed something just a tad quieter since I still daily my car. So, I went back to the old trust Megan Racing Drift Spec that I had on my KA for about 5 years, this time in a 3" for the SR.

Now on to some misc intake and exhaust related things. I picked up this Stance oversized water pump pulley since I know SR's are notorious for overheating. I also picked up this neat Mishimoto radiator cap that also has a temp guage in it, which has proved very userful. Also a HKS SSQV blowoff valve, which sounds great!
Got the Greddy Type-LS front mount all mocked up. I have to say, comparing this to other kits such as CX racing and other off brand ones, paying the extra bit of money to have the fitment be dead on is totally worth it! haha The only thing I had to do with this kit was drill out the hole in the battery tray!
I did have to remove my front bumper support. Since I don't have the proper tools to cut the USDM one, i'll either do it later, or try to pick up a JDM one. ;)Also, its worth noting, I had to trim a few plastic pieces off the back of the type-x bumper, but nothing too crazy.

One thing that I really wanted to do was keep this car reliable. So, instead of fully building the head, I decided to just keep the internals stock, and upgradae the cams to Jim Wolf Technology S3HL cams.

One thing I found helped out alot when doing this, was just zip tying the chain to the sprocket so my timing didn't get out of place. Then, to prevent the sprockets from falling down too far into the motor, I just put a socket extention down the hole to block things.

Got everything apart, and inspecting stuff for any issues/wear

Here you can see the lobe difference compared to stock which feature a 272 Duration, and an uncommon 11.5mm of lift. This will prevent me from being forced to the solid lifters like with most 12mm setups.

Staying with the head side of things, one common issue I've seen alot of with S13 valve covers, is oil blowby. So, I decided to pick up this S13.4 valve cover. The front half is s13, the rest is s14 due to it having better oil baffles in the valve cover.

To make things cleaner I picked up this Tomei spark plug cover, and also some other misc parts like heater core conversion hoses, since I daily this car and would like heat during the winter time. haha

Lastly, I picked up this Radium Engineering catch can to filter out all the crap before it goes into my turbo. I'm not running it at the moment, since I still need to pickup some more AN fittings and line, but i'm looking forward to seeing how much it picks up.

Now, lets move over to Fuel/Engine Mgmt! The harness I'm running is Chase Bays and to be honest, had less than stellar quality with them. I'll explain a bit later on that though.

Here's one thing I noticed right off the bad. when installing my Power Enterprises 850cc injectors.

 

Here you can see the normal SR injector plug, with these offset slots. however...

The injectors I got came with the slots even with each other. This is different compared to the old Nismo injectors I pulled, which were offset like the plug.

 

The fix I did for this was to just bust out a file, and grind down one side of the injector the following two directions.

Once its ground down like this, the plug fits right on with no issues. I might throw some zipties or something around these though going forward. Since, after doing some doughnuts recently, I had one of my injectors pop off.

 

For Boost Levels and A/F's I'm running AEM Tru-Boost and AEM EUGO gauges. There's a few advantages to this. With the Tru-Boost gauge, it also doubles as a boost controller while providing a few options such as scramble boost(not using this quite yet, but might in the future), and over boost detection(kick down to wastegate pressure if it detects boost pressure getting too high). Also, the EUGO controller, allows me to run A/F data directly to the gauge, then from there send it to my ECU. Also, FYI I not running a MAF setup since its relatively old technology, and I figured its smarter and more reliable to go with a MAP setup. So I picked up an AEM 3bar MAP and IAT sensor.

I ended up just running this dual-gauge pillar. However, I ran my wires a bit differently than most. Instead of cutting/drilling into my dash or pillar, I simply disconnected the plastic hose behind my cluster, and ran the wires up through the vent!

To make life easier and add flexibility later down the road, I picked up a full standalone EMS series 2 ECU from AEM. I debated picking up haltech, but a majority of tuners in my area can do AEM. So, that was the difference maker, aside from the various plug-n-play sensors and gauges.

One thing worth noting, is with the AEM ECU, you also need to run the CAS trigger wheel they supply with it.

 

At some point(this is 4 months afterwards) I made the call to start pulling the trusty old KA, and drop in the SR.

 

 

One thing I sort of forgot to do, was plug the back of the transmission..>< the result was a lake of tranny fluid all over my garage floor. haha

I then got the front stuff of the motor wrapped up with the Stance pulley and GKtech fan for more colling. One thing I later found out, is once that nismo thermostat kicks open, its a bit difficult to get any heat in this thing. haha I'll report back how things are after some track days. but, so far for daily driving anyways, it takes quite a while to warm up, and is only at the first bar on the stock temp gauge. I'll probably pick up an aftermarket water and oil temp gauge shortly as well.

For even more cooling, I picked up this Koyo radiator.

With the KA out, I figure it was a good time to cleanup my engine bay. Sadly, it instantly got just as dirty right away, so that as a bit of a waste. I really need to plug the big holes near the firewall..:\

Here's the overall finished product!

 

For my battery I just ran this little Odyssey battery, and seems to be fine as long as I fire up the car once every other day. If it goes more than a full day, it will go dead. :p

I threw in this bottle until I could get my intake piping for the turbo made. :p

Once I had the SR in, I did notice a few clearance things. First off, the space for the wastegate is pretty cramped, but looks just barely clears. I rubbed it up against the firewall when I dropped the motor in, so that's what the mark is from.

The other issue, is dealing with the dump pipe. Taking this thing on/off is seriously a huuuge pain, and I actually had to have the pipe angled down to a 45 degree angle, instead of a 90 for more clearance for the steering rack and because it was hitting up against the brake booster. My one gripe right now, is its not long enough, and could use another 45 degree bend at the end, and a straight section so it blows more towards the back end of the steering rack and not directly on it so much.

After finally getting everything in and buttoned up, I seemed to have a pretty annoying issue. The car had fuel and compression while cranking over, but absolutely ZERO spark. I went through all the basics and was pulling my hair out. I was about to leave to japan in a matter of a few weeks, so I called up Alex over at Carb Connection to see if he could sort the car out for me while I was on vacation. luckily, he obliged, and I arranged for Yuki to get towed down to their shop.

This post is already getting a bit long, so i'll continue things in part 2! :)

posts.title: Yuki: Boosted Goodness: Part 2
posts.markdown: Picking up from where I left off over in Part 1, The initial build of my SR was finished. But, I was running into some spark issues. After I came back from japan during the holidays, sadly they were still fighting the no spark issue over at Carb Connection. until things were working, I really was getting really annoyed not having any wheels, so I rented this sweet ride for most of the month of January 2014. The main issues ended up being two things. 1) the wiring for the chasebays harness was bad, and some of the CAS pins came out from the ecu plug. 2) the car then would run on only 3 cyclinders, but still had no spark on #4. After sending the ecu down to AEM, we later found that the ignition coil drivers was bad, and AEM swapped out the board. During this whole fiasco the Chase Bays support was very unimpressive IMO. They had really crappy phone reception wherever their office was located at, and when asking for some help after explaining my situation, they just blamed it on the ecu. Another issue i've ran into, that i'll take pictures on, is a few things: 1) my speed sensor plug is wayy too short, and will never reach back towards the speed sensor area of the tranny 2) their documentation on their site is out of date, and wasn't helpful when comparing it against the harness they sent me when I was trying to verify which plugs went where, and checking wiring things. 3) I still have no clue what the "proper" way to route this harness is. Currently, I have it going through the runners. Basically, above the lower intake manifold, but below the upper one. Part of the issues this causes, is I can't really hook up my Knock Sensor since its too short to go around the lower intake manifold. All that being said, I ended up running a combination of harnesses. A wiring specialties lower harness, which would connect up to all the tranny plugs, and run power to my alternator and starter. However, with the way the Chase Bays was designed, it eliminates the lower harness. So, I currently don't have any speed or reverse lights working..:\ I'll probably at some point swap out the chase bays harness for a Wiring Specialties one maybe. We'll see.. ANYWAYS, after sorting out all those issues and wierdness, we finally got the car running and up on the dyno! [video width="640" height="640" mp4="http://domofactor.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/yuki_dyno_idle.mp4"][/video] Once we finally got some heat into the thing, we put it through its paces, and maan this thing sounds great! There was some wierd spark breakup at high rpms, which we later found to be because the spring I had in my wastegate actually was 20psi. So, when setting the tru-boost levels, things went a bit wierd. Once we disabled the solenoid, and just went off of wastegate pressure, everything smoothed out. [video width="640" height="640" mp4="http://domofactor.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/yuki_carb_conn_dyno.mp4"][/video] Here's the numbers I ended up with. Initially I was pretty pleased, and these were about ballpark of what I was expecting. I'm not quite sure why it went really lean there around 4k rpm. Overall the car ran smooth, but it ate up gas like there was no tomorrow. I was filling up maybe every 3 days. Realizing this way wayy wrong, I took the car down to Bob over at Drift Office to see what he could do to try and lean the thing out. Not only did he lean it out and make things much smoother, I had more power, and a much better curve overall! He also let me know some issues I was having with my CAS, and threw in some new spark plugs to boot! With this setup, its alot better. I average about 40miles per day commuting to work, and fill up about once every 5-6 days. There's still a bit more tweaking that can probably be done to get more MPG's, but for running 370hp@20psi w/ 318 ft-lbs of torque, i'm not complaining. :p I later bugged Galen Callahan who's a friend of Ricky's to make up an intake tube for my turbo, and weld in an AN bung for when I throw in my catch can. He had done great with some some small work with my dump pipe and intake tubing which came out great, so I wanted to go back. Overall, I'm really happy with this setup, and so far its been very daily friendly. with this turbo setup, I basically have full spool on tap at 3k when i'm on the freeway, so as soon as I get on it in 5th gear, its right there on tap! I'll be heading out to take Yuki to her first drift event after dropping this new motor in. So, i'll report back later on how things go there!
posts.html:
Picking up from where I left off over in Part 1, The initial build of my SR was finished. But, I was running into some spark issues.

After I came back from japan during the holidays, sadly they were still fighting the no spark issue over at Carb Connection. until things were working, I really was getting really annoyed not having any wheels, so I rented this sweet ride for most of the month of January 2014.

The main issues ended up being two things.
1) the wiring for the chasebays harness was bad, and some of the CAS pins came out from the ecu plug.
2) the car then would run on only 3 cyclinders, but still had no spark on #4. After sending the ecu down to AEM, we later found that the ignition coil drivers was bad, and AEM swapped out the board.

During this whole fiasco the Chase Bays support was very unimpressive IMO. They had really crappy phone reception wherever their office was located at, and when asking for some help after explaining my situation, they just blamed it on the ecu. Another issue i've ran into, that i'll take pictures on, is a few things:

1) my speed sensor plug is wayy too short, and will never reach back towards the speed sensor area of the tranny
2) their documentation on their site is out of date, and wasn't helpful when comparing it against the harness they sent me when I was trying to verify which plugs went where, and checking wiring things.
3) I still have no clue what the "proper" way to route this harness is. Currently, I have it going through the runners. Basically, above the lower intake manifold, but below the upper one. Part of the issues this causes, is I can't really hook up my Knock Sensor since its too short to go around the lower intake manifold.

All that being said, I ended up running a combination of harnesses. A wiring specialties lower harness, which would connect up to all the tranny plugs, and run power to my alternator and starter. However, with the way the Chase Bays was designed, it eliminates the lower harness. So, I currently don't have any speed or reverse lights working..:\ I'll probably at some point swap out the chase bays harness for a Wiring Specialties one maybe. We'll see..

ANYWAYS, after sorting out all those issues and wierdness, we finally got the car running and up on the dyno!

[video width="640" height="640" mp4="http://domofactor.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/yukidynoidle.mp4"][/video]

Once we finally got some heat into the thing, we put it through its paces, and maan this thing sounds great! There was some wierd spark breakup at high rpms, which we later found to be because the spring I had in my wastegate actually was 20psi. So, when setting the tru-boost levels, things went a bit wierd. Once we disabled the solenoid, and just went off of wastegate pressure, everything smoothed out.

[video width="640" height="640" mp4="http://domofactor.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/yukicarbconn_dyno.mp4"][/video]

Here's the numbers I ended up with. Initially I was pretty pleased, and these were about ballpark of what I was expecting. I'm not quite sure why it went really lean there around 4k rpm.

Overall the car ran smooth, but it ate up gas like there was no tomorrow. I was filling up maybe every 3 days. Realizing this way wayy wrong, I took the car down to Bob over at Drift Office to see what he could do to try and lean the thing out.

Not only did he lean it out and make things much smoother, I had more power, and a much better curve overall! He also let me know some issues I was having with my CAS, and threw in some new spark plugs to boot!

With this setup, its alot better. I average about 40miles per day commuting to work, and fill up about once every 5-6 days. There's still a bit more tweaking that can probably be done to get more MPG's, but for running 370hp@20psi w/ 318 ft-lbs of torque, i'm not complaining. :p

I later bugged Galen Callahan who's a friend of Ricky's to make up an intake tube for my turbo, and weld in an AN bung for when I throw in my catch can. He had done great with some some small work with my dump pipe and intake tubing which came out great, so I wanted to go back.

Overall, I'm really happy with this setup, and so far its been very daily friendly. with this turbo setup, I basically have full spool on tap at 3k when i'm on the freeway, so as soon as I get on it in 5th gear, its right there on tap! I'll be heading out to take Yuki to her first drift event after dropping this new motor in. So, i'll report back later on how things go there!

posts.title: Japan Trip Winter 2013: Part 3(Shizuoka)
posts.markdown: So, kicking things back off was my venture down south of Tokyo. First stop was Shizuoka! I'm gonna do this a bit backwards, and show you my last day first, and then the first day last. There's a reason for this, which you'll see later. :p First off, I picked up this AMAZING strawberry break thing before heading to the train station Then it was onto the bullet train to make my way down to Shizuoka! I still get kind of freaked out when these things go through the stations and don't stop. For obvious reasons, its not at full speed, but they're still moving pretty damn fast. lol fast forward, and my buddy Ken and his wife Satomi were visiting Satomi's family in Shizuoka for the holidays and invited me out to cruise up in the mountains. So, I hopped on a local train about 10 minutes north to this tiny station to meetup with them. The weather didn't look that great, and I thought it was going to rain, but luckily it didnt. Before heading into the mountains, we stopped off to get some Udon for lunch. Then after driving for about 30min-1hour before coming across this crazy suspension bridge. The views were actually awesome, but man that bridge was sketchy as hell.   You can see just exactly how wide this thing was, and there were quite a bit of planks that were rotting away or had holes in them. lol we finally managed to get across without dying.. then, decided to do some exploring Of course being Shizuoka, there were tons of tea leaves everywhere  But also some really great views. On the way back this girl was wearing heels and a short dress thingy..I'm not complaining but wasn't the best of choices. :p I actually got honked at when I took this as there was a train behind me. :p haha Heading back down towards town, I started to get carsick, so we stopped at a rest area and swapped places so I could drive. At the rest area, there was this super wierd toll-ish thingy. Okay, now that we got the ending part of shizuoka over, lets rewind to the beginning. Everytime I go there, its to meetup with Hideki who helps his dad run Garage Miura which specializes in AE86's, Mini's, Daihatsu's and tons of other small/kei cars. I metup with him and his sister Yukako at Sawayaka who later introduced me to their friend Yuya and his wife(whos name I cant remember). The Hamburger there never dissappoints, and I can't wait to go back again this year in 2014! ^_^ oh, they give you those paper "shields" to prevent the grease from splashing on you. lol After dinner Hideki had to head up to the shop to prepare for a race in Tsukuba  in a couple days. On the way, we stopped off at a gift shop, and there was a group of these awesome Soarers chilling outside. Back at Hachi Roku HQ, I started taking more pics. Even though this is my 3rd time, I still have an awesome time visiting there. Yuya also gave me some....unusual chocolate. haha There's always interesting stuff laying around. Such as this cool 4AG Supercharger which I assume is off of an AW-11 motor. Or these kouki lips I also spotted this super old school Apexi AFC device. I forget what car it came off of, but apparently the thing still works from what Hideki tells me. That same blue levin is still sitting there...hopefully somebody buys it eventually..;) haha up above that is Hideki's dad's car, which is super clean I was even surprised with the underbody. He recently put a wing on his own 86 to get better downforce at Tsukuba. But, opposite to how I feel, his somewhat dislikes 86's with wings. So, after the tsukuba event, its coming off. haha Towards the back there's a nice collection of exhausts hanging around. Back towards the front you can see all the goodies lining the walls. I still wonder sometimes how the heck they got that red car in there. lol  The next morning we were heading off for Fuji Speedway to go watch Hideki's friend do some drifting! So, i'll cover that in a separate post! posts.title: Japan Trip Winter 2013: Part 3.5(Fuji Speedway)
posts.markdown: So, while I was in Shizuoka, Hideki invited me out to a drift day happening over at Fuji Speedway. He wasn't driving since he had an event at Tsukuba the following day, but one of his friends was. So, I tagged along for a ride. The morning started off pretty early with Hideki stopping by the hotel to come pick me up. After that it was off to grab some food before heading up to Fuji Speedway. This place called Smile(スマイル) apparently is pretty famous, and is only found here in shizuoka. You can get Udon, Onigiri and Coffee for only ￥３００($3.00USD)!  After breakfast it was off to Fuji! When we first got there, I was pretty surprised at just how many 4-doors there were. Apparently this trend has been getting popular lately in Japan, but since our 4door cars in the US are crap, its not quite the go-to option for drifting. More chaser goodness A bit farther down, this pinked out s14 was driven by a girl of course. lol We later caught up with Hideki's friend Kodai driving this white AE86. I'll post video I took down towards the bottom of the page. Also another one of their friends was driving this blue silvia. This 86 was also killing it all day which I later found out was one of the Run-Free guys! After the morning session, we headed over back towards the main circuit area to get some food. Kodai looks indecisive since pretty much everything at these little shacks tastes awesome and its not very expensive either! I ended up eating a crepe and some curry rice. To everyone's surprise, the crepe was first. :p Hideki couldn't resist taking some shots to post up over on his Minkara Blog. Talk about having a professional cameraman pose! :p I decided it was my turn to try taking some fancy pictures. I think they came out looking okay. After lunch it was back to the pit area to do some more scouting. Hideki later intoduced me to the guy putting on the event for day, Koichi Urushibara. he's was super nice and we talked about all sorts of things about the US and Japan. When I told him, he could easily sell that car for around 12k in the US, he was pretty surprised. haha His car was running great, and I got quite a surprise when he popped the hood... Vmount, and lots of other goodies that I don't see most SR's in japan with! I wish my engine bay was this clean. T_T You can actually catch more info of his car featured in the Febuary issue of Drift Tengoku! Once things started wrapping up for the day, shenanigans ensued. Talk about Inception setting in. haha A little prior to this, Yuya and his wife had came up from Shizuoka to watch, and also give me a ride back to shizuoka! haha I was able to snap a proper group shot finally. lol This guy threw a peace sign for the camera as he was leaving, but I fail and missed it..>< Fuji Speedway is always tons of fun and I can't wait to go back! Since Hideki was off to Tsukuba after this, we all headed out to get dinner before parting. We went to this Family Resteraunt called COCO's. Overall the food was great. Although the portion size on this spaghetting left alot of be desired..:( Luckily this pizza was really good! haha [gallery columns="4" ids="10996,10995,10994,10993,10992,10991,10990,10989,10988,10987,11037,11035,11034,11038,11033,11032,11031,11030,11029,11028,11027,11039,11040,11026,11025,11024,11023,11022,11021,11041,11020,11019,11018,11017,11016,11015,11014,11013,11012,11011,11010,11009,11008,11007,11006,11005,11004,11003,11002,11001,11000,10999,10998,10997"] Overall even though I didn't drive it was great to watch and interact with everyone there. The next day, I left Shizuoka and headed for Osaka to hangout with friends down in the Kansai area! I'll be covering that in the next post, so stay tuned!
posts.html:
So, while I was in Shizuoka, Hideki invited me out to a drift day happening over at Fuji Speedway. He wasn't driving since he had an event at Tsukuba the following day, but one of his friends was. So, I tagged along for a ride.

The morning started off pretty early with Hideki stopping by the hotel to come pick me up.

After that it was off to grab some food before heading up to Fuji Speedway. This place called Smile(スマイル) apparently is pretty famous, and is only found here in shizuoka. You can get Udon, Onigiri and Coffee for only ￥３００($3.00USD)! 

After breakfast it was off to Fuji!

When we first got there, I was pretty surprised at just how many 4-doors there were. Apparently this trend has been getting popular lately in Japan, but since our 4door cars in the US are crap, its not quite the go-to option for drifting.

More chaser goodness

A bit farther down, this pinked out s14 was driven by a girl of course. lol

We later caught up with Hideki's friend Kodai driving this white AE86. I'll post video I took down towards the bottom of the page.

Also another one of their friends was driving this blue silvia.

This 86 was also killing it all day which I later found out was one of the Run-Free guys!

After the morning session, we headed over back towards the main circuit area to get some food. Kodai looks indecisive since pretty much everything at these little shacks tastes awesome and its not very expensive either! I ended up eating a crepe and some curry rice. To everyone's surprise, the crepe was first. :p

Hideki couldn't resist taking some shots to post up over on his Minkara Blog.

Talk about having a professional cameraman pose! :p

I decided it was my turn to try taking some fancy pictures. I think they came out looking okay.

After lunch it was back to the pit area to do some more scouting.

Hideki later intoduced me to the guy putting on the event for day, Koichi Urushibara. he's was super nice and we talked about all sorts of things about the US and Japan. When I told him, he could easily sell that car for around 12k in the US, he was pretty surprised. haha His car was running great, and I got quite a surprise when he popped the hood...

Vmount, and lots of other goodies that I don't see most SR's in japan with! I wish my engine bay was this clean. T_T

You can actually catch more info of his car featured in the Febuary issue of Drift Tengoku!

Once things started wrapping up for the day, shenanigans ensued. Talk about Inception setting in. haha

A little prior to this, Yuya and his wife had came up from Shizuoka to watch, and also give me a ride back to shizuoka! haha

I was able to snap a proper group shot finally. lol

This guy threw a peace sign for the camera as he was leaving, but I fail and missed it..><

Fuji Speedway is always tons of fun and I can't wait to go back! Since Hideki was off to Tsukuba after this, we all headed out to get dinner before parting.

We went to this Family Resteraunt called COCO's. Overall the food was great.

Although the portion size on this spaghetting left alot of be desired..:(

Luckily this pizza was really good! haha

[gallery columns="4" ids="10996,10995,10994,10993,10992,10991,10990,10989,10988,10987,11037,11035,11034,11038,11033,11032,11031,11030,11029,11028,11027,11039,11040,11026,11025,11024,11023,11022,11021,11041,11020,11019,11018,11017,11016,11015,11014,11013,11012,11011,11010,11009,11008,11007,11006,11005,11004,11003,11002,11001,11000,10999,10998,10997"]

Overall even though I didn't drive it was great to watch and interact with everyone there. The next day, I left Shizuoka and headed for Osaka to hangout with friends down in the Kansai area! I'll be covering that in the next post, so stay tuned!

posts.title: Japan Trip Winter 2013: Part 4(Kansai)
posts.markdown: So, here's my second to last post of my winter japan trip. Just a heads up, once this series is over, you'll be seeing some big changes on the site. :p anyways, on to the next stop which is the Kansai region! First things first, I grabbed my ticket and headed over to Kakegawa station to take the shinkansen to Osaka station. From there I metup with my friend Satoko who was nice enough to let me stay at her place while in Kansai for a bit. My first plans while in Osaka was to play some basketball with my friend Koju. However, I completely forgot to bring my basketball shoes with me on the trip..>< While on the hunt for some new shoes, I ran into this wierd spaceship looking thingy. lol Also spotted this white GT-R way in the back, although I was a bit late snapping the picture. lol Finally, after search I found this tiny little shop called Dope Hoop near Namba! I ended getting a great deal on These Jordan Melo's. Just let it be known that most regular places don't sell shoes over size 28(US 10) in japan. The next day I metup with Koju and got my ball skills(or lackthereof) on! I can't wait to go back and play again. Although, even though I was the tallest person there, everyone was disappointed I couldn't dunk. lol Staying on the same subject, I saw this sign over at Tennoji Station in Osaka, and was a bit confused at first. I later realized its just the name of some stores. haha The following day, I headed over to Nara to meet my friend Eriko, who's mom runs a small cafe! The food was awesome and I'm looking forward to going back there to visit.(ignore my massive finger in the picture) Another thing I didn't know, is that Eriko's mom(Etsuko) also holds ukulele workshops once in a while there at the cafe. So, I put my rusty playing skills to the test for a bit. We took a short drive over to Nara park to go checkout the crazy deer they have there. Here's some video of us getting attacked by the deer. lol You can buy Senbei(crackers) at the entrance, and feed them to the deer as you go deeper into the park. Just be careful, they eat ANYTHING. I jokingly offered one deer my phone to eat, and he didn't hesitate in trying to chew on it. lol After being harassed by the deer, I was able to snap some pics before escaping. After going back to Osaka, I met with my friend Yuna for some Katsudon. she normally lives in Finland, but came back home for the holidays. The last time I saw her was like 3 or 4 years ago back in seattle. lol I had nothing planned the following day, so she invited me to come hang out at the mall and join her family for dinner. when I went to go check out the gamecenter there, I was blown away by this kid playing the Taiko Master game. Dude was playing with invisible notes!! 0_o Also, Sonic decided to make a guest appearance. lol We then later went to this place for dinner.(I don't remember the name at all). haha I had an awesome time meeting her family, and everyone was really fun to talk to. One highlight of the night, was when her grandma kept asking to get hooked up with my dad. >< The next morning, I set out to do some exploring since I finally had some downtime. One thing that can get very confusing, is the multiple exists at trainstations. This happens to be simple since its a small one. But, in some of the bigger ones, you have multiple numbered exits for West, East, South, and North exits. I hopped on the train over to Q's mall near Tennoji Station to see what was going on.  The weather was great, but I wasn't able to find anything interesting really.. Spotted this cool Subie Forester with some PIA rack lights And this classic Toyota Celica I then decided to walk down along the street since I saw there was some park/zoo thing off in the distance to the left. It kind of amazes me how japan is able to keep these railways so clean and well maintained. We just have one in seattle, and its ALWAYS dirty. lol Making my way....over that way. lol Once I got there, this wierd pigeon was marching around like he was in the military. so...I snapped a quick shot. lol One thing I do like about japan in general, is how much awesome architecture there is, and how it blends old with new stuff. Like this clock, with an older castle in the background.   This zoo/park thingy was wierd. You had to pay to go inside...but it was all fake animals. haha I guess that's one way to keep cost down *shrugs*   I snapped some more shots of builders while making my way back.   Sometimes I got vertigo just looking UP at them. lol   One of the few times I ate mcdonalds over in japan. The french fries tasted a bit less salty, but other than that...things were pretty much the same for the mcdouble and the quarter pounder. lol   After dinner, I headed out to get some night shots and enjoy the scenery. It wasn't a very clear night, so I had a difficult time shooting stuff up at this lookout area.   I really need to work on my night photography..:\   The next day, I headed up to Kyoto to meetup with my friend Yukari and grab some dinner at this little Izakaya place. I forget all of what I ate, but this sashimi was bomb! On the way back, I made a quick pitstop to say hi to my friend Akane while she was working her part-time job at this english pub. There was actually alot of foreigners in there, so I guess that's where they all hang out at. :p Well, that's about it for Kansai! There's a pretty popular and hilarious show called Gaki no Tsukai that has a 6 Hour special every year around near years. I got lucky and was able to watch it live this year! :p   The next and last stop will be in Gunma! So, stay tuned!

First things first, I grabbed my ticket and headed over to Kakegawa station to take the shinkansen to Osaka station.

From there I metup with my friend Satoko who was nice enough to let me stay at her place while in Kansai for a bit.

My first plans while in Osaka was to play some basketball with my friend Koju. However, I completely forgot to bring my basketball shoes with me on the trip..>< While on the hunt for some new shoes, I ran into this wierd spaceship looking thingy. lol

Also spotted this white GT-R way in the back, although I was a bit late snapping the picture. lol

Finally, after search I found this tiny little shop called Dope Hoop near Namba!

I ended getting a great deal on These Jordan Melo's. Just let it be known that most regular places don't sell shoes over size 28(US 10) in japan.

The next day I metup with Koju and got my ball skills(or lackthereof) on! I can't wait to go back and play again. Although, even though I was the tallest person there, everyone was disappointed I couldn't dunk. lol

Staying on the same subject, I saw this sign over at Tennoji Station in Osaka, and was a bit confused at first. I later realized its just the name of some stores. haha

The following day, I headed over to Nara to meet my friend Eriko, who's mom runs a small cafe! The food was awesome and I'm looking forward to going back there to visit.(ignore my massive finger in the picture)

Another thing I didn't know, is that Eriko's mom(Etsuko) also holds ukulele workshops once in a while there at the cafe. So, I put my rusty playing skills to the test for a bit.

We took a short drive over to Nara park to go checkout the crazy deer they have there.

Here's some video of us getting attacked by the deer. lol You can buy Senbei(crackers) at the entrance, and feed them to the deer as you go deeper into the park. Just be careful, they eat ANYTHING. I jokingly offered one deer my phone to eat, and he didn't hesitate in trying to chew on it. lol

After being harassed by the deer, I was able to snap some pics before escaping.


After going back to Osaka, I met with my friend Yuna for some Katsudon. she normally lives in Finland, but came back home for the holidays. The last time I saw her was like 3 or 4 years ago back in seattle. lol


I had nothing planned the following day, so she invited me to come hang out at the mall and join her family for dinner. when I went to go check out the gamecenter there, I was blown away by this kid playing the Taiko Master game.

Dude was playing with invisible notes!! 0_o

Also, Sonic decided to make a guest appearance. lol

We then later went to this place for dinner.(I don't remember the name at all). haha I had an awesome time meeting her family, and everyone was really fun to talk to. One highlight of the night, was when her grandma kept asking to get hooked up with my dad. ><

The next morning, I set out to do some exploring since I finally had some downtime.

One thing that can get very confusing, is the multiple exists at trainstations. This happens to be simple since its a small one. But, in some of the bigger ones, you have multiple numbered exits for West, East, South, and North exits.

I hopped on the train over to Q's mall near Tennoji Station to see what was going on. 

The weather was great, but I wasn't able to find anything interesting really..

Spotted this cool Subie Forester with some PIA rack lights

And this classic Toyota Celica

I then decided to walk down along the street since I saw there was some park/zoo thing off in the distance to the left.

It kind of amazes me how japan is able to keep these railways so clean and well maintained. We just have one in seattle, and its ALWAYS dirty. lol

Making my way....over that way. lol

Once I got there, this wierd pigeon was marching around like he was in the military. so...I snapped a quick shot. lol

One thing I do like about japan in general, is how much awesome architecture there is, and how it blends old with new stuff. Like this clock, with an older castle in the background.

 

This zoo/park thingy was wierd. You had to pay to go inside...but it was all fake animals. haha I guess that's one way to keep cost down shrugs

 

I snapped some more shots of builders while making my way back.

 

Sometimes I got vertigo just looking UP at them. lol

 

One of the few times I ate mcdonalds over in japan. The french fries tasted a bit less salty, but other than that...things were pretty much the same for the mcdouble and the quarter pounder. lol

 

After dinner, I headed out to get some night shots and enjoy the scenery.

It wasn't a very clear night, so I had a difficult time shooting stuff up at this lookout area.

 

I really need to work on my night photography..:\

 

The next day, I headed up to Kyoto to meetup with my friend Yukari and grab some dinner at this little Izakaya place.

I forget all of what I ate, but this sashimi was bomb!

On the way back, I made a quick pitstop to say hi to my friend Akane while she was working her part-time job at this english pub. There was actually alot of foreigners in there, so I guess that's where they all hang out at. :p

Well, that's about it for Kansai! There's a pretty popular and hilarious show called Gaki no Tsukai that has a 6 Hour special every year around near years. I got lucky and was able to watch it live this year! :p

 

The next and last stop will be in Gunma! So, stay tuned!

posts.title: Japan Trip Winter 2013: Part 5(Gunma)
posts.markdown: hey guys, Here's the final part of my Winter 2013 Japan trip! Enjoy! I took the long train ride from Osaka all the way up to Maebashi in Gunma and metup once again with my good friend Eichi who runs the Gunma chapter of Garage Re-Sanai. He surprised me with a new car he picked up which was sporting a very nice wing. :p After heading back to drop off my things, and relax a bit, we went over to see our friend Yuya for dinner who runs a local Ramen Shop I've covered before called Menya Gekkou(麺屋月虹) To be honest I don't even remember what I ordered since its now 6 months after the fact. But, I do remember it being awesome! The next day for lunch I ate...yep, ramen! This place was within walking distance from Eichi's place. There were surprisingly a decent number of people there for it to have been morning. haha After lunch, we realized this was my 3rd time in japan and I still haven't been to an onsen. So, we headed up into the hills to this place that was maybe 15min away. If you have time, I totally reccomend checking one out. Feels great on a cold winter day! ^_^ After the Onsen, we stopped by Okada's pudding/cake shop Crayon.  As always, everything tasted AMAZING. I keep trying to confince him to open up a Seattle branch, but no luck so far. :p Okada-san had some time after work, so he joined us for some all-you-can-eat ShabuShabu. The next morning, Eichii invited me to go with him down to Tokyo with his co-workers for New Years stuff over at the temple. I stopped this super clean R33 on the way heading out of Gunma. One thing I finally realized, its a pain to find street parking in tokyo with lowered cars. Those big green blocks that you park on are pretty annoying. lol Turns out, there's a TON of people that like going to temples around this time of the year. haha Apparently, i'm supposed to have a really good year, and got the best out of all the fortunes which is DaiKichi(大吉). So far (Beginning of May), Things are going well. we'll see how the rest of the year goes. lol Afterwards everyone went to get lunch at this awesome Hot Pot place.  Getting gas on the way back to Gunma. roughly $74 bucks for 12 gallons of 100 octane gas! ouch! >< Once back in Gunma we metup with Eichii's friend Hideki to get ramen again. :p hopefully you see a trend here. haha Hideki also owns an FD and was nice enough to let my take it for a spin! Before this, I had never driven a Turbo car before. So, it made me look forward to having my SR running even more! lol The next and last day of my stay we headed up so I could do some shopping. Picked up a Baby Metal CD I was having some trouble finding back in Seattle! Afterwards we still had a bunch of time to kill so Eichii remembered there was a car museum not too far away called the Yokota Car & Doll Museum. ohhh man, was I in for a surprise. lol I'm getting lazy, so i'm just post up everything below. There were a TON of awesome cars here and old school stuff. but the thing that most caught my eye was the small Initial D section they setup. The actual Tofu store was torn down a few years ago. So, its nice to see this small corner dedicated to it. lol After the museum it was time to head down to the airport and catch my flight back to seattle..:( I'll be taking another trip towards the end of may. But, I'm not sure how much of it i'll document this time. These things are getting time consuming...or i'm getting lazier...or both! haha
posts.html:
hey guys,

Here's the final part of my Winter 2013 Japan trip! Enjoy!

I took the long train ride from Osaka all the way up to Maebashi in Gunma and metup once again with my good friend Eichi who runs the Gunma chapter of Garage Re-Sanai. He surprised me with a new car he picked up which was sporting a very nice wing. :p

After heading back to drop off my things, and relax a bit, we went over to see our friend Yuya for dinner who runs a local Ramen Shop I've covered before called Menya Gekkou(麺屋月虹)

To be honest I don't even remember what I ordered since its now 6 months after the fact. But, I do remember it being awesome!

The next day for lunch I ate...yep, ramen! This place was within walking distance from Eichi's place.

There were surprisingly a decent number of people there for it to have been morning. haha

After lunch, we realized this was my 3rd time in japan and I still haven't been to an onsen. So, we headed up into the hills to this place that was maybe 15min away. If you have time, I totally reccomend checking one out. Feels great on a cold winter day! ^_^

After the Onsen, we stopped by Okada's pudding/cake shop Crayon. 

As always, everything tasted AMAZING. I keep trying to confince him to open up a Seattle branch, but no luck so far. :p

Okada-san had some time after work, so he joined us for some all-you-can-eat ShabuShabu.

The next morning, Eichii invited me to go with him down to Tokyo with his co-workers for New Years stuff over at the temple. I stopped this super clean R33 on the way heading out of Gunma.

One thing I finally realized, its a pain to find street parking in tokyo with lowered cars. Those big green blocks that you park on are pretty annoying. lol

Turns out, there's a TON of people that like going to temples around this time of the year. haha

Apparently, i'm supposed to have a really good year, and got the best out of all the fortunes which is DaiKichi(大吉). So far (Beginning of May), Things are going well. we'll see how the rest of the year goes. lol

Afterwards everyone went to get lunch at this awesome Hot Pot place. 

Getting gas on the way back to Gunma. roughly $74 bucks for 12 gallons of 100 octane gas! ouch! ><

Once back in Gunma we metup with Eichii's friend Hideki to get ramen again. :p hopefully you see a trend here. haha

Hideki also owns an FD and was nice enough to let my take it for a spin! Before this, I had never driven a Turbo car before. So, it made me look forward to having my SR running even more! lol

The next and last day of my stay we headed up so I could do some shopping.

Picked up a Baby Metal CD I was having some trouble finding back in Seattle!

Afterwards we still had a bunch of time to kill so Eichii remembered there was a car museum not too far away called the Yokota Car & Doll Museum. ohhh man, was I in for a surprise. lol

I'm getting lazy, so i'm just post up everything below. There were a TON of awesome cars here and old school stuff. but the thing that most caught my eye was the small Initial D section they setup. The actual Tofu store was torn down a few years ago. So, its nice to see this small corner dedicated to it. lol

After the museum it was time to head down to the airport and catch my flight back to seattle..:( I'll be taking another trip towards the end of may. But, I'm not sure how much of it i'll document this time. These things are getting time consuming...or i'm getting lazier...or both! haha

posts.title: Yuki: Maiden Voyage
posts.markdown:
hey guys! well, I can finally say Yuki is finally home safe and sound after taking her on the maiden voyage from my friend’s shop back to my house^_^ I've been driving her around and to work the past couple days and this car is amazing! it's totally different than anything I've ever driven before!! I plan on still tidying up a few things, and finishing up a few pieces with the car before looking into more upgrades to buy like a 4 point harness. lol

As of right now she's still missing the front end caps, side skirts, and rear valences since the painter kinda failed on them and they need to be touched up just a bit. I also have the carbon kevlar center garnish trim but I haven’t gotten around to putting it on yet. lol Well, Here's just some pics I snapped with my camera phone the other day. My normal camera broke, so eventually I'm just going to buy a DSLR. lol I’m going to try and get some proper pics sometime next week.

These Raybrig housings + Polarg Shining Wizard bulbs are amazing! I can’t wait to get legit photos so you guys can see how awesome the color is.>_<

Who needs ABS when you have Haruhi’s Willpower!

Rabrig race queen air freshener, and yuki mascots.^_^

posts.title: Yuki: Purple Rain!
posts.markdown:
hey everyone! more updates on Yuki. lol I’m pushing to get her finished by next weekend! I went down a few days ago and finally bought the paint for her. The paint is Nissan paint code LP2. Which is called Midnight Purple, Cabernet, or Deep Metallic Purple depending on where you live at. lol this paint came on the R33 Nissan Skyline, Sentra, and 300zx. well, anyways tell me what you guys think. The purple has a blue pearl in it to give it that color shift depending on how the light hits it. However, it’s a pretty dark purple. at night it’ll look black pretty much, then depending on how the sun hits it. It will look purple with a slight tint of blue.

 

I also picked up a set of wheels they’re Work CR-KAI replica’s in 17x9 +15 offset, and did some slight fender rolling for fitment^_^

This is where the wheel should sit at fully compressed. lol I would rock it this way all the time, but since my car is a daily driver. I dunno if I’d be able to pull it off with 17’s. haha

This is where the car should sit for ride height, and daily driving.

checking what little clearance there is. haha

managed to get it in there juuuust right

 

Other than that, I resanded the whole car in some finer grit sand paper, scuffed the engine bay and door jams, and also sanded my type-x pieces. Everything should be good to go, and hopefully I’ll have her in the booth at some point next week^_^ It’ll be a mad push for the Golden Gardens/ XXX Drive-in meet on the 27th, so we’ll see what happens. lol jya na!

posts.title: Japan Trip: Day 1 (Wandering, Yakiniku, and Parfaits)
posts.markdown: Day 1 of my japan trip is under wraps! Check out the jump below for all the goodies! ^_^ *Note: 56k dial-up users BEWARE! There's alot of pics. haha Overall the trip started fine, got to the airport in Seattle with plenty of time to spare. It was funny though that in both Seattle, and LAX, TSA people couldn't figure out what the hell my helmet+camera gear bag was. lol LAX was especially funny since my camera badgcombined with the camera mount in the next pouch almost looked like a gun in the scanner. >_< haha After possibly the worst and most grueling flight EVAR in my life(16 total hours), I arrived to jdm land at last! overall the fact that I was in tokyo didn't quite hit me until a bit later since at the time above it was 5:30am and the airport was pretty dead. Sadly, I had to sit around and wait for that Softbank Place to open at 0630 so I could get my japanese sim card + phone number. It's worth noting that I ran into Super GT300 Driver Mitsuhiro Kinoshita(Also driver of the WTAC Hankook FD3S). When I asked him if he was Kinoshita-san from Rev Speed and the Hankook FD3S he just replied with "Sorry, no English." so...yeah that was a little disheartening. Since either he was a DEAD look alike, or it had to be him. haha After picking up my sim card, and exchanging my cash money into Yen(stupid exchange rates..T_T) it was time to figure out how to hell I was going to get to my hotel.  I knew roughly that I had to get to Hamamatsu-cho, and then hop on the JR Yamanote line to get to Meguro which is where my hotel is at.After talking to this lady at the information booth, she said I needed to take the Monorail to get to me to Hamamatsu-cho. Luckily almost all of the signs had english,hiragana, and kanji written on them. So, I at least had a 2/3 chance of being able to read it and figure out where I needed to go. lol By this point, I managed to succefully take my first public method of transport into the heart of tokyo. The monorail was pretty dead since it was super early on a sunday morning. But, I was curious when I switched over to the JR Yamanote Line how busy and difficult it would be. Turns out, transferring and using the JR railway overall is a breeze! The ticketing system confused the hell out of me at first, but after the first couple times it made sense.(I totally forgot to get a picture of the ticket machine, so I'll do that tomorrow :p). Anyways, as you can see.....it was pretty dead early in the morning. lol I managed to brave the worst of my fears so far, and got off at the correct stop. Then, I sort of had to judge where certain streets where based off what I remembered looking at from google maps. My phone has data disabled(cuz its hella expensive), so I didn't have any maps to tell me exactly where the hotel was. Here's an super clean Subaru WRX(GC8) that I saw on the way to the hotel. There was also a super sexy white Ferrari F40 that went flying by, but I couldn't pull out my phone in time!! >_< I'm staying at the Hotel Mid in Meguro from a recommendation from ken whos been there many times. ^_^ One thing that was kind of annoying is when I walked in, they said check-in time was 3pm. It was 8am at the time, and I had just flown for 16 hours. So, needless to say I was pretty annoyed. They grabbed a few of my bags to be put on hold, and I set off to do some exploring to kill time. A wider view from outside the hotel. This is the main road coming from the train station. Another shot of the same road going away from the train station. The left side there is lined with some awesome places to eat from the looks of it. So, it'll be fun to go try some. More notably there's a 7-11, Chinese restaurant, and English Pub. So, those ones I'll for sure go to in the coming days. lol Here's something I didn't expect to see here. lol LHD Dodge Magnum w/ some DUB's. I felt a few blisters starting to develop from walking, and was getting tired of the humidity and mild heat(80). It's weird because the humidity here feels different. According to google, the percentage is about the same between here and seattle. but, here it just feels....heavier or something..idk hard to explain really. lol Anyways, I grabbed a drink from the vending machine outside(80Yen), went back to the hotel lounge, and popped in my Hot Version DVD to kill the 2 more hours I had left.(I forgot to get a picture of the vending machine too, so I'll do that tomorrow.) Random side note, this hotel only had one person that spoke conversational english when I showed up earlier. Luckily, I understand japanese better than speaking it because that one person who knew english took off while I was waiting for check in time. So, the girl came around the corner at noon letting me know my room was ready, and needed to go over a few things with me. Apparently, like the trains, everything gets shutdown at midnight here. So, she was telling me that to get into the elevator area I needed to also use my key card if its between 12-6. Overall the staff here are super helpfull, and she even complimented me on my Dragon Ball Z t-shirt. ^_^ finally.....A BED!!!! The bathroom is pretty cool. It was a recessed floor. So, if you spill water all over the place, it just goes to the drain there under the sink. another thing I liked is they provided bodywash+shampoo in the dispencer thingys. I forgot mine at home, so this was awesome. lol Also, that toilet scared the bejesus out of me. It was one of those built in bidet/butt washer things along with a seat warmer. All of these seemed pretty creepy, and I luckily figured out how to disable them all. lol I like my toilets how I like my revenge. COLD! I finally managed to get all my crap sorted out luggage wise, and hop online to send out my "I'm still alive emails". Shortly after that one of my previous co-workers who was now living in tokyo gave me a call saying he had church in shibuya(2 stops away from me) from 1-4pm and wanted to meetup for dinner. My eyes were pretty bloodshot from not getting ANY sleep on the flight over here, so I told him to give me a call once his church stuff got out. This enabled me to at least get a few hours of naptime in, before heading out again. One thing I still wasn't sure about fully, was buying train tickets. For my monorail I just chose the monorail+JR Yamanote line button for 500Yen. This time, however there was no button for which specific stop I wanted to go to. There were only faires along with some other misc options. Not realizing there's a chart right effing above my head showing what fares to use to get to a specific station, I just picked 540Yen, and embarked to shibuya. I later found out, that getting to shibuya only requires 150yen...so yeah. lesson learned. lol Anyways, I was supposed to meet my friend Yoshi at the Hachiko statue outside of Shibuya station which is a really popular meetup spot. Little did I know, is that its on the east exit of the station. Being my normal stupid self, I exited on the west side and wandered around for a while before finally giving him a quick call. We were going to get sushi, but the place he normally ate at was closed due to repairs. So, we went to this awesome Yakiniku place called Toraji located in the Palco shopping centre. Yoshi in all his glory. I like the fact they gave us those aprons to prevent spilling stuff on our shirts. Also, like a few japanese places in Seattle, it looks like no matter where you go, you get something to clean your hands with before the meal. I think its really cool, and wish more places over stateside did the same. Here on the menu they explain all the different cuts of meat, and where they come from. We ended up getting the Toraji Assortment to the right there along with some Salad that was actually really good. It had was really good and had some light tasting type of dressing on it similar to what you get a teriyaki places. OM NOM NOM NOM. The meat was seriously amazing. It was super soft, and falls apart in your mouth.   Next up was a short walk down the street over to another shopping centre(forgot the name) for some desert. It had tons of stuff in the lower levels like phones+accessories(yes a whole floor dedicated to that),appliances, TVs, and video games. At the top we came a place called Nishimura Fruits Parlour. My inner Gintoki was not dissappointed, and this Strawberry+Bannana parfait was really good. As you can see, I started tearing through it, then realized I needed to take a picture. haha Heading back to the train station, I saw this epic MIB3 banner. lol I remembered I forgot to grab a picture of my station, so I did so on the way home from dinner. The ticket machines I talked about are to the left there. You tend to get a bit stressed out if you've never used them before, because people are waiting in line behind you. lol Horrible shot of the main street outside of the Meguro station that leads down to the hotel My last mission for the night was figuring out how the hell to get this A/C thing working >_< all the buttons were in kanji. So some guess work, and a quick google search helped me get the thing running properly. Anyways, that's about it for my first day here.I'll leave you with a view from my hotel at night before hitting the sack in a few minutes. Plans for tomorrow are to head out to Gunma in the morning to go tour around with my friend Eichi and also check out his Rotary tuning shop Complete Garage Re-Sanai. So, hopefully I can get there without taking the wrong train to somewhere :p

posts.title: Yes, i'm still alive and Japan Trip #3!
posts.markdown: hey everyone, sorry for being so dead recently. I've just been busy with work, life stuff, and alot of awesome stuff with Yuki which you'll see some posts about starting the new year. that aside, I just wanted to give a heads up that i'm going back to japan again! This time its for the holidays. I'm trying to finish packing as we speak before flying out later this afternoon. So, Look forward to some more awesome Japan related stuff coming your way over the next couple weeks! Later!

posts.title: Ghost!
posts.markdown:
so, you may have noticed things look quite a bit different around here.

I recently worked on migrating over from Wordpress to a new awesome blogging platform written in NodeJS(Soon to be EmberJS) called [Ghost](http://ghost.org)! 

At the moment, I still have a few more things to work out. But, feel free to shoot me an e-mail or comment is you have any issues or suggestions. Thanks!

posts.title: Catching the Drift Bug
posts.markdown:
![](/content/images/2014/Aug/1553331_485993748169598_3097342204559669187_o.jpg)

When I initially built my s13 named Yuki, I decided I wasn't going to be doing that many track days in an effort to keep her clean and unmolested by unsuspecting corners, cones, and whatever else jumps out at you on circuits.

well....that didn't last very long and after driving at Ebisu Circuit for the [Team Orange Drift School](http://domofactor.com/japan-trip-day-3team-orange-drift-school-ebisu-circuit/) back in 2012, I ended up doing a few other drift days here and there over the course of the next few years.

![](/content/images/2014/Aug/evd117_7.jpg)

![](/content/images/2014/Aug/evd117_9.jpg)

Here's some footage of how bad I was! ;)

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/jJjXtF3o8A4" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/2zsXOAKbVMM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> 

Before I knew it, I caught the drift bug. However, I wanted to drive somewhere else other than Evergreen Speedway for a long list of reasons i'll save for another time. Also, I felt like only driving once a year made it really hard to improve.

I'd heard of a cool tight technical track similar to Ebisu and experienced briefly over at PGP. However, it being roughly a 3 hours from my place north of Seattle, I was hesistent to make the trip incase something broke. One day I decided to throw caution out the window and not worry about crap I can't control. So, I packed up some tires with my friend Kyle from Krafted Photography and headed down to Pat's Acres Racing Complex(PARC) 30 minutes south from Portland in Canby,OR.

![](/content/images/2014/Aug/1795309_464591520309821_488100340401595196_o.jpg)

As expected, I sucked my first time down there having only driven 3 times over the course of 2 years. But, it was a good way to knock off the rust at a low speed while still having fun.

![](/content/images/2014/Aug/1912301_462640397171600_1520772669086714824_o.jpg)

![](/content/images/2014/Aug/1941616_464591216976518_1664646937236144369_o.jpg)

Here's some video evidence! My entry and throttle control got better, but I still needed some work on transitions. 

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/gBPVMfuWegQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

It gets super slippery in the wet and I learned the hard way how important using a bit of front brake and a bit more caution can be. The result was getting into a bit of a fight with some bushes, which I had to get pulled out of by the tractor. :p

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/GdP8XDjzNRk" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

After making another trip to japan the following month(which i'll cover sometime soon), I was able to make it back down to PARC in July with my buddy Thomas whom I previously met at an event at Evergreen Speedway earlier in the year and also owns a purple s13.
![](/content/images/2014/Aug/10428187_485995058169467_6604621092152602861_o.jpg)

This time, it was a mix of dry and wet weather all morning until it finally cleared up towards the end of the day. 

![](/content/images/2014/Aug/10557143_485993534836286_710580760615286158_o-1.jpg)

Until then, I had oddly always just drifted in the wet. So, it took some getting used to with having a higher entry speed and ALOT more grip in the corners.

![](/content/images/2014/Aug/10571937_485994461502860_8157745290445306443_o.jpg)

Overall though, the improvement I made from morning to late afternoon that day surprised even myself! I went from spinning out once or twice, to linking the entire course. Its also worth mentioning, I did my first tandems ever that day and also took part in a 10 car drift train!

![](/content/images/2014/Aug/10556880_485995231502783_118520742031910675_o.jpg)

![](/content/images/2014/Aug/10575333_485994254836214_8240608406277007907_o-1.jpg)

![](/content/images/2014/Aug/10383870_485994271502879_2278150614988902954_o.jpg)

and more moving pictures....

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/X5lki2aBhrs" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/9c7th1J1b2E" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

After this latest trip, I came away with three things that I learned.

__1. Don't use up all your gopro battery in the beginning of the day__ (makes you look bad on video)
__2. Remember to keep the revvs up in the power band__ (also makes you look bad on video)
__3. Tandem drifting is mad fun__ (makes you look awesome on video)

I can't wait to get back out there and kill some tires and meet more awesome people! The next event coming up is PARC Fest. So, look for some updates soon!

users.bio: Hey, I'm Terrell from Seattle,WA. I go drifting, visit japan, and fix broken Linux boxes!

settings.value: This place has stuff about cars and japan! :)
